PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Archer (from 165 citizens) and Senator Calvert (from 50 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Australian Labor Party should return to its traditional support for the Constitutional Monarchy as represented by Messrs Chifley, Evatt and Hayden and reject support for an Australian Republic being promoted by Mr Hawke and Mr Keating.
Your petitioners therefore request that:
The Senate call on the Australian Labor Party to return to its traditional support for the Constitutional Monarchy.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. the petitioners note particularly that:

PETITION.PARA: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PARA.TAB: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PETITION.PARA: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.TITLE: World Heritage Listing of the Nullarbor Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned oppose the attempts by the Federal Government to World Heritage List the Nullarbor Region.
In doing so, we condemn the State and Federal Government for failing to consult with the residents of the Nullarbor in relation to the listing proposal.
Further, we affirm the excellent record of pastoralists, highway operators and the local communities in protecting the heritage and environmental value of the region.

PETITION.TITLE: Antarctica: Huskies
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled, we the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that there is no scientific evidence which shows that huskies are:
1.A threat to Antarctica's fauna including seal and penguin colonies.
2.Linked to disease among other animals in the region.
3.Disease carriers because of a failure in the strict quarantine methods used when introducing a new dog.
4.Inferior to fuel driven vehicles in terms of efficiency of transport and impose greater damage on the environment compared to fuel driven vehicles.
Australia's signature on an international agreement will end a significant Australian tradition of using husky dogs in Antarctica by requiring the removal of all huskies presently in Antarctica.

Recognising that since 1898 huskies have supported Antarctic expeditions, have continued to be of value to scientists carrying out research and are an intrinsic part of the Australian presence in Antarctica your petitioners call upon the Government to reverse its decision concerning the huskies in Antarctica and allow them to remain in Antarctica.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, this petition from concerned parents and consumers respectfully requests that the Broadcasting Services Bill which will control Television and Pay Television, will:
prohibit all considerably violent programs,
prohibit indecent and obscene programs, (to protect the young and impressionable),
prohibit blasphemous programs which denigrate religious faith or belief,
establish strict legally enforceable Standards for programs and hours,
ensure that "nothing is included that will offend against good taste and decency
ensure that films are judged not as a whole, but each in its several parts,
that the Bill underpins and supports pro-social media in spirit and intent,
reject industry Codes that will sell-out Australia's defenceless children,
exempt all classification criteria and hours from s149(d),
ensure genuine consumer consultation, so that parents can have access to Program criteria information, and input into decision-making for their home environment.
Because children are defenceless and helpless, because they have no vote, no power, and no advocate other than you.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia respectfully shows:
That the current Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance made by prospective citizens of Australia pledges allegiance to Her Majesty, Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia, Her Heirs and Successors.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

PARA.TAB: Legislate to change the Australian Citizenship Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance to a pledge of Allegiance to Australia and the people of Australia, to reflect the true nature of Australian Government and society.

PETITION.PARA: And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: British Commonwealth Occupation Force, Japan
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectively request that:

That all former members of the British Commonwealth Occupation Force (B.C.O.F.) Japan, who have not established eligibility through other military service, be granted eligibility for the Service Pension, and all benefits thereto, including the issue of campaign medals.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to so grant this request by legislation enacted by Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a)notes, with concern, the Labor Government, after 10 years in government resulting in the worst recession in 60 years since the Great Depression, is dividing Australia into two nations, the northern and western States on the one hand, and the southern States on the other;
(b)deplores the loss of confidence under the Labor government which is a major cause of the collapse in private investment and loss of jobs, particularly in the southern States;

(c)condemns the Government for the harsh impacts of its deliberate policy of high interest rates, its failure to rein in high debt levels over the 1980s, its reduction of tariff protection without lessening the other costly imposts on manufacturing industries, and the pathetically slow pace of structural reforms, on the traditional manufacturing States of Victoria and South Australia;

(d)notes that, along with home-grown State difficulties, compounded by incompetent State Labor Governments, the cost of labour to employers has actually increased during the recession, rather than decreased, ensuring that high levels of unemployment will continue, directly affecting the southern States which are heavily unionised and which continue to maintain inefficient work practices;
(e)expresses its concern that these negative trends in the southern Labor States hasten the emergence of a divided Australia; and

(f)urges the Government to put national interests ahead of its short-term political agenda for survival, and to adopt the Coalition's Fightback! policies which will benefit all Australians wherever they live.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has decided not to include any small business organisations in the July `Unemployment Summit', and
(ii)this action is a further blow to the one million unemployed because small business:
(A)already employs nearly half of the private sector workforce, and
(B)accounts for 96 per cent of all firms in operation,
(iii)if every small business in Australia took on just one extra employee, every Australian looking for full-time employment would get a job, and
(iv)by its very nature the small business sector has the capacity to create a substantial number of jobs because of its flexibility and easy adaptability to changing market conditions; and

PARA.TAB: (b)condemns the actions of the Prime Minister which will ensure that, because this sector will not have the opportunity to put its views forward and to comment on Government proposals, its potential to create thousands of new jobs will go unrecognised and unfulfilled.

PARA.TAB: That the following matters be referred to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs for inquiry and final report by the last sitting day in June 1993:
(1)Psychotherapeutic medication in Australia with particular reference to:

TAB.TAB: (a)prescribing patterns of general practitioners and specialists;
(b)research into the effects of long-term medication and the effects of mixtures of medications and other substances;

PARA.TAB: (2)That the Committee present an interim report to the Senate on 17 December 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a)notes that a public rally will be held at midday on 24 June 1992 to protest the imminent closure of the Northwest Onestop Welfare (NOW) Centre at 200 Sydney Road, Brunswick, in Victoria, because it represents a decision by the Government to abandon single homeless women, the disabled, families in need of emergency relief, children living in poverty, people of non-Australian ethnic background, and the homeless, in a community with 19 per cent unemployment;
(b)calls on the Government to demonstrate its commitment to the welfare of the victims of its policy-driven recession through the restoration of funding to the NOW Centre; and

(c)calls on the Liberal and National Parties to demonstrate their commitment to the continuation of the NOW Centre, as canvassed during the recent Wills by-election, by joining with all those supporting the provision of community welfare services in the campaign to keep the NOW Centre open.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a)notes, with concern, the forecast by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics that neither the Common Agricultural Policy of the European Community nor possible reforms flowing from the Uruguay Round would significantly improve commodity prices in the financial year 1992-93;
(b)notes that only a moderate 2 per cent rise is forecast in 1992-93;
(c)calls on banking institutions of Australia to show the same consideration to the rural sector as they have to the international sector of Australia; and
(d)accepts, finally, that if there is not to be a resource led recovery, there will not be one at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has finally set 22 July 1992 for the proposed Youth Jobs Summit, and
(ii)no unemployed persons or young people under the age of 25 are on the Summit guest list;

PARA.TAB: (b)condemns the Prime Minister for his high-handed policy-making on the run, and failure to consult adequately with community groups; and
(c)calls on the Government to discuss the youth wages issue with a wider range of interests than just big business, big unions and big Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)two reports released on 23 June 1992, commissioned by the Government's own Economic Planning Advisory Council, show that the Government's often repeated claim that structural changes have exacerbated unemployment levels is false;
(ii)both reports show that high interest rates prompted the recession, exacerbated growing unemployment levels and accounted for half the lost production in the last financial year;

(iii)this confirms what the National and Liberal parties have been telling the Government for years, namely, that the Federal Government has no capacity for economic management, no strategies for change and no workable programs that will assist Australia out of a recession induced by the Australian Labor Party; and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Federal Government to acknowledge its economic incompetence and embrace policies that will provide some hope for Australia's nearly one million unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate:
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)two reports, commissioned by the Government's own Economic Planning Advisory Council, one by Dr Peter Brain of the National Institute of Economic and Industry Research and the other by Dr Chris Murphy, a Director from Access Economics, and
(ii)that the Government's high interest rates of the 1980s are the cause of the present recession;

PARA.TAB: (b)rejects the Government's claims that structural changes in the economy have added significantly to the unemployment rate; and
(c)notes that both reports argue that tariff reduction and other micro-economic reforms have played only a small part in the recession and sharp rise in unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the resolution of appointment of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation be amended to provide that:

(a)The term of appointment of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation be extended for a further two months after the Committee presents its final report to the Senate, to enable the Committee to monitor and respond to correspondence and public comment related to the committee's report; and
(b)The Committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources to enable it to conduct such work.
I seek leave to make a brief statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senators would be aware that during the past 12 months the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation has conducted a far-reaching inquiry into a range of issues relating to retirement incomes in Australia. During this time, considerable community interest has been aroused as a consequence. In accordance with a previous resolution of the Senate, the Committee's third and final report is due to be presented on or before 10 September 1992. If community reaction to the first and second reports of the Committee is any guide, it is likely that the Committee will need to address the concerns of a wide range of persons and interest groups following the tabling of its third report. At the conclusion of this task, the Committee secretariat will carry out the necessary clerical tasks to wind up the administration of our Select Committee.

PARA.TAB: Further, the Committee believes that during the period of the extension it will play an important role in monitoring government legislation which will be introduced in response to the Committee's recommendations on prudential controls for superannuation funds which were included in its first report, Safeguarding Super. It is for the preceding reasons that the Committee seeks the approval of the Senate for the life of the Select Committee to be extended for a period of two months after the tabling of its final report. I commend the motion to the Senate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Reid)—by leave—proposed:
That the Business of the Senate, order of the day No. 1, be postponed until 20 August 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Parliament, on an all-party basis, is very concerned that the subject of this motion—namely, an independent inquiry into the activities of the Civil Aviation Authority—does take place. The emphasis is on the word `independent'. The concern is with the process that has been followed, not with the outcome of the process necessarily. It is quite intolerable for the Parliament to accept that the practices that were set in place in this selection process become established for major contracts for Australia.

PARA.TAB: I have been surprised over the last couple of months, even as recently as this morning, at the number of Labor senators and members who have spoken to me and congratulated me on the actions that we have all taken to see that due process is followed and that accountability takes place here.

The Parliament accepts that the Government is in no way involved in this issue; it is a matter for the management of the CAA to explain how it came to follow this path and why it came to the decisions it did. There was not the slightest involvement of the Government and the Parliament accepts that Senator Cook is trying to do the right thing and set up a completely independent inquiry. That is why this motion has been deferred. If when we return in the Budget session it has not come to pass that there has been an independent inquiry, the Parliament clearly reserves its right to go ahead and form its own committee to look at the matter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: I would normally seek to speak to the amendments to outline the rationale for them but, due to the limited time available, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a brief speech that I otherwise would have made on the introduction of those amendments.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE (ADMINISTRATION) BILL 1992

Mr President, the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill was introduced on 2 April 1992. The Government subsequently introduced amendments as a result of consultations with various industry and employer representatives. Those amendments added provisions which permitted contributions to be made in advance, excluded certain foreign executives, and made some minor technical amendments.

Since that time the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation has heard evidence on the proposed legislation and has made recommendations in its report released last week. The Government has decided to move amendments to the Bill to give effect to those recommendations.

These changes will be occurring in the context of other changes to superannuation laws, including increased prudential supervision and a gradual increase in the preservation age from 55 to 60, and a change to industrial relations law requiring the Industrial Relations Commission to take superannuation contributions into account in arriving at national wage case decisions.

The Government believes that the Superannuation Guarantee legislation, in the context of those other changes, represents a major advance in superannuation policy for the working men and women of Australia. It will allow them, when they retire, to benefit from a much higher retirement income. It will allow future governments to increase the aged pension in line with community expectations. It will reduce the future burden on today's youth flowing from our increasing aged-dependence ratio. And it will provide for a much needed increase in private and public savings.
Minimising Impact on Employers

As a result of consultations with the Australian Democrats and the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee, the Government has decided to move certain amendments to the Bill with the object of reducing the initial impact on employers.

The current exempt salary level below which contributions do not have to be made for an employee will be raised from $250 per month to $450. This will also bring the annual exempt level into line with the current income tax exempt threshold of $5,400.
The threshold payroll above which the higher charge percentage applies will be increased from the present $500,000 to $1 million.
The contribution period for which contributions need to be made to avoid the charge for the 1993-94, and subsequent, financial years will be changed from a monthly to a quarterly basis.

The charge percentage for larger employers will be reduced from 5% to 4% for 1 July 1992 to 31 December 1992. This rate will increase to 5% from 1 January 1993 unless either House of the Parliament defers that rate increase until 1 July 1993.
The present schedule of charge percentages, reaching 9% by 2000-2001, will be adjusted so that the 9% rate will not be reached until 2002-2003.
Payments to a Complying Fund

A complying fund is a fund which satisfies the standards set out in the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act and its Regulations. At present, the Bill only treats contributions as counting towards the requisite level if they are made to a complying superannuation fund.
Difficulties arise if an employer contributes to a fund believing it to be a complying fund when it is found subsequently to be a non-complying fund.

The amendments include provisions to overcome this difficulty by allowing contributions to be counted where the employer had reasonable grounds for believing that the fund was complying. Similar amendments will apply to defined benefit funds.
Local Councillors
The Bill presently defines "salary or wages" to include payments to local councillors.

The amendment proposed will replace the word "payment" with "remuneration" to make it clear that only payments for work done by councillors will be salary or wages. This amendment will also apply in respect of other Commonwealth, State or Territory employees.
Technical Amendments
The proposed amendments will also cover three technical aspects of the superannuation guarantee scheme.

First, amendments will provide that any superannuation guarantee charge payable by a company in liquidation is to rank equally with employee entitlements. Provisions are also to be included so that a company receiver and manager is required to set aside certain assets in respect of the superannuation guarantee charge of the employer company.

The current Bill operates by initially imposing the full charge on all employers but reducing it for contributions made to complying funds. There is a technical defect in the formulas used to reduce the percentage, which effectively imposes a charge on some employers who have met the expected minimum contribution. This occurs because the formulas count the full period of employment even if the employee was an exempt employee for some of that time (for example, where an employee is 65 years or older or where the employee's salary is below the exempt level).
The proposed amendment will remove that defect by deeming someone not to be an employee in periods in which they are an exempt employee.

Finally, technical amendments will be made in respect of the benefit certificate required so that benefits provided in relation to a defined benefit superannuation scheme can be taken into account when working out an employer's actual level of superannuation support.
Full details of the amendments are contained in the Supplementary Explanatory Memorandum being circulated to Honourable Senators.
Mr President, I commend the amendments to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are all conscious of the time, and I simply wish to indicate the Opposition's position in relation to these amendments. According to the speech that has just been incorporated, the first batch relates to minimising the impact on employers. Our position is that we are still fundamentally opposed to the whole concept of compulsory superannuation. Nonetheless, we recognise that these are marginal improvements within the context of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill itself and the scheme to which it commits the Government. However, even with these amendments, the Government is really only tinkering at the edges and, therefore, we oppose each amendment.

PARA.TAB: The proposal involving payments to a complying fund seems to make sense. Again, within the context of the Bill, it is reasonable to say that employers should not be penalised if they act in good faith and then subsequently discover that they have made a payment to a non-complying fund. Therefore, that proposal, which I am sure will be supported by the Australian Democrats, is one that significantly improves the Bill.

The same can be said in relation to local government councillors. Our fundamental objection is that a whole series of people are being unnecessarily swept up in this legislation to the extent that we will have many more inaccurate accounts than ever before. To the extent that this amendment at least makes it clear that only payments for work done by councillors will be salaries or wages, it is an improvement and is in line with the representations that have been made to us. We therefore welcome that amendment. The same can be said in respect of the technical amendments which are indicated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply want to place on the record the Australian Democrats' role in having the Government move these substantial amendments. I do not believe that it is simply tinkering at the edges, but we had that debate last night. I believe that there is still a question mark within 10 per cent of the community about the threshold level for low income earners. I want to put on the record again that we can do a great many other things to minimise the impact of this legislation on low income earners, and that we intend to pursue those alternatives.

PARA.TAB: I agree with the comments of Senator Alston in respect of payments to a complying fund, local councillors and the consequent technical amendments. I would like to leave time to make sure that we get to the Opposition's amendments, particularly Nos 2 to 5.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask some questions regarding unanswered questions, complications or unintended consequences, particularly about the relationship of salaries and wages and the meaning of the terms `employer' and `employee'. I refer particularly to clause 11(1) which talks about commission as part of salaries or wages.

PARA.TAB: Some three years ago, the ISC changed the rules affecting people working for commissions and said that they were no longer entitled to be part of an employer sponsored fund. It seems as though this legislation reverses that decision so that people who were no longer entitled to be in an employer sponsored fund and who had to provide for themselves through a personal superannuation fund—many have already arranged that—will now become employees. I wonder whether the Government is aware that one of the complications this might cause is that some people who are now in a personal superannuation fund and who may lose a certain amount of their tax deductibility, may be worse off under this proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —People will not be worse off directly as a result of this proposal because it goes directly to merely the payment. There are subsequent decisions to be made about tax arrangements that cover people who are making contributions. I am not trying to avoid the fact that, if you look at all the changes that will take place, it is nevertheless possible that somebody will gain under the levy and, depending on the announcements of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) about the taxation of contributions, it is conceivable that they will lose some tax deductibility benefits.

PARA.TAB: Alternatively, they could cease making the contributions. They would then be better off in terms of immediate income, and they would still get the retirement income benefits as a result of this measure.That is a matter of judgment for the individual. We do not want to make those sorts of decisions. I am not personally aware of the previous matter to which Senator Ferguson refers.

The only other comment I would make is that by this amendment we are not trying to determine the status of people as to whether they are employees for other purposes. We are simply saying that one of the measures of salary and wages for the purpose of this legislation is commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following on from that, one of the things that seemed to be confusing people in the community was the determination of either an award or a levy. We are told by the superannuation hot line that an award overrules the levy, but the levy does not overrule the award. This could mean that in view of the Democrats' agreement that the levy will not come in until people are earning $450 a month, we still have the situation where, for instance, employers in the hospitality industry will have to pay superannuation for casual employees earning only $250 a month. Why is the Government retaining the productivity award system of superannuation now that it is introducing a compulsory levy?

—I made it very clear when summing up the second reading debate last night that it is not intended that these provisions should override or displace award provisions. It may be that an employer and an employee have an agreement reflected in an award to do more than the legislation requires. We have no intention of undercutting those agreements and those awards.

PARA.TAB: This is merely designed to ensure that where people are doing less than the legislation requires, a retirement income scheme is put in place for those employees. Where a retirement income scheme is in place which is better than this, it is not for us to seek to override it. That would cut across the objective of the Bill. The objective of the Bill is to enhance the retirement income for workers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ferguson may or may not know that I was one of the persons responsible for the outcomes in the hospitality industry in terms of the minimum monthly payments. When the discussions occurred, that matter was not finalised in an agreement between employers and the unions, but was arbitrated by the Industrial Relations Commission. It took into account a variety of factors, including the various administration charges in the funds in the hospitality industry, the hours of work, and the potential manipulation of the minimum monthly level. The Industrial Relations Commission determined that level which is approximately $250 a month, depending on the particular award.

PARA.TAB: As Senator McMullan has explained, it is not the Government's intention to override those existing provisions where there has been agreement by the parties or where the Industrial Relations Commission has determined that an appropriate lower figure should remain, as in this case.

SPEECH.PARA: Unanswered questions/complications of Super Bill
Clause 13—Currently a person receiving only award super is entitled to claim a tax deduction of $3,000 towards a personal fund.

PARA.TAB: (1) The levy may take that person above the award—does that mean the $3,000 deduction is no longer applicable?

(2) What will happen to public servants who have opted out of Government super schemes? Are State and Federal Governments going to pay the levy? Will those employees lose their tax deductibility on their present personal superannuation funds?
(3) What happens to a self-employed contractor who contracts labour only to build a shed on a farm—will the farmer be required to pay the levy?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, we should now deal with the amendments circulated in the name of the Opposition. These relate to two separate areas. The New South Wales Coal Association in particular has been very concerned to ensure that its existing scheme and an award which will soon be in place as a result of negotiations between the industry and the union will comply with the new arrangements.

PARA.TAB: I think we all have sympathy for the position that has been brought to our attention. Dear Senator Kernot
I understand that you are concerned about the treatment of some types of award payments under the Superannuation Guarantee legislation.

I confirm the Government's commitment to ensuring that employers who contribute under existing industrial awards that are calculated as a percentage of a standard employee's earnings, will have that contribution counted towards their superannuation obligation under this legislation. SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 7 gives expression to concerns that have been made to us—particularly by Esso, but I am sure there are others in the same situation. As I understand it, the Government is exempting managerial staff who have more than adequate superannuation arrangements being provided by their overseas employers but who come to Australia on a short term contract basis. In those circumstances it would seem unnecessary, and is in fact simply sheer duplication, to require that they comply. But the Government has not extended the same convenience to non-managerial staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether Senator Alston sees any similarities between the impact of this amendment and the situation of the shearing industry dispute. Does he see that the effect of this amendment will be to entrench up to a 9 per cent differential labour cost and that therefore we are discriminating against Australian employees in this?

—I cannot say that that is a matter which has been drawn to my attention specifically, but I would have thought the principle was still valid. In other words, if those shearers, by some reason or other, happen to have generous superannuation arrangements continuing to be made on their behalf in their country of origin, I would not see the need for them to be covered by superannuation in this country. But, of course, in the normal course of events one would not expect contributions to be made for them while they are absent from their home country and, therefore, this provision would not affect them.

—In outlining the Government's opposition to these two amendments, I will pick up the point of Senator Kernot's question, if I understand it correctly. Our concern is similar to the concern which underlies some of the queries that were raised, for example, by the shearers and their representatives. Let us not get into the argument about whether the shearers and their representatives are right. They have raised the concern that arrangements exist which make it cheaper for Australian employers to employ people from a country other than Australia because they do not have to comply with the requirements of Australian awards or laws because, in that instance, they can establish an artificial contract relationship in New Zealand.

PARA.TAB: Our concern with the principle of amendment No. 7 is that in the tourist industry, for example, which might apply in this case, if there is a contest for employment between an Australian employee and an employee resident overseas, it may be that we are building an incentive for the employment of that person from overseas. One can make that too melodramatic because there is a point underlying it that says, `Obviously we are not contributing to the retirement income of that person, so there ought not be a levy'. On balance, at this stage, I think the Government's view is that we should not go in this direction because of the labour market distortions that will arise.

Our more serious concern, in terms of the administrability of the scheme as a whole, relates to amendment No. 1. The two amendments hang together: one is the corollary of the other because one needs the proposed amendment to the definition of `exempt employee' before one can make sense of proposed subclause (e) in amendment No. 7. Firstly, it requires the employers to have knowledge, which it may not be possible for them to have, about the resident status of employees. That information is not always available. More importantly, it requires the Commissioner of Taxation to know what superannuation—or, as has been described here, `benefits in the nature of superannuation', which is open to interpretation as to whether that is an accurate description of what is being applied in a particular country—is provided in another country and whether it is provided in the circumstances of this individual.

The Commissioner needs to know where the person is ordinarily resident. We can all think of circumstances, sometimes very unfortunate circumstances, concerning individuals who are resident in Australia, but ordinarily resident no-one could be quite sure where, because of refugee situations or whatever. The Commissioner would need to be able to determine the level of the overseas benefit in such a comparable way that he could make an interpretation that it is not inferior, as required by proposed subclause (ii).

The facts that are required to make this amendment work, in at least some instances, will not be available either to the employer or the Commissioner. Therefore, the judgments that are required will not able to be made properly. We have the problem of labour market distortion with regard to amendment No. 7. Therefore, we are opposed to both of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I put on the record that what the Government is saying—and I think it is implicit in Senator Kernot's question also—is that comparative wage arrangements are more important than retirement income arrangements. This amendment is clearly designed to apply only where people already have superannuation being paid for them. In other words, there is no need to have superannuation paid in this country in that circumstance, without unnecessary duplication. The Government is saying, `We really don't care about that. This is all about ensuring that people don't get some sort of comparative advantage out of the total remuneration package that might need to be paid'. I can understand those considerations, but I simply want to make it clear that this is yet another example of industrial relations considerations overriding genuine retirement incomes policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a concern about amending trust deeds to make funds comply from 1 July with requirements such as vesting provisions. There have been real concerns as to whether trust deeds must be changed before the law is passed and proclaimed. Would the Parliamentary Secretary clarify that for me please?

—Because of the time that is available to make the payments that would meet one's obligations in the first year, in the infrequent instances, we hope, where either the articles have not been amended to meet, for example, the vesting requirements or one is not certain of the situation, then the employer would be wise to withhold the contributions until that situation is clarified. There is sufficient time to pay because of the deferral arrangements in the first year. We think most people will be able to comply, but it may be that an employer would be uncertain as to whether the payments would be to a fund that met the requirements and may not therefore discharge its obligations under the legislation. Employers would be wise, because we have given them the leeway about the initial payments, to use that time to confirm the status of the fund. I do not regard that as likely to be a common problem or as likely to undermine the whole structure of the scheme. Individuals may have problems and they would be wise to act in that way.

—There is a problem, by reason of the legislation's failure, with predecessor funds within the 21 August 1991 grandfathering arrangements under proposed sections 13 and 14. These will operate as a disincentive for amalgamation of superannuation funds which I believe, and I think the Government must believe, is somewhat desirable. How can we overcome that problem?

—Because of the time available, I simply say it is our view that that disincentive to amalgamation does not apply. Perhaps Senator Watson and I could discuss that subsequently. Our view is that there is not a problem. Can I simply indicate, because I know some honourable senators have concerns they wish to raise, that if somebody wanted to suggest a brief extension of time for further consideration of these two Bills—I am talking about 15 minutes or half an hour at the most—the Government would not resist that suggestion.
—Could we have another 20 minutes?
—I move:

PARA.TAB: That time for consideration of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 be extended by 30 minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Watson asked for 20 minutes.
—I am generous—and deaf!

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a small problem with `retirement due to illness'. There may be some problems with clause 61, which provides that an employee under 55 who retires because of illness should not be in any worse position. Does the Government see this as a problem? Does it believe that people who, because of retirement due to illness, could be in a worse position?

—This issue had not come to my attention until the advent of Senator Watson's question. But, as I am advised, on the face of it, there does not seem to be a disadvantage to such a person, other than perhaps a slight delay in the payment. However, if Senator Watson and Senator Ferguson want more details, perhaps they could put a question on notice or even send me a letter and I will respond to it.

PARA.TAB: The honourable senator may have raised a technical point in his question which I have missed, so I will happily give that subsequent consideration. But, on the face of it, my advice is that the only problem is a potential slight delay in the payment. However, there may be another point and I would be happy to respond to that subsequently.

TALK.START.PARA: —My next question concerns the effect of reasonable benefit limits. The Bill does not appear to make any provision for a situation where no further contributions can be made to a superannuation fund in respect of a particular employee because of the application of the reasonable benefits limit contained in the occupational superannuation regulations. Is it correct that receipt by the superannuation funds of contributions in excess of these limits could endanger the complying status of the fund?

—The Government made a policy decision. One often has to ask: should we make the core concept more complex to deal with marginal cases? I think we made the decision not to do so. My advice is that it is possible for individuals to make arrangements perhaps with a second fund that would enable the problems which Senator Watson raises in respect of the marginal or extraordinary case to be accommodated. That is my understanding of the situation.

—I must apologise, I have another marginal case; I think often the law is tested by the marginal cases. An unusual situation could arise for an employer where a liability to the levy occurs simply because of the unusual case I mentioned of an employee who has failed to nominate a fund into which superannuation contributions are to be paid. This could appear to be an inequitable result, since this is a factor out of the control of the employer.

—This matter is related to a question that Senator Sherry and I discussed, and I think Senator Kernot also raised it with me on one occasion. My advice is that, by the employer making a contribution to many of the funds that operate at the moment, the person on whose behalf the payment is made would be made a member of that fund and therefore would meet the requirements of the legislation. It is a marginal case, not an impossible case. One can imagine the extraordinary circumstance where it might come up.

PARA.TAB: I do not think we want to put another section in the legislation about how we deal with all these extraordinary circumstances, but we have had a look at that. My understanding is that an employer could discharge his obligation under this legislation in those circumstances. I think that is a margin that we have actually accommodated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I have incorporated some questions, I would like an explanation of the terms `employer' and `employee'. I refer to the explanatory explanation which says that:

SPEECH.PARA: a person who works under a contract wholly or principally for labour is an employee of the other party to the contract.

I cite the example of a person who is a self-employed painter who contracts his labour to paint a room, an office or anything else. He is really selling only his labour as a party to a contract. Does that mean that the person for whom he is working is then obliged to pay the levy to that self-employed contractor?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to pursue the example because it raises some extraneous factors to do with what constitutes domestic work and a few other elements of the definition. Once again, we do not want to get into affecting other laws as they impact upon contract for service debates, contract of service debates and debates about determining whether a person is an employee for other purposes, such as industrial purposes. It is an endeavour to be consistent with the Income Tax Act where what constitutes wages and salaries for the purpose of the Income Tax Assessment Act is intended to be what constitutes wages and salaries for this legislation in the cases to which we are referring.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Ferguson is asking whether this makes a person an employee, which may have some consequential impact on other contractual matters to do with industrial matters, no, it is not designed to affect in any way the industrial status of the individuals; it is designed to be consistent with the tax situation of the relationship between parties to the contract.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only other area that people in the community express some concern about relates to the award and the levy. It is my understanding that currently if a person is only receiving award superannuation they are still entitled to claim up to $3,000 as tax deductible contributions to a personal scheme. Where the levy may take them above the award—in other words, in the case of larger companies where the levy will be 4 per cent and the award is only 3 per cent—will these people then lose all tax deductibility of their contributions to personal superannuation funds? I understand that currently once a person receives more than the award, more than 3 per cent, he or she is no longer entitled to claim any deductions at all under a personal fund.

—The Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) has made it clear that he will be making an announcement about the tax arrangements with regard to superannuation for two reasons: one to do with simplification; and the other to do with the consequences of the passage of this legislation. That statement is merely awaiting the passage of this legislation. The Treasurer has said that he will do it before the end of the financial year, so that statement will be made in the next six days.
—Are they achievable?
—The options are getting a bit narrow to achieve. But the Treasurer does intend to make that statement.
—The last minute briefing of the industry is not until tomorrow.

—We would not wish to prejudge the Parliament. Far be it from us to do such a thing. Of course, the situations that the honourable senator outlined would occur if no other changes took place, but other changes will take place and will be announced before this legislation comes into effect.

—Where contributions are treated as having been paid by an employer to an accumulation fund, the amounts are applied or credited in lieu of employer contributions. I would like to know the rationale of the Government's decision not to allow this. I point out to the Committee that these amounts could be drawn either from reserves representing forgone benefits or from the conversion of a former defined benefit fund to an accumulation fund. It seems to be a harsh provision in relation to people who have set up generous funds in the past and who do not seem to qualify under the new regime. It is another situation, I believe, where we should have some transitional arrangements.

—My advice is that there is concern within the Insurance and Superannuation Commission about the consequences such arrangements might have for funds. It is not at this stage satisfied that it could put arrangements in place to ensure that people could proceed in the direction the honourable senator outlined and still be serving the best interests of the beneficiaries of the fund. So it is not that we are totally unaware of the need to address this issue, but there is not at this stage an agreement that we have satisfactory arrangements in place. There may be in future. I do not want to go as far as we did on the other matter in giving a guarantee that we will act, because there may be no mechanism by which we effectively can act. There is within the ISC a consciousness of this issue but some concern about possible implications. So we have not yet sought to proceed to facilitate those sorts of arrangements.

—I thank the Parliamentary Secretary for his assurance that the Government will examine this issue but, if I may speak to the problem, we could reach a situation where employees are entitled to greater benefits where a defined benefit fund is converted to what is essentially an accumulation fund. It may still be classified as a defined benefit fund under the Act because there is a grandfathering minimum benefit guarantee for membership prior to the date of conversion. I thank the Parliamentary Secretary for his offer to examine this proposal and I hope that he, in conjunction with the ISC, is successful in overcoming this problem.

—I also want to ask the Parliamentary Secretary about the Government's policy and how it affects these provisions. I want to deal narrowly, within the confines of this committee stage debate, with the clauses that we are now examining. Many workers now desire to retire early but do not do so because, if they did, there would be a substantial drop in their standard of living. Many of them have not paid off their houses.

PARA.TAB: Because of the current employment situation, if the Government's policy were to encourage persons to retire early, should they so desire, why has that not been reflected in this Bill? I wonder about the proposition to provide for the vesting to age 60. I know about the transitional provisions and the sliding scale, but is it not a fact that the sliding scale is drawn in such a fashion that it would unduly affect the persons who, for example, might wish to retire at the age of 55?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine raises a serious question, but it will be addressed. I cannot say anything about the extent to which it will be addressed but it will be dealt with by next week's statement by the Treasurer concerning tax arrangements rather than here now. This is about what arrangements the superannuation funds have to make about preservation up to age 55 et cetera. The arrangements will cover whether a person can leave work at 55 and get benefits and whether they can take any of their lump sum for mortgages et cetera. These issues have been in debate at the very least since the Wollongong conference that some of us attended concerning superannuation, and they have been debated to some extent by, for example, the ACTU, for longer. That is a matter that will be addressed in next week's tax arrangements statement by the Treasurer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with a measure that is putting in place certain provisions which will virtually be set in concrete. The Parliamentary Secretary will appreciate that, in the absence of that definitive statement, it is difficult for us to see just where we should go. I will deal with the other matters that concern me under the next Bill because they do not come up here.

SPEECH.PARA: For the same reasons as for the earlier Bill, I again seek leave to have my speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, these amendments are consequential to the amendments being moved in relation to the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992. The amendments will also make changes to the Industrial Relations Act as a result of the proposed introduction of the superannuation guarantee scheme.
Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987

Amendments are proposed to the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 to require superannuation funds established on or after 1 July 1992 to provide prescribed information to the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. On receipt of this information the name and address of the fund will be incorporated into a list of superannuation funds which may be able to accept superannuation guarantee moneys. These amendments will also allow the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to disregard a breach of superannuation fund conditions if such a breach has been notified to the Commissioner and employer sponsors as soon as practicable and has been rectified within a period of grace. If the fund is unable to correct the breach, all member benefits including superannuation guarantee moneys, will need to be transferred to another complying superannuation fund so that the first fund may still be recognised as a complying superannuation fund for income taxation purposes for the relevant year.
Tax Acts

Amendments are proposed to a number of Tax Acts to incorporate a reference to the provision being inserted in the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 requiring a receiver and manager to set aside certain company assets to cover the superannuation guarantee charge of an employer company. The amendments enable the amount of superannuation guarantee charge to be taken into account where company assets are also required to be set aside to cover other taxes such as income tax.
Industrial Relations Act 1988

The Government has also agreed with the Australian Democrats that an amendment be made to the Industrial Relations Act 1988 to permit the superannuation contributions contemplated by the superannuation guarantee scheme to be taken into account when the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is making its decisions in National Wage Cases.
Details of the amendments are contained in the Supplementary Explanatory Memorandum being circulated to Honourable Senators.
Mr President, I commend the amendments to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the amendments in relation to the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act are consequential. Requiring the information to be provided to the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner in order to provide a list of funds which will be able to accept superannuation guarantee moneys is a logical consequence of the Superannuation Guarantee Levy Bill. We therefore do not have any major objection, except our fundamental one in principle to the whole regime.

PARA.TAB: The change to the Income Tax Assessment Act, again requiring a receiver and manager to set aside certain company assets to cover the superannuation guarantee charge of an employer company, is an extension of the principle of funding and is certainly consistent with the approach of the Bill. I would like to pose a question to Senator McMullan in relation to the proposed amendment to the Industrial Relations Act. In the accompanying speech, Senator McMullan says—and indeed I think this was the form of words agreed upon by the Australian Democrats—that the superannuation contributions would be taken into account by the IRC. The amendment proposed is that the Commission must have regard to the operation of the Act—and I

SPEECH.PARA: presume that refers to the 1992 Act rather than the 1922 one. Could Senator McMullan indicate whether there is, in fact, any distinction between `taking into account' and `having regard to'?

PARA.TAB: We will certainly be watching with a great deal of interest to see the extent to which the Industrial Relations Commission genuinely discounts wage claims to take account of the SGC regime. I have to say, however, that its track record and its constitutional obligation to accord primacy to industrial relations considerations and the conciliation and arbitration of industrial disputes ahead of sensible wage outcomes, productivity increases and general affordability principles are well known. Therefore, we are somewhat sceptical about the prospects of a genuine discount being put into place, other than the sorts of discounts that have accompanied national wage cases in recent years whereby pious promises are made about future work practices being negotiated away and those future promises forming the current basis for wage increases. Could Senator McMullan indicate whether what he has in mind for the Commission simply takes into account or has regard to discounting up front; in other words, taking account of performance to date rather than merely future promises?

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be a matter entirely for the Industrial Relations Commission to decide on the appropriate weight to be given to the level of contributions contemplated under the superannuation guarantee legislation when dealing with national wage case applications. The Government felt that under the Industrial Relations Commission's existing powers and responsibilities what this amendment does could in any event have been achieved, and in our view would have been achieved. We are trying to make it an explicit requirement simply to make it more apparent. We believe that it would have been inevitable and desirable that the Industrial Relations Commission would have taken these factors into account and it would have been reflected in any Government submission to that case.

PARA.TAB: We do not regard the change of wording as of any significance; it is intended to be the same. As Senator Alston knows, the Industrial Relations Act is not my area. As I understand it, the drafting has to be consistent with other factors. We cannot decide in advance how the Industrial Relations Commission should take it into account; if we did have a view, we could not guarantee that the Commission would agree with it. That is one of the glories of the Commission's independence—an independence which we support even when sometimes we do not like the outcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Senator McMullan saying that the Government will not put a position to the Commission as to the way in which it ought to be taken into account? If he is not saying that—I expect he is not—does it follow that the Government will simply take the same general approach that it has taken in the past, so that it would regard the Commission as having taken into account this new regime if it simply proceeds on the basis of future promises of productivity outcomes or work practice negotiations?
—That is a level of specifics to which I cannot commit the Government in advance, even if I were the Minister for Industrial Relations—which I am not and for which I am duly grateful.

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not excluding all the other options, simply Minister for Industrial Relations. This is not one of the world's great self-denying ordinances that the Senate is hearing.
—You are available for almost anything.
—Would Senator Alston like to make some offers?
—You're not doing too well on that side!

—We can worry about that on another occasion. I understand that there is a vacancy for the Premier of New South Wales, but I am not applying for that either. Other honourable senators have raised the same issue with me. We cannot decide in advance what submission the Government will make, but obviously the Government will make a submission to the national wage case bench with regard to this part of its responsibility as with regard to all its other responsibilities, but I cannot now say what it will say.

—One thing that influenced me in my decision to push for this explicitness was simply that, on the one hand, we were compelling employers to a certain course of action, while the other party in the equation was asking us to take in good faith based on past practice a promise that it would continue to hold down wage claims according to the inflation levels of major trading partners. I do not think it is enough to take a person's word on the one hand and to apply compulsion on the other.

PARA.TAB: This is a reasonable compromise. Unlike Senator Alston, I have some faith in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. We need an independent arbiter, and we have one. Perhaps Senator Alston and the Australian Democrats could make our own submission—nothing can stop us doing so—on the next national wage case. If Senator Alston wants to argue for up-front discounting—and I also am attracted to that proposal—there is nothing to stop us making a case for that. In the meantime, I believe that we have a reasonable outcome, which is an explicit direction to the Industrial Relations Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to this question because it gives me a great deal of concern, and I am sure that I am speaking for a number of people on one side of the chamber who perhaps cannot express this view. I cannot possibly go along with this proposition because it has grave implications now and into the unforeseen future.

PARA.TAB: Under this legislation the Government is virtually instructing the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to take account of what has occurred as a result of these measures. In plain terms, that means that it will discount increases that the workers are entitled to in national wage cases as a result of increases in the cost of living. There is no way that I would go along with that proposition. That is what the result will be.

The worker is not getting the money now in his or her pocket. The worker already has had his or her wage rate substantially slashed. For example, since 1984 the tradesman's rate has declined by 14.6 per cent. That is now due to decline even further. That is one reason why families cannot live on one income. For example, an ASO4 in the Australian Public Service has also had his or her salary decline in real terms by about that amount.

The Government is offsetting a particular percentage, but what about when it comes to the figure of 9 per cent? The Government is building into the Industrial Relations Act a provision which virtually tells the Commission to discount increases that the worker desires and needs as a result of increased costs of living.

The other point is that the wage of a worker who is 30 years of age, for example, and who is living on one income and struggling to make ends meet for his wife and family, will be cut. The wage in his pocket will be cut as a result of this legislation and for what? So far as he is concerned it is for something that will occur in 30 years time. What government will be in power here in 30 years time? When an older worker who is now 50 years of age retires and becomes eligible for a part pension, who is to say that the government at that time will not discount the pension to be paid to the person who is entitled to superannuation?

I have grave problems with this particular provision. I feel that the Parliamentary Secretary should answer on behalf of the Government the questions I have raised on behalf of the Government. I want to hear what he has to say about the views the Government will take in respect of this before the Industrial Relations Commission. It is important to know that before we vote. It is probably important on that side of the House, it is equally important from my point of view and, presumably, from the point of view of the Senator McMullan's colleagues. The Government must have thought about this and I would like Senator McMullan to respond and let us know what its views are.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very important issue, and we have very little time. I did make it quite clear in my response to Senator Alston the essence of the Government's view with regard to this matter. It was always the Government's view, and it has always been explicit, that there will be wage offsets for superannuation. It will be part of a package of enhancing the living standards of workers by a comprehensive range of measures, but it will include wage offsets. I made it quite explicit that it is our view that what would be the outcome as a result of this amendment would have been the outcome without this amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING SERVICES BILL 1992BROADCASTING SERVICES (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 4 June, on motion by Senator Collins:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of Bills—
—Is there only one of you over there?
—It is called multi-skilling.

—I am not sure whether there is much synergy between the two, but they each have their separate buzzers. The Broadcasting Services Bill 1992 and the Broadcasting Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1992 represent the first major attempt to rewrite broadcasting legislation in 50 years. They have had one of the longest gestation periods in history. I can recall a solemn promise being made by the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, prior to the 1987 election to urgently overhaul this archaic legislation, as I think he described it, and Mr Willis during the next three years frantically scratching around to try to ensure that we finally had a broadcasting Bill that brought us up to date and would take us into the twenty-first century.

PARA.TAB: The Broadcasting Bill, which is the major Bill in the package, certainly is a very great step forward and will in many respects ensure that the Parliament and the institutions that are established under the Bill are at last able to recognise the rapid change in transmission technologies, the convergence of broadcasting in telecommunications and the globalisation of communications industries.

The current regulatory structures and mechanisms are based on restricted entry to scarce resources and are no longer appropriate. Indeed, in many respects they belong to an earlier era when communications issues were seen as essentially technical problems to be adjusted in a relatively static environment. The Broadcasting Bill recognises that the law has simply not been able to keep up with the pace of technological change and should certainly not be trying to pick winners and quarantine technologies. The new approach is much more deregulatory and technology neutral. We very much support the overall thrust.

In some respects, however, the Bill does not seem to be willing to recognise the pivotal role that ought to be played by the Trade Practices Commission as a competitive watchdog in promoting and facilitating the introduction of new technologies and services; and in ensuring that there is, indeed, a diversity of services and programs to a much greater extent than had previously been the case and which is now, I think for the first time, much more possible as a result of many of the remarkable changes that are currently taking place.

The Bill establishes an Australian Broadcasting Authority with less intrusive requirements than the existing tribunal. It encourages diversity and competition, and allows the introduction of more broadcasting services. Decisions have yet to be made on licence fees for commercial broadcasting services and on the detail for the price based competitive licence allocation processes. Reduced reporting requirements will result in lower costs to the broadcasting industry; improved efficiency should result from greater competition; and greater economic activity in the supply of equipment and programs should be generated by facilitating the introduction of new technologies and services.

The Bill is therefore a significant step forward, but in some respects it does not go as far as we would like. I think it is appropriate that I take the opportunity today to spell out the preferred course we believe that broadcasting should take—and I use the word `broadcasting' in the broadest sense. One probably could not find a better example of the difficulties that legislators have in keeping up with the pace of technological change than a broadcasting Bill which is now regulating `narrowcasting'. In logical terms, that is a contradiction, but nonetheless it is a reflection that there are now so many different gradations of service and degrees of difficulty of access that one simply cannot mandate technologies, one cannot require people to stay within boxes any more, and one therefore ought to have a regime that will facilitate change in an effective manner.

I turn to some of the proposals that we intend to put forward and the amendments that we intend to move in due course. We require greater parliamentary scrutiny of planning measures and procedures by making a number of changes proceed by way of disallowable instruments. In the area of commercial radio and television, there is the obnoxious and indefensible ban on political advertising, which I think even the Government is having second thoughts about, no doubt for purely pragmatic reasons. Maybe the second thoughts have not found their way into a commitment to legislative change, but certainly there have been a number of reports about Mr Keating, at least for pragmatic reasons, accepting that it does not make a great deal of sense. One would have hoped that the debate would proceed on a higher moral plane than that, because it is clearly one of the grossest infringements of freedom of speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would break new ground in the Senate!

—I think we could all have taken the high moral ground without fear of people casting stones if we had accepted the status quo. But once the Government moved unilaterally to do what it has done it left itself open to that charge. We certainly maintain a fundamental objection to the ban on political advertising and we will move an amendment accordingly.

PARA.TAB: In relation to commercial radio, we favour the removal of cross-media rules between radio, television and newspapers. In reflection of the fact that radio is now a mature industry, that there are very many more players, that because of digital compression and the extent to which technology has now largely overcome separation problems and, indeed, the quality of broadcasts as a result of the inevitable moves from analog to digital, we will not have the same problems that we had in the past of a very limited amount of spectrum being allocated to a few major players. That greater degree of diversity and maturity should ensure that no-one will be able to capture the market, and we should therefore have a commitment to allowing in a much greater number of players.

We also want to ensure that applicants for supplementary FM licences already in the system are able to operate under the rules of the current Broadcasting Act. To the extent that there are broadcasters who have applications currently in process, we certainly do not want to see them disadvantaged or not eligible to convert to FM licences. Therefore, we will favour the fast tracking of FM services, particularly in remote and regional areas where there are currently no such services.

We will also conduct an early review of arrangements, but we would retain the two to a market rule at the present time. We would also maintain the requirement under the current Broadcasting Act in regard to religious broadcasts, and we would retain the intent of the prohibition on the broadcasting of blasphemous material.

As far as commercial television is concerned, we have already made it clear that we do not accept the 1997 moratorium on change and we will undertake an immediate review of the limits to entry to the commercial television market. That is not to say that we favour in any way open slather as such; it is simply a recognition of the fact that it is inappropriate to lock oneself into a mould for a five-year period when there are such dramatic changes taking place. The introduction of pay television, which is long overdue, will obviously have a significant impact on the free to air broadcasters, and we want those matters to be taken into account as well. Proposals such as an open university channel, which could well be the appropriate forum for education services to be delivered on the sixth UHF frequency, may well be another way in which an early review of the current arrangements would result in greater diversity.

We would also extend the audience reach limit to 100 per cent. There has been a lot of toing-and-froing on this over the years. No-one has ever really been able to provide a sensible rationale as to why the figure was, I think, at one stage 43 per cent; then a bit of horse trading with our coalition partners took it to 60 per cent; now the Government wants to go to 75 per cent. All of these figures are essentially arbitrary. The principle ought to be that we should not try to put restraints on technology. Indeed, there will be many opportunities for people to derive economies of scale from being able to access the entire Australian market and, therefore, we favour the 100 per cent limit.

The sorts of flip-flops that have gone on in a range of areas as far as this Government is concerned are extraordinary. They have been motivated entirely by politically pragmatic considerations. There is no rhyme or reason for, in one instance, as I recall it, allowing something like 49 per cent foreign ownership, effectively, through a series of direct and indirect interests, and then suddenly bringing that down. Again, there were all sorts of different formulas that were floated by Caucus and others. Finally, we came up with a 20 per cent limit. Now other changes are proposed; whether they be to a 30 per cent or a 40 per cent limit—none of it really matters in the long run.

What is crucially important is that we ought to have access to the best that overseas technology can offer, the accumulated wisdom and experience that will increasingly become essential in a global market. If we are serious about wanting to ensure that we do end up with quality broadcasting in this country, we certainly should not hide behind artificial barriers that will basically result in backwater arrangements. We currently have two free to air broadcasters that are limping on from day to day in financial terms, one owned by Westpac Bank. The end result of that is that they are very much constrained in terms of capital investment, acquisition of new technology, buying of up-to-date programming and the like. We therefore think that foreign ownership is not the bogey that the Democrats would have it painted as being. We will reassess the whole approach on a case by case basis. New Zealand interests will be treated in the same way as Australian interests and local content regulations would be removed as they apply to New Zealand.

We indicate support of self-regulation of advertising. We are conscious of the difficulties that have arisen in recent years as a result of self-regulation, but we do not favour time standards. We accept that FACTS will indeed review and upgrade the standards of the industry. We proceed very much on the basis that there will be good faith in recognising and being responsive to community concerns.

I am certainly acutely conscious of a number of representations made to me about people who complain that all the best movie programs are decimated by back-end loading; in other words, you are sucked in to watch the first hour of a movie as it is essentially ad-free, and then the last climactic half hour or one hour is torn to shreds by the screening of ads every three or four minutes. I have had that experience very occasionally, and I am sure that regular viewers will be regularly annoyed by that sort of system. I am sure that the commercial stations realise that they are on notice that, in a sense, they simply cannot get away with flouting the wishes of the viewers. We hope that they will be much more responsive to those concerns than they would appear to have been to date.

As far as standards are concerned, we would require that a children's television standard be established jointly by the ABA and the Australian Children's Television Foundation. We would make it mandatory rather than optional that matters must be taken into account in the development of codes of practice. We would require in relation to program promotions that the standard released by FACTS on 18 June last be applicable to the ABA, given that it is more restrictive than the current ABT standard. We would retain the intent of the draft exposure, that prevailing community standards to matters of taste and decency must be taken into account in the development of those codes of practice. We would require that, if no code of practice has been registered with the ABA, the ABA `must' rather than `may' determine a standard.

We would remove the R category for pay television and apply the standards for commercial television, pending the completion of a comprehensive public inquiry into content. I understand from discussions with the industry that that is not seen as any impediment in commercial terms to bidding for the licences. There are a number of other fundamental reasons why they might be very reluctant to come to the barrier, but certainly that is not a reason.

I think it is only proper, given the level of community concern about violence and soft-core pornography, that we should not simply rush into the issue and that we should have it properly assessed. The holding position that I foreshadow today is very much in line with the recommendation of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies, which tabled its report yesterday.

We would also favour a code for commercial television governing children's television in violence as being appropriate for pay television. We would require, under the ABC Act, that the codes of practice relating to programming matters developed must also be published in the ABC's annual report. We, of course, indicate support for the continued banning of X-rated material for all categories of service.

Pay television by satellite is probably the most contentious aspect of the principal Bill. We indicate our support for pay television as a matter of principle. This has been on the front-burner and alternatively the back-burner for at least 12 years. It has been a matter of regret to us that it has taken so long to get to the starting point, but hopefully we are almost there.
