The only problem is that when we have fundamental shifts of policy of the sort we saw a few weeks ago with Mr Keating's triple back flip with pike, where even the Minister had no idea what was being proposed until he walked into the room and was told, it is inevitable that what might get one a cheap headline on day one will, when exposed to the light of day by the industry, be greeted fairly sceptically—and I think that is what has happened to date. What we have seen is that a number of the major potential applicants have expressed great scepticism about the affordability of the very limited 12-month exclusivity period.

Indeed, as has been put to me, who would want to put up front something of the order of half a billion dollars, run the very real prospect of the whole deal falling over or being swamped within a very limited time frame and then walk away with a smile? The Minister may know more than we do, but all the indications to date are that there will be a very great deal of reluctance to put in genuine bids under the current regime.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you tell us what you would do?

—I am just about to. Our approach is quite different. We recognise the absurdity of that sort of artificial arrangement and we therefore favour genuine competition in this area. We would retain—set aside exclusively—one transponder for the ABC on terms and conditions as determined by the Minister, which would include a national pay television service and a consortium that would include only Australian investors.
—What about SBS?

—I will come to SBS in a moment. There would be a separate corporate structure for ABC pay television. There would be a requirement that, upon the event of digital video compression providing additional channel capacity, one such channel be provided to the SBS upon similar terms as apply to the ABC—which, in the normal course of events, will be two or three years. So `one becomes four' makes a lot more sense of the whole proposal.

PARA.TAB: A more competitive structure for the remaining five transponders would involve five separate licences being issued so that each applicant would be confined to one licence only or one transponder only. But, again, bearing in mind the imminence of digital compression, each of those would be looking at four channels within a period of several years. We therefore regard that as providing a great deal of diversity.

TALK.START.PARA: —You reckon that is commercial?

—That is certainly commercial. During the process we will have regard to bundling proposals upon certain principles and assess on their merits the implications of concentration in the particular market. We have every confidence, from the soundings we have taken, that there will be—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Powell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me be clear. We are entirely confident that there will be five separate licence applications for each of those five transponders.
—One channel each for five years.
—It is not one channel each; it is one transponder. They will have the ability to access four channels within a couple of years.
—Five.
—As a result of digital compression.
—If you're lucky.

—Not if we are lucky. The Minister can say that the technology is about to slow down, but all the best estimates are that it is going to be with us in a couple of years time. That is the great virtue of being able to take advantage of these technological changes. The Minister might also be interested that we would also allow the possibility of competing satellite operators; in other words, Palapa and Intelsat. To the extent that there is excess capacity available outside this country, we would be prepared to consider allowing the use and operation of those services.

PARA.TAB: Overall, we do not believe that we should be constrained by the Government's position. With the pressure of technological change, acceleration to a truly competitive position is the only viable alternative. We indicate that proscriptive levels on foreign ownership are unhelpful and we do not support the 20 per cent and 35 per cent limits. We indicate support for 10 per cent Australian content based on expenditure, given that the granting of a transponder to the ABC would contribute to the promotion of Australian cultural values. We would require that the reception equipment used by all operators be of a similar and compatible type for a period of three years. We would require satellite subscription services to be, as far as possible, within the technological capacity of the operators, a national service accessible on like terms by regional and remote Australians. We would remove the moratorium on advertising on pay television, which is presently to operate until 1 July 1997.

TALK.START.PARA: —That surely follows.

—It does not follow at all because those commercial operators would be able to bid for any one of those five licences. They will be able to participate in the migration that will inevitably occur—I think the industry accepts this—from free to air to pay.
—But no alliances between the transponders allowed.

—There will be no alliances between the owners of the separate transponders; that is right. If we look at the experience in America, we will find that there is very little advertising on pay television simply because it is an area that is demand driven. If people do not like the quality and quantity of advertising, they walk away from it and they do not pay their subscriptions. We believe that that will be a sensible recognition of reality and the market will determine the extent of advertising.

PARA.TAB: We would also provide for the development of codes of practice for consumer protection. There will be a complaints regime which will require the establishment by the ABA of an independent complaints review panel for complaints of serious bias, lack of balance and unfair treatment by both the commercial and national broadcasters to be appointed after consultation with the commercial licensees and the ABC and SBS. We would require the ABA to have at least one person representing consumer interests. Also, the codes of practice for handling and recording complaints should be mandatory and make these codes disallowable instruments.

The board of the ABC would be required to develop codes of practice relating to programming matters and that these be notified to the ABA; the codes of practice to be published in the ABC's annual report; and the code to be disallowable and, in the event that it is disallowed, the commercial code will apply. We would also require a record and report of written complaints received by commercial and national broadcasters to be provided to the ABA.

We will require that sanctions on the commercial broadcasters include a prohibition on advertisements for one week or on a graduated system and reduce the $100,000 a day penalties on licensees with a maximum cap tied to the same penalties as in the Trade Practices Act. Information to be gathered by the ABA would require the insertion of additional subclauses to provide that a journalist is not required to answer a question or produce a document which would disclose the source of information and that such non-disclosure does not constitute a contempt. That is a matter that has been canvassed publicly in recent days by people such as the President of the ACTU. We acknowledge that it is certainly not desirable to put journalists in a position where they are not able to effectively pursue investigative journalism for fear of being required to disclose their sources.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a better amendment.

—Okay. Hopefully, we will have a chance to look at that and others. As far as the ABA is concerned, no term of office appears to be provided in the legislation. We would therefore require that the Chair, the Deputy Chair and members hold office for a 12-month period.

PARA.TAB: This Bill is a welcome step forward. It is an acknowledgment that telecommunications broadcasting and computing are undergoing rapid change and convergence and that the new technologies which are emerging do not necessarily respect national borders. Many of those technologies have the potential to remove scarcity of the spectrum for radio—in particular with digital audio broadcasting and the fibre optic revolution, which is upon us. All have the ability to deliver hundreds of channels into the home and office. As markets converge, there will be, I hope, a much more market driven approach to the whole area and it will be much more a matter of broad brush regulation and detailed attempts to restrain the rate of change and to somehow second guess what is in the best interests of consumers and others.

Our paramount concern ought to be for the listeners and the viewers. We certainly believe that in a deregulatory regime the players themselves will need to be responsive to those changes, not just in an aesthetic sense but in a market sense because in many respects, particularly in the area of pay television, you simply go broke if you do not deliver the goods. We wish to see a regime that allows for a regulator to take a broad view rather than being required to spend endless hours and indeed others being required to spend endless thousands of dollars on quite often meaningless licence renewal hearings and other pro forma applications. That is something that ought to be put very much behind us. We do not want people using their pockets to freeze others out of the game. We want them to use their resources for the benefit of consumers. They will best do that by investing in technologies and programming rather than fighting to maintain their patches through litigation.

Hopefully, when we have all had an opportunity to digest the amendments that have only recently been circulated on all sides, and when we finalise the process, we will have in place a much better version of broadcasting regulation—one that will carry us through to the twenty-first century.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Alston has said, and as the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, in introducing the Bill a couple of weeks ago, pointed out, this is a major rewrite—the major rewrite—of broadcasting legislation, bringing the Broadcasting Act of 1942 up to date. As is the case with many Acts of Parliament, the Broadcasting Act has been considerably and regularly amended since its original passage. The Broadcasting Act, in particular, has been subject to amendment brought about by necessity due to changes in technology, the development of broadcasting and, as Senator Alston has pointed out, the development of narrowcasting and other forms of technology.

PARA.TAB: Discussions, at least in some form or another, about this rewrite go back—certainly to my knowledge—to Senator Gareth Evans's time as Minister for Transport and Communications. At that time I had shadow responsibility for this portfolio on behalf of the Democrats. I now have that responsibility again. So it has been with some interest that I have watched and been part of the process.

In general terms, the process by which we have been debating the Broadcasting Services Bill today has been a very good one. In late November and early December last year we had a draft Bill with which I was not particularly happy. I thought it took the changed approach to regulation too far down the deregulatory track. It was too much of a hands-off process. It was one which did not really allow sufficiently for community input. The Democrats and others in the community believed the public interest issues were not appropriately or adequately dealt with. It was, however, a genuine draft and I want to commend the various Ministers, their advisers and the departmental people responsible for their part in the process of consultation that took place between then and the introduction of the Bill here a couple of weeks ago.

There is no doubt that all of us had a good idea of what the eventual Bill was going to look like, with the exception of part 7, that being the pay TV section. I want to make the point here at the beginning of the debate that I think it has been a good process. I think that the outcome has been as good as we could have expected in a political environment where deregulation is the go and has been for some years. I think that most groups in the community who are concerned about the delivery of broadcast services to the consuming community, about specific industry areas, about Australian content production in other manufacturing sectors and about the whole question of the ability of this area of regulation to work effectively, believe that we have something which builds on the early ABT experience.

None of us would deny that in our attempts to regulate through that process we have, in fact, created barriers, hurdles and processes which have not always worked very well, even though they may have had the best of intent.From time to time, we found that the old Australian Broadcasting Tribunal did not have sufficient teeth and it might have been argued that, in giving it teeth, we actually impeded its processes. However, that was part of the learning curve.

We will now have an Australian broadcasting authority with a more streamlined procedure but, from our viewpoint, one which is accountable and which takes into account the public interest. At this point I should say that I propose an amendment which reinstates somewhat further, in my view, the emphasis on public interest in the objects of the Bill. In spite of the positive comments I have made, I think that a change in wording is necessary and I will be proposing such an amendment to the objects of the Bill.

As I know there are a lot of industry people interested in this debate, I want to make it clear that my amendment talks about protection of the public interest, but takes into account the costs to the industry of regulation. I am not ignoring that question in moving this amendment; I simply think there is a need in the objects of the Bill to lay that emphasis which, when implemented, will carry through to all of the other provisions of the Act.

Again, in terms of the public processes, I will be moving another amendment to another section of the Bill relating to applications for licence renewals under the Australian Broadcasting Authority. Under this Bill, notification to the Australian Government Gazette is all that is required. The Australian Democrats believe that notification to a newspaper circulating in the area where the licence will apply should also be legislated, and I will be moving an amendment to that effect. We believe the public interest is served by maximising public information in this kind of area. It is something that has been a part of previous processes and we want to see that included in the Bill.

I want to leave all of my comments about part 7 and the pay TV aspect until I have covered other areas in the legislation which I propose to amend. I will also be moving an amendment to ensure that programming standards will apply to all subscriber services, not just to satellite broadcasts. I found that to be a deficiency in the original legislation.

What we have heard from the Opposition is quite extraordinary, mostly with regard to pay TV but in a number of other areas as well. The Opposition puts forward its policy in this area as one which is hands off, deregulatory, all on the arguments of introduction of masses of competition, all in the interests of consumers and industry. It is the fairy story of the day. Yet there are selective areas where the Opposition is quite clearly prepared to regulate. Again, I will refer to most of those in my discussions on pay TV.

I think the position the Democrats take is much more honest; that is, we believe in selective regulation. This goes across policy areas, and is no less the case in broadcasting. We are prepared to say that there are certain areas which we consider to be very important and we are prepared to regulate in those areas for whatever reason. This broadcasting legislation is no different. It is along that track that I am proposing an amendment to have advertising time standards enforced by the ABA in the same way as children's programming and Australian content are.

I am doing this for a particular set of reasons. We have seen self-regulation given in this area and it has not worked. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal stepped in and imposed a set of standards. Those standards are before the courts at this moment. I understand that that court decision will be brought down this afternoon. It is possible that that court decision could wipe out the standards that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has in place. If it does, I doubt whether the provisions of this Bill will be any help to us at all. I understand that the Government's intention was to have the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's advertising time standards carry over until such time as the Australian Broadcasting Authority, established by this Bill, was able to approve, under the processes in this Bill, the whole range of voluntary codes. If there is not anything to hand over as a result of today's court decision, that would be a problem.

I also have an amendment to tighten up the grandfathering provisions in the Broadcasting Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, because I felt that that was necessary anyway. I hope that, if the Government does not accept my initial amendment, it will accept that one, should we have any standards left to carry over—depending on what happens in the courts in Sydney where those standards are being challenged by two of the commercial broadcasters.

That is the immediate practicality. In general terms, leaving aside the court case, I believe that advertising time standards have been seen to have failed under self-regulation. Since that is a very significant area of the activities of commercial broadcasters, I think there are very strong arguments that they, too, should be direct responsibilities of the Australian Broadcasting Authority that we are establishing with this Bill. I will be moving an amendment to that effect.

I will also be moving an amendment, with respect to the development of standards, which asks that we also require the Australian Broadcasting Authority to consider the portrayal of women and their roles in society as part of the list of issues that are to be taken into account in the establishment of standards which then become a part of licence provisions. This issue has been raised previously. In fact, the Minister assisting the Prime Minister on the Status of Women (Ms Fatin) has had a committee look at this question. I believe it is a matter of sufficient concern in the community, particularly to women and to me. I want to see this, along with the other broad issues that are in the legislation, as part of this process which is being developed.

Perhaps an issue of great emphasis for the Australian Democrats in this legislation, as in many other areas of legislation, is the role and fate of our national broadcasters. The Australian Democrats believe that the ABC and the SBS should not be brought under the jurisdiction of the Australian Broadcasting Authority in any way. Under their respective Acts, we believe that both national broadcasters have appropriate legislative procedures in many areas, including the area of complaints. We do not believe that the ABA's involvement is necessary. Indeed, we believe that it makes something of a mockery of the independent statutory nature of the separate Acts of Parliament of our public broadcasters. We want to emphasise that issue. We take that as one of our major issues of concern in this legislation.

Another major issue relates to the ABA's powers of investigation. Much has been said about this question to most of us who have been taking an interest in this legislation. One might say that something of a campaign is being waged on this by people in the media—people who have a great deal of influence and opportunity to run such campaigns. I do not think we should see that campaign as a matter of self-interest.

I share the concerns expressed by professionals and professional organisations about the possible effect of the very sweeping powers of investigation in this legislation on the ability of journalists in particular, and people putting together broadcast programs generally, to put together programs without fear or favour. The ultimate concern is about what sanctions this brings down upon the heads of those people involved in that programming.

I have a series of amendments which do not detract from the ABA's ability to investigate a wide range of matters, particularly in relation to its licensing responsibilities, which would remove its ability to do this when it comes to program content. I believe that is how we can ensure that, in particular, investigative journalism in this country—and there is some debate about the standard of investigative journalism in this country, but there have been plenty of examples over the years where it has been vital to our democratic processes—is not interrupted or interfered with.

At the same time, I do not want to be seen to be wanting to place journalists and broadcast programmers above the law in any particular way. It is a difficult matter that concerns us all around this chamber. I do hope that, in the process on further debate in this legislation, we will come to the right approach.

I have put up a series of amendments which I think will have this effect; no doubt others will have something to say on those amendments. Basically, the amendments take program content out of the purview of the ABA's powers of investigation. I do not believe that that in any way damages the opportunity of the ABA to take up its responsibilities with regard to, for example, children's programming. My amendments would not prohibit any voluntary turning over of program material to the ABA for investigation, which anyone would have to do if, for instance, children's programming were classified. That is a positive and voluntary move. I believe that what I am proposing only prohibits the ABA investigating program material on its initiative as part of the other investigation process.

I have covered the issues of major concern to the Democrats on which I will be moving amendments. The Democrats have strong views about foreign ownership levels. We would not have wanted to see them go as high as 35 per cent in the pay television area. However, I note that the Opposition says that it opposes that measure. Therefore, keeping it at 35 per cent depends on the Democrats. I want to make it quite clear that it will not go any higher—at least not while we are around and while the Government sticks to that level.

I have expressed my views about how long pay television will last. I quiver in my shoes at the thought of a weak Federal government coming in here and trying to lift the level of foreign ownership. We would certainly oppose any lift in that regard. I appreciate that people in Caucus have probably been responsible for keeping it as low as 35 per cent in the first place, knowing that they would have our support in the chamber.

Pay television is perhaps the most significant area. It is the exception to what I said at the outset where we had good, deep and quite lengthy consultation on the rest of the Bill in a wide section of the community with all those people who were interested. We have had a succession of Ministers in this portfolio in the past few months and that has been one of the reasons why the ticklish questions concerning pay TV have not been resolved until the last minute. It has been very much a last minute process.

However, the decision having been made, I have made it quite clear on behalf of the Democrats from the beginning that we believe the package put forward by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and picked up in this legislation is fatally flawed. Our views on that have been endorsed by independent technical experts, academics and a wide cross-section of industry interests who have been waiting first for over 10 years for a decision to be made that pay TV could go ahead and then a series of months for a decision to be made on the basis on which it would go ahead. I quote from a document sent to me by Stewart Fist, who is termed here a `technical writer'. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: No-one doubts that the primary decision to give pay TV to AUSSAT was a pay-off. It was Beazley's bribe to Optus for agreeing to take the embarrassment of AUSSAT off the Government's hands at a fictitious multi-million dollar figure.

I could not have said it better myself, and perhaps I have said it equally as well. To the Democrats, the whole question of pay TV is a Mount Everest issue: it is there so we have to climb it. We have never agreed that we should have pay TV. However, once it was brought to us, courtesy of the often existing unholy alliance between the Liberal Party and the Labor Party, we took it upon ourselves to take the most responsible attitude we could. We looked at a couple of benchmarks and one of those was the consumers of television services in this country. Even after five years, if pay TV does get off the ground, the majority of consumers will still use free to air services. That is a given fact.

PARA.TAB: I quiver again in my shoes listening to Senator Alston and considering the things the Opposition's package intends to do to those free to air broadcasters by allowing advertising on pay TV at a time when, as he said himself, two of our commercial broadcasters are hard up against the wall anyway. The advertising industry has plateaued; it is patchy. There is no slack in there and there has not been for most of the last decade. The Opposition talks about an immediate review of the existing situation applying to commercial broadcasters with the potential of the almost immediate introduction of further competition, again at a time when they really cannot afford it.

I am not here to stand up in favour of commercial television operators. That is not what I am doing. I am saying that Australian television consumers must have free access, as they always have. There is no way one can argue that the introduction of pay TV is a plus. There must not be a transfer across of viewing opportunities to a system which only the select few will have. I will not have one and the Minister said at one point he will not have one. Why would we pay money to put stuff into a house that we do not live in? I do not think we parliamentarians are a very good market, but our kids might get a paper round and get one for themselves. That is their business.

The Democrats have tried to take a responsible attitude. Pay TV was sold to Caucus on the basis that it would involve the development of Australian industry—the manufacturing and production industries—so that there would be jobs in it and that this would be a development for us in Australia. That will not happen if we believe that our market is enough to support a whole new manufacturing industry and development in Australian production. We must realise that we are a piddly little market down here in the South Pacific. The only reason why manufacturers are interested in building up manufacturing in this area in this country is if it provides a platform into the wider market in Asia. They will not be interested. They have told us all. We have all had the documentation and I will not have time to read it all out. It is all on the record and most of it has been on the public record.

They are not going to have that if they have to limp into a process where they have no protection and no guarantee that in this piddly little market, with full and open competition, under Senator Alston's process, with six jumping in all at once and one of them with a major advantage—Kerry Packer, who is supposedly locked out by the Government's system which, of course, I will have something to say about in a minute—there will be a level playing field and incentive for industry development.

So we will get cheap rubbish from Asia, as far as hardware is concerned, and we will have lost a major industry opportunity. Mind you, I contend that we will have already done that if we end up with the Government's package, which it looks as though we will. A one-year period of exclusivity is not enough—all the industry people are telling us that—for the sort of process that manufacturers need to get this platform into Asia established in this country.

It comes back to what I have said—the Democrats believe in selective regulation. Our whole policy on tariffs at the moment, which is being articulated often, demonstrates that. Our policy in all areas demonstrates that and we do not resile from it at all. We believe it is essential to understand what the realities are, where the bumps are in the level playing field, what the market really means and what the market can really deliver.

We believe that this slightly less flat-earth proposal of the Government's is fatally flawed by virtue of the fact that there is only that one-year period of exclusivity. Through some of the process available under the legislation as it stands, depending on what the Government decides to do with the allocation of its second and third licences for the fifth and sixth transponders, it may be possible that that period of time will be slightly longer. There may be ways in which the Government is prepared to stand behind its commitment to the development of a manufacturing industry around pay TV. I hope we will hear from the Minister on those questions.

Reading between the lines, Senator Alston seemed to have heard some of the concerns about viability that the industry put to him, yet the solution for six licences all at once, one on each transponder, puts forward a more fragmented and more economically non-viable market. It seemed to me the greatest leap of logic I have heard in this place since I last had this portfolio, and the Opposition was faced with the Government trying to push the level of audience reached from 60 per cent up to 75 per cent.

Senator Alston was not the shadow spokesperson at that time. The Opposition had a bit of trouble with a policy vacuum. Members of the Opposition had a meeting late one night and came up with a policy which said, `We want 100 per cent audience reached'. So they came into this chamber and opposed the Government's lifting to 75 per cent because it was not 100 per cent. This is the kind of logic behind Senator Alston's position. He stood there and said, `The operators and the potential bidders are all saying that a year is not long enough so we will let them all in, all at once, on six transponders and Bob's your uncle'. That is the greatest leap of logic since `75 per cent is not 100 per cent' and, therefore, those opposite opposed it even though it was up from 60 per cent.

The other thing that really concerns me about the Opposition's proposal for these six immediate licences is this pig in a poke bundling. The mind boggles. Maybe that would get X-rated. The Opposition is saying that it might be prepared for some of those six people to bundle. On what basis? With whom? For what reason?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he told me, `No alliances'.
—You cannot have alliances but you can bundle. Surely the Minister understands that.
—What's the difference between a bundle and an alliance?

—I think probably it will be X-rated and we will never find out. That is really my point. Senator Alston says that operators would require compatible reception equipment. My question is: how? I cannot conceive of any way that that will happen unless there is going to be a separate piece of legislation. Guess what? That will be regulation, will it not? So how, in his flat earth policy with his six transponders all at once, is Senator Alston going to make something like compatible equipment stick? At least in the Government's proposal there is a four-channel single licence for a year—or possibly a little longer—which can be required as part of that licence provision because it is only one at the start. I hope the Government will do the right thing there.

PARA.TAB: I think that the Opposition's proposition is fairyland in the extreme. Senator Alston finished up by saying `when we have digested all these amendments that have just arrived'. My amendments have been in the hands of the Government, the Opposition and Senator Harradine since last week. I know it is only Wednesday, but drafting instructions for them have been generally widely discussed between me and those other people for some weeks. My public position on the question of pay TV has been known since the day Paul Keating put down his proposal and it was accepted by the Government. My digestion is fine. I am disappointed that I still have not seen anything on paper from members of the Opposition. They need to do something about their decision making processes, particularly if they think that they are going to be in government after the next election.

The Bill was introduced at a time when all members of the coalition were here in this place. It was not introduced after they went away. It is quite unconscionable that a party which proposes itself for government has to have a press conference at 10 p.m. on the day before the Bill comes down to tell us all what it thinks, and then gives us a fairy story about buying a pig in a poke, bundling and all the rest of it.

The problems that we have are with the pay TV section. I regret to say that in about 12 months time I expect to be in this place saying, `I told you so'. I hope I am not. However, I believe that we have the Optus of the airwaves ahead of us, with wrong decisions, wrong processes and lost opportunity. I hope that the Caucus members who fell for the story about more jobs and more industry and all of the rest of it will keep a weather eye on this matter and perhaps encourage the Government to administer its proposition in such a way that it will at least allow some sort of viability. Finally, I think that the commercial operators ought to be very concerned about their fate at the hands of the potential coalition government with its flat earth theory.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Broadcasting Services Bill has been described as the most important Bill in the field of broadcasting in the last 50 years. It is a pity, therefore, that the Australian Labor Party Government has done its best to prevent a smooth, sensible, well-considered approach to the issues contained in the Bill. The Bill is far-reaching. It encompasses the areas of radio licensing, the abolition of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, the establishment of the Australian Broadcasting Authority, community broadcasting, censorship and classification. Most importantly, it provides a mechanism for the introduction of pay television into the Australian culture. With many of the measures in the Bill, particularly those relating to the radio industry, the Government is deregulating. This is to be welcomed.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition agrees with the general direction of the Bill, as it encourages diversity and competition, and allows the introduction of more broadcasting services. Therefore, we will not be opposing it. However, the Bill has several shortcomings. A number of amendments are, therefore, necessary, particularly in relation to the facilitation of new technologies and new players in the industry.

The legislation has received considerable community comment since an exposure draft was released in November last year. The draft has changed considerably, especially in relation to pay TV. This is hardly surprising, given that there have been four Ministers for Transport and Communications during that time. There has also been a remarkable number of `policy on the run' turnarounds by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, in this area. Firstly, there was the policy of changes by television interview, courtesy of the Sunday program. Then there was the about-face a couple of days later, just before the Bill was introduced, which resulted in the Bill that we have before us.

This has served only to confuse the community, the industry and almost anyone associated with the Bill who is trying to keep track of what is happening in this area. It is certainly no way to go about introducing and considering a framework to establish a major new area in communication in Australia, nor is it a way to encourage business to invest in one of our few remaining growth industries. There are many groups who have competing interests in this Bill. As usual, the Government has tried to meet the specific desires of quite a number of pressure groups, in a self-interested attempt to run from a number of the hard decisions. Therefore, it has lost the overall picture in a number of ways.

I will go on to a number of issues that I believe are of concern in this Bill. A major issue in the community is the content and in particular the standards that will be involved with pay TV. Fortunately, the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies has looked at this very issue and made several recommendations which the coalition is prepared to take on board. Those recommendations address the very real concerns that have been raised regarding what will and will not be permitted on pay TV, and they ensure that community standards of taste and decency will be upheld.

It is particularly important that in relation to program promotions, the current standard applied by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal be tightened up in line with the proposal of 18 June 1992 by the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations. The Senate Select Committee has recommended that X-rated material is not suitable in any way for pay TV. Also, current standards of free to air TV should apply to pay TV until community standards of taste and decency are properly assessed and the Australian Broadcasting Authority, we believe, should conduct extensive quantitative and qualitative research on community standards. This will establish a benchmark by which to assess censorship levels. Personally, I find it astounding that this has not been undertaken before in this country.

Despite the good intentions of members of the Office of Film and Literature Classification, I cannot really see how they can possibly establish what community standards of taste and decency actually are if they do not receive input from a wide range of the community in some sort of scientific, rather than haphazard, fashion. The Chief Censor admitted to the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards that, in 20 years of operation, no systematic survey of community standards has ever been conducted. Presumably members of the censorship board just pick them up by osmosis when they travel around on buses. That is probably why there is such widespread concern in the community about this issue.
In this context, the Senate Select Committee report on pay television quotes the Governor-General, Bill Hayden—who I would have thought was a good friend of Senator Schacht's:

As a matter of personal observation, the one subject more than any other that people volunteer to me in conversation as I travel around Australia on this job is their concern with television violence.
The issue of community standards also raises other problems with the rapidly developing technology of pay television.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about sex and violence?

—We do not really need Senator Schacht's loopy, loony, left-wing views. He may recall from the debate in the Standing Committee that the Democrats, the Liberals, the Independent and the ALP were of one mind in terms of putting this particular point of view; he seemed to be the odd man out.

PARA.TAB: With the advent of pay TV in Australia we will have access to broadcasts that are approved by the relevant Australian authorities, such as the Office of Film and Literature Classification. Regulatory bypass may be a major problem in the future, with material that has been proscribed being accessible within Australia. Should the Government be concerned about this? If so, what can be done? These are serious questions that a responsible government should be considering, yet this Labor Government chooses to ignore these issues.

There are other problems with the Bill. The technology involved in pay TV is constantly being renewed and replaced. At present this technology is undergoing very rapid advances, due to the refinement of digital compression technology. The question that arises is whether the introduction now of pay TV in Australia will leave Australia with a system that is based on satellite technology that will be redundant in a very short space of time. If so, the introduction of pay TV at this time is obviously premature and the Government is merely in a rush to recover its investments in satellites during the 1980s. The Government would be sacrificing long term benefits for short term financial gains. This is hardly in the best interests of the Australian public.

There are also the complications of competing technologies such as cable television, fibre optics and multipoint distribution. Given that these Bills are being introduced at this time of rapidly changing technology, a number of very serious questions have to be raised.

Can we be assured that the Australian public will support pay TV when it is introduced? Can the Australian consumer afford the cost of set-up and the cost per program, particularly as the costs get greater the further one gets from the eastern metropolitan centres? Will the Australian consumer be prepared to—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are opposing the Opposition's position?
—I am just raising a number of very serious issues.
—You are just opposing the Opposition's position.

—I am not opposing the Opposition's position. We are broadly in favour of the direction of this Bill. We do have a number of concerns about pay TV, however—concerns that the Minister's Government has not really solved at this point. I think they should be raised as questions. I am not proposing them as amendments; I am posing them as questions that the Minister perhaps should consider.

PARA.TAB: Is the Australian market big enough to support the 24 specialised services that this legislation looks towards? If it cannot, will initial investors in this field get their fingers burnt? What will be the effects on the current free to air broadcasters? Will the quality of their services be ensured and will they remain financially viable?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is there a doubt?

—The Minister may not think these are serious questions, but I think they are. Will the Australian public hold off and wait to see what technology is available further down the track? I believe that these questions must be raised and I do not really believe the Government has provided answers at this point. Given that we have put off—
—No-one can.

—The Minister should let me finish raising questions with this one: given that we have put off for quite a few years the introduction of pay television, and given that digital compression technology is in the pipeline and coming soon, one would wonder why we are not putting it off until a more appropriate time in this year.
—Another five years.
—Is it really, as I said before, just to recover the investment in Aussat? Is that why the Government is rushing ahead with it at this point?
—If you wait for the technology to change you will never do anything. It changes all the time.
—I realise that it is an ongoing thing but we are coming to a watershed of a really new type of technology.
—Why do you say that?
—It is so with the introduction of cable TV; it is so with the introduction of digital compression.
—What is going to replace digital compression?

—It is not around Australia yet. Cable television is being developed around Australia and it will be years before it is actually there. There are other problems with this, in terms of the problem of coverage right across Australia. This system that is being set up does not cover every area of Australia. Tasmania is left out, as is Western Australia, and a lot of the inland areas are going to be disadvantaged. Some of these will be able to receive the satellite signal and transmissions through land based systems but the whole of Australia will not be covered in the system that is being set up.

PARA.TAB: Questions must also be raised about the viability of the original players once the whole area of TV communications is opened up. Given the relatively small Australian broadcasting market, will newcomers be sufficiently established in the timeframe that the Government has given them to defend themselves against attacks to be launched by the main players in the media industry and remain commercially viable? What factional deals have occurred in the ALP to come up with the system that we have got at the moment, this rather unrealistic system that the Government has set up, and the timeframes that have been established for the introduction of this new system?

A whole lot of questions are raised about the way pay TV is being introduced in this country. I do not believe the Government has answers to a lot of these questions and one wonders why it is in such a rush to bring it in at this time. This Bill, apart from the pay TV issue, is particularly helpful for the radio industry, and the deregulation that is being put up in that area is to be encouraged. The most serious questions are in the area of pay television.

The Government has gone through a number of policy somersaults about pay TV. This has been seen most recently in the changes and antics of the Prime Minister. The industry is confused and getting mixed signals about the future of pay television in this country. I believe the Government has messed up yet another piece of legislation. Although the general direction of the Bill is sound, it has been left to the Opposition, I believe, to introduce a number of amendments that will make the Bill more palatable. We will be introducing those in the next reading stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The measures in the Broadcasting Services Bill and the Broadcasting Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1992 will have vast ramifications throughout this and the next century. Indeed, the Government said in the second reading speech that the measures are intended by the Government:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to establish an appropriate regulatory framework for the broadcasting industry that will serve Australia into the 21st century.

PARA.TAB: The time that is now available to the chamber to debate this momentous legislation—which will have incredible effects amongst families throughout Australia—is only three hours. This includes the period for consideration of quite a large number of amendments. It is totally unacceptable. It is in fact a denial of freedom of speech in an area in which we are dealing with communications. We are dealing with the future of the television and radio broadcasting services in this country and the effect that that will have on the populace, and here we are denied our true freedom of speech because of the operation of the guillotine.

The Broadcasting Services Bill proposes that radio and television industry groups will be established representing commercial broadcasting licensees, community broadcasting licensees, providers of subscription broadcasting services, providers of subscription narrowcasting services and providers of open narrowcasting services. Much has been said about the question of program standards and, as to these standards, the Bills are a further move towards deregulation. Witness the complaints that are pouring in at present to politicians, the ABT and television stations. As the ABT admitted yesterday, there has been a doubling of complaints in the last two years. The situation now is not sufficiently regulated.

There is a situation of grave concern. The ordinary viewing public does not know where to turn. I agree with what Bill Hayden said. We go around the community and one of the regular complaints that we get is about what is dished up over television. The proposal of the Government, however, is to provide a freer hand to TV and radio broadcasting stations in program standards. That will result in more violent and exploitative sex programs being transmitted over television into Australian homes. Why do I say that? Because we are beginning to witness it now.

What is happening in Sydney? Channel 9 in Sydney is pushing the bounds of propriety to the limit; all one needs to do is to ask the people in Sydney. It is pushing the bounds of propriety to the limit, virtually saying, `If people do not like it, they can switch off'. It is ignoring the fact that has been pointed to by the recent Australian Broadcasting Tribunal's paper that hundreds of thousands of children are still watching television at half past eight at night. It ignores that. It also ignores community attitudes towards taste and decency.

I know, of course, that there is a conflict within the television industry on this particular matter. There is a conflict with those who take a more responsible attitude, for example, in Channel 7. There is a concern that the views and the attitudes that have been taken at Channel 9 are going to rebound on the television industry itself. The Government might say, `That is what we are on about. We are suggesting that the program standards should be determined and agreed upon by the industry itself'. But the question is: who has the final say within the industry? The fact of the matter is that, if it is left to the industry, unfortunately in many instances a situation as to program standards will result because of the everlasting chase for the almighty dollar. That is what it is all about.

That is the bottom line that Channel 9 is looking at, at the moment. I am thinking of the statements that I have read from persons who are in the Channel 9 programming area. The persons who are responsible for them ought to take that on board. The ordinary public will regard this as unfair. The public recognises that the airwaves are rightly owned by the people of Australia. Because of the abuse of this facility by some television stations, there will be a reaction. Many community groups are now proposing to take concerted action, including boycotting products that are advertised on offending programs. That action is their right.

We must ensure that the material that goes over free to air television has certain standards. One of the biggest problems, as reflected by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal surveys, is that many thousands of parents are concerned about the promos for adult-only programs that are shown at times when there is a large viewing audience of children. That is a matter of great concern. It is an area that I have looked at, and I believe that the Opposition has looked at it. I believe that the Opposition will cover that problem in an amendment.

I am proposing as well to include in the objects clause of the Act the fact that broadcasters should make it a high priority to protect children from any material that is likely to be harmful to them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that include their parents? Often they are the worst influences that children can have. Do you want to protect them from their parents?
—I pause for that observation. I will not say anything about it.
—It is a real-world observation.

—That observation will go into Hansard. My amendments are designed to improve program standards and the rights of viewers and listeners. I suggest that if they are not carried, the public and the viewers will experience even greater problems in that area. There have been difficulties in having instructions issued to draft these amendments, but I note that what the Government has done in this legislation is to abolish the provisions of section 118 of the current Act which make it an offence to broadcast over the ABC, SBS or other television or radio stations any item which is blasphemous, indecent or obscene. That has gone from the legislation. One of my amendments is to ensure that the ABC, SBS or the holder of a licence under this Act shall not broadcast any matter which is blasphemous, indecent or obscene.

PARA.TAB: It is important for us to know what the Government is doing to exclude the ABC and SBS from the blasphemy, indecency and obscenity provisions of the existing Act. It is important to know that the Tribunal, over a period, has relied considerably on those provisions in respect of the actions that it has taken. One needs only to have a look at some of the Tribunal's reports to realise that.

I will also be moving amendments which tighten up provisions so as to allow more community input to and parliamentary supervision over particular provisions in the legislation. I will also be seeking by way of amendment to clothe the ABA with further power, as proposed by the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on the role and functions of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. That parliamentary inquiry, in its conclusions on standards, had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear the Australian community believes that TV programs should reflect and maintain community standards.
I have an amendment on that so far as the objects of the Bill are concerned.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am reading from the House of Representatives Committee report. Let me read it. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Tribunal is the appropriate body to determine how these standards are reflected in TV programs through the processes of the Tribunal, including public inquiries.

There is public concern about what are perceived as declining standards, relating particularly to the quantity of violence in TV programs, how violence is portrayed on television and the possible link between such programs and violence in the community.
There is a heavy obligation on the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to lay down program standards which properly reflect community views.

Likewise, appointments to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal are important and there is a heavy obligation on the Government to appoint members to the Tribunal who understand the community's high expectations of them and who are capable of reflecting the community's standards. The Government should therefore engage in a consultative process before appointments to the Tribunal are made.
Where is that provision in the legislation?

TALK.START.PARA: —We do.

—Senator Schacht says that they do this. They do not do it and it is not in the legislation. I therefore confidently expect that Senator Schacht will support my amendment, which will ensure, as the House of Representatives Committee recommended, that the Government engages in a consultative process before appointments to the Tribunal are made.

PARA.TAB: Whilst I am on the question of tribunals, the Senate Select Committee and, indeed, the Law Reform Commission have made observations about the terms of office of persons appointed to particular tribunals. In that case, it was the Office of Film and Literature Classification. Those concerns also were expressed by the Joint Select Committee on Video Material. It is important to recognise that persons who are on these tribunals, including officers of the Film Censorship Board, can become desensitised to the matters in which they are engaged.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate. Is it a fact that on Northern Tasmanian ABC radio late yesterday the Minister Tate attacked the decision on homosexuals in the Defence Force, asserting that the Chiefs of Staff were out of touch, that it was in breach of our international treaty obligations and that we could well become a laughing stock? Did he also say that there was great Caucus disquiet and that the matter probably would be discussed in Caucus today? Can he tell the Senate why he attacked the decision, and therefore the Ministers for defence, on ABC radio yesterday? How can he attack a decision of his colleagues and retain ministerial unity?

—At no stage did I attack the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray. I did indicate that I believe that in this respect the Defence Force was out of touch with community values. That is acknowledged in the directive, if that is what it is called, put out by the Defence Force itself in relation to this matter. It explicitly indicates that the defence forces have a view on this matter which—I think it was in respect of national security matters—may be out of kilter with community attitudes. That is acknowledged by the defence forces themselves in the directive. I was doing no more than that.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister says that he did not attack the Ministers for defence; yet he well knew that this was a decision taken by Ministers Bilney and Ray, as was very specifically and clearly set out yesterday in the debate in this Parliament. How can he possibly say that this is not an attack on the Ministers for defence? Is this not just another example of the disunity and the cracking up of this Government?
—It is no evidence of any such disintegration of the Government. It was an indication of the fact that the armed forces in this particular area—
—Caught out.

—I am not caught out at all. The armed forces themselves acknowledged that their particular point of view on this matter was out of kilter with that of the general community. I have never—and I explicitly said this—attacked the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray. He has made a decision as the responsible Minister, and I am sure that the processes of the Government are quite capable of dealing with this particular matter.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Japanese Participation in United Nations Peacekeeping Operations

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What are the implications of the legislation recently carried by the Japanese Diet authorising Japanese participation in United Nations peacekeeping operations? What is Australia's position in this regard?

—As honourable senators will probably be aware from press reports, after protracted debate the UN peacekeeping operations legislation was passed by the Diet on 15 June. It allows the Japanese self-defence forces to take part immediately in a range of non-military support functions associated with UN peacekeeping activities, as well as seconded public servants and civilian police. These functions include election monitoring, administrative support and civilian police duties, medical support to either the military or civilians, assisting refugees by providing food and medical supplies, repair and construction of infrastructure facilities, and transport, communications and construction and logistical support to civilians and UN forces.

PARA.TAB: The UNPKO legislation also defines armed peacekeeping activities which, in principle, could be undertaken by the self-defence forces but which are frozen until further Diet approval is given. These include establishing and monitoring cease-fire arrangements as well as arms flows.

The Japanese legislation is significant in both symbolic and practical terms. It strengthens Japan's capacity to make a truly comprehensive contribution to international stability and prosperity, quite apart from the major financial and growing political role that Japan already plays. Importantly, the legislation enables Japan to send self-defence force elements to Cambodia to perform a range of support functions. The Japanese Government is about to dispatch a fact-finding mission to that country to examine what form Japanese participation in the UNTAC peacekeeping activities there might take.

Australia supports Japan's participation in UN peacekeeping activities and, therefore, we do welcome the passage of the Japanese UNPKO legislation. This is consistent with our often expressed desire to see Japan assume greater international responsibilities commensurate with its economic status. Clearly, the scope of Japanese participation in UN peacekeeping operations is tightly circumscribed by this legislation and it does not involve a wider regional Japanese military role which, in any case, is not of course sought by Japan. Australia would very much welcome a contribution of Japanese personnel to the current UN peacekeeping operation in Cambodia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government. In July 1990, the Government instituted an Australian country information service trial program which made provision through the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the Office of Local Government for access to Commonwealth services and programs in remote locations throughout Australia. The trial service was funded by the DPIE and in three instances, in the shires of East Pilbara in Western Australia, Brewarrina in New Southi Wales and Flinders in Queensland, these local authorities took on the task of providing the information services for remote Australians. The trial period finishes at the end of this month. I understand that the program has been a success as far as the three shire councils are concerned. Does the Minister and the Department share the view that the program has been a success? Would the Minister also advise what funding the Government will be providing to continue the program after the expiration of the current trial? Finally, are there any plans for the service to be extended to other parts of Australia using local government authorities as the providers of the service?

—I understand that the trials to which Senator Macdonald refers have been quite successful and they have demonstrated the very important role that local government can play in undertaking some sort of agency arrangement in relation to other spheres of government, especially in rural areas, remote areas, where perhaps the local government shire council might be the only focal point which can make available information on the activities of other agencies or the benefits that might be obtained through contact with other agencies. In fact, the local shire might be the only locally accessible public sector infrastructure that can then provide that sort of information. So it has been a success, as I understand it. An evaluation report has been undertaken which supported that sort of intuitive guess that one would make that it would be a very useful service.

PARA.TAB: From the local government point of view, I understand that the Minister would be keen to see ways in which this capacity could be utilised to the benefit of all the parties concerned. The Minister is considering options to pursue this objective, either through an extension of the service or through some other arrangements. I am unable to give any more specific or detailed explanation of what funding options might be pursued.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I mention to the Minister that the program does run out in six days time and the councils and other people involved really would like to know whether the service is to continue. It is quite imperative that a decision be made at an early date. If the Minister, who is the representative Minister, is not aware, could he undertake to try to get me an answer either today or tomorrow on whether the funding is to continue and, if not, why not? Also, could he find out whether it is intended to make it more widely spread in rural Australian communities using the services of local governments?

—I am quite confident that the Minister for Local Government, the Hon. David Simmons, is very well aware of the urgency of the matter and the need to resolve it in a way which will enable the services to continue through some means or another. I undertake to convey Senator Macdonald's sense of urgency, but I do not think it will add anything to the sorts of deliberations the Minister is undertaking at the moment.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the issues to be discussed at next month's national meeting on youth training and employment? Can he confirm that young people have been invited to participate in the meeting?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The question and the answer I am about to give do not have that marginalised peripheral nature which the Opposition, by its interjections, would like to suggest. This is a very important initiative and, as I have already said here, the meeting will be held in Canberra on 22 July.

PARA.TAB: Senator Childs asked about the issues. The issues to be discussed at the meeting will be substantial. The focus of the meeting will be on proposals to increase work and training opportunities for Australia's youth. These will include the TAFE system and its need to be more responsive to the needs of young people and industry. The Carmichael report and the proposed youth training wage also will be examined, as will the funding of local employment opportunities for young people through community rural and environmental programs. Therefore, it will be a meeting of substance.

I find it sad to say that yesterday, just as people have interjected here today, Dr Hewson, the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives, reacted to this announcement in a most negative way. Apparently, he believes that meetings with leading representatives of industry, business, unions and young people in the community are a stunt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did you leave off the Salvation Army?
—Senator Bishop keeps interjecting, asking why the Salvation Army was not asked. This is a summit or a meeting about job creation.
—They are not important?

—The Salvation Army is very important in terms of its contribution to the alleviation of circumstances for people who are unemployed. But in terms of a job creation seminar, obviously the Salvation Army is of lesser relevance in that context.
—`Of lesser relevance'. Isn't that wonderful!

—I know Senator Bishop's affection for the Salvation Army; her affinity with `Major Barbara' is well known. The people who have been asked to this seminar are people who are relevant to the issue of job creation.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I find the implication in what the Minister had to say a reflection on the integrity of the Salvation Army. I would ask you to ask him to withdraw that offensive interpretation. For the Minister to say that the Salvation Army's relevance to dealing with the jobless who are left behind by the policies of this Government is a good reason to leave them off this so-called important summit is totally unacceptable. I ask him to withdraw his implication.
—Order! There is no point of order because there is no protection for outside agencies such as that to which Senator Bishop referred.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. We can tell the days on which the Senate is being televised because each time that happens Senator Bishop raises a bogus point of order—and she has done it again. Mr President, I want to draw to your attention standing order 203 in relation to constant and persistent attempts to disrupt the proceedings of the Senate. Senator Bishop does it all the time and she has just done it again, when she knows there is no point of order. She has deliberately flouted your ruling that honourable senators should not do so.
—Order! There are too many interjections. I have ruled on the point of order: there is no protection.

—Mr President, speaking to Senator McMullan's point of order: if we want to refer to the Standing Orders, I would point out that Senator Button was beginning to debate the issue. That is clearly in contravention of the Standing Orders. Mr President, I can find many rulings of yours and of former Presidents to the effect that that is not acceptable. Mr President, you choose very often to overrule your own findings; but in respect of Senator McMullan's point of order, I find his trying to marginalise the Salvation Army by pulling a spurious point of order to be totally unacceptable.
—I wish to ask a simple question, Mr President. Can Senator Bishop seek to speak to a point of order that you have already ruled is not a point of order?
—Order! I have ruled on the point of order. I am not ruling against an order I have made before on an issue like this.

—Mr President, with the greatest respect, before I go on with my answer I want to comment on your own words in ruling on the point of order.
