I said that the people who have been asked to this meeting are people who are primarily concerned with job creation. Senator Bishop, sitting there in her red jacket, raised the question of the Salvation Army, and I responded. Perhaps she should not do it so often.

PARA.TAB: Let me get back to what I was saying. Instead of supporting the Government's initiative on this matter, we got the standard response from the Opposition in reaction to every piece of good news or positive announcement that came out. We heard the same old negative, carping line from Dr Hewson that we have come to expect. Perhaps the Opposition does not believe that forging partnerships with business and the wider community in relation to this issue is an important thing. The Prime Minister has already announced some of the people who will be attending the meeting—people with experience and potentially constructive ideas who can make a positive contribution on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Laurie Carmichael?
—I assume that he will be there; he has written a very thoughtful document about youth training.
—Australia Reconstructed.
—Order! Senator Alston, it is no use complaining about whether a Minister is debating an issue when there are constant interjections asking him questions.
—The interjection is about the 1980 show, which is what Senator Alston is about. He is talking about a document contributed to by Mr Carmichael years ago. That is how up to date he is.

PARA.TAB: The Government believes that young people have a role to play in a meeting such as this. Certainly young people will be involved; they will be represented by an Australian youth policy in action coalition, which has been invited to bring a delegation of young people to the meeting.

I do not know whether those people, if they have been asked to some Opposition stunt which is to take place at about the same time, will go there understanding the Opposition's policies in respect of some of these issues. Will they understand, when they go to the Opposition stunt, that if you are in receipt of a redundancy payment, under Opposition policy you will have to expend all your redundancy payments on a notional scale determined by the Opposition before you are entitled to unemployment benefits? I wonder whether they will understand that. I wonder whether they will understand that the Opposition policy proposes to close the CES and youth access centres. I wonder whether they will understand that they will have unemployment benefits taken away from them after nine months. I wonder whether they will understand that the Opposition has promised to slash funding to TAFE, as Dr Hewson wants to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. If ever there was a classic example of debating the question, this is it. I would have thought, at the very least, that we should not be exposed to the gross misrepresentation of our policy, which in no shape or form involves cutting off unemployment benefits after nine months. If the Minister has not heard of special benefits, he should come and see me afterwards.
—There it is: after nine months they will go off unemployment benefits and on to special benefits.
—Order! There is no point of order, but it is becoming a very long answer.

—In conclusion, this Government has made a lot of progress in doubling the proportion of young people completing secondary education and in increasing the number of university places by 50 per cent. The measures to reinvigorate the economy announced in the One Nation statement will help to overcome youth unemployment.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. This is continuing the debate. Senator Button was asked about the youth summit and he is now giving us a lecture on his Government's policies and what he claims to be its achievements.
—I believe that the Minister has almost finished his answer.
—I conclude with a piece of information for Senator Bishop. The Salvation Army has been invited to participate in the meeting—not this afternoon.

—I am pleased to follow on with a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate on another point in relation to unemployment. Does the Minister accept that Australia has the second lowest rate of taxation of all OECD countries, equal to the US and only slightly higher than Turkey? Does the Minister also accept that the UN comparison of personal purchasing power shows that, on average, Australians are the eighth richest people in the world? Does the Minister draw the conclusion from this that those Australians in jobs could afford to help those without jobs in a more substantial way? If so, can the Minister indicate what, if anything, his Government intends to do to bridge this gap between those in employment and those without a job?
—There are a number of parts to this question, and I might deal with them one by one. Australia does have the second lowest burden of taxation in the OECD—
—Personal tax.

—No, total taxation. Australia's tax burden is about equal to that of the US, at 30.1 per cent of GDP, and just above Turkey's 29 per cent. In this respect we rank somewhat lower than the United Kingdom, for example, which has a tax burden of 36.5 per cent, and far better than the Scandinavian countries, with a tax burden of up to 56.1 per cent of GDP.

PARA.TAB: I make the point in the context of the question that a variety of countries are suffering the present difficulties which we have in Australia—structural difficulties and difficulties associated with recessions which have led to high levels of unemployment. There are different methods of trying to handle these problems in different countries.

However, it is not with the OECD countries that we should always be comparing ourselves. This is a very fashionable thing to do in Australia. The OECD—I hope it will not be offended if I say this—is very much a European club. We continue to compare ourselves in respect of a variety of matters with the OECD. The fact is that our future lies with the Asia-Pacific region predominantly, and we need to compare our performance with the countries of the world that are growing rapidly towards developed status, predominantly in the Asia-Pacific region. For that reason, in particular, comparisons of business taxation regimes become extremely important.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't want to compare growth rates.

—That has been true for the last 25 years now. The honourable senator should think about the implications of that in terms of Liberal governments. I am not suggesting that we should reduce our social safety net to the sorts of standards in those countries where the priorities are on wealth creation and industrial development. They do not have the sophisticated social safety nets which we have in Australia and which are clearly better than those which exist in the United States and in the United Kingdom. But, in a world of mobile and footloose capital, we cannot be complacent about the competitiveness of our taxation system as it bears on business activity, because it is business activity which creates jobs and longer term employment.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter also referred to an international comparison of purchasing power. I do not know of a report ranking Australia eighth in that respect, but I do know that the United Nations world development report ranks Australia eleventh and that the OECD purchasing power parity program ranks Australia thirteenth. The United Nations human development index, which uses data on income, life expectancy, education and so on to construct a composite measure of human progress, ranks Australia seventh.

I do not wish this to be misinterpreted, because we have a serious unemployment problem in Australia, but the upshot of all of that is that Australia is a relatively well-off nation—which is the implication of Senator Coulter's question—and one in which the predominant number of people are happy to live. The best way of helping those without jobs is, of course, to provide them with jobs. The whole thrust of the Government's economic policies is addressed to providing a sustainable improvement in the unemployment rate. That means we must not threaten progress on inflation or micro-economic reform. We have to have regard to relevant big business tax regimes around the world, particularly with our major trading partners and competitors. To that end, the One Nation statement introduced a number of policies to produce productive public and private investment, depreciation allowance changes, the development allowance and infrastructure spending programs.

The November employment statement and the February One Nation statement provided increased funding for a number of labour market programs relevant not only to the safety net but also to training and production of skills, programs for apprentices, programs to boost skills and so on. The Prime Minister has, of course, announced the national youth meeting which has been the subject of discussion here already.

Real wage restraint is the best way that those in employment can help the unemployed. The Government's wages policy has restrained real unit labour costs so that pricing costs and the competitiveness of the Australian industry are around 15 per cent better than in 1982-83. This will benefit employment as we come out of the recession. The Government has been addressing, and continues to address, the jobs situation as a matter of urgency.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his detailed reply, but I assure him that on the 1990-91 figures Australia is eighth in terms of personal purchasing power and ranks well ahead of all the Asian nations in our region—Malaysia, Singapore and even Japan. Does the Minister think, in view of that and in view of our current low rate of taxation, that it is appropriate and prudent to offer further tax deductions as are offered in the One Nation statement to Australians?

—The answer to the second part of the question is yes, in the context in which those proposed tax reductions are set in the One Nation statement. I cannot agree, as I do not know, but I suspect that Australia's ranking of eighth—according to Senator Coulter's certain guideline—is probably right. There are a number of measures to those things and that seems to be right and consistent with other indicators.

—I address my question to the Minister for Justice. The Minister will be aware of the extreme personal distress suffered by families in which unresolved disputes over child custody or access lead to the abduction of children to other countries. What action has been taken by the Federal Government to ensure that children wrongfully detained overseas are returned to the custodial parent and that appropriate orders in relation to child maintenance, custody and access are internationally recognised?

—Australia has recently made arrangements with New Zealand, Austria and Mexico to deal with the question of the removal of children, maintenance orders and the enforcement of access orders. This adds to a list of about 22 countries with which we have such arrangements. In this respect, certain provisions of the international Hague Convention were effected with New Zealand only a few weeks ago—in early June.

PARA.TAB: I think that Senator Bishop has taken an interest in this particular matter of relations with New Zealand. It is quite clear that abduction of children across the Tasman must be a cause of great distress to many custodial parents who find that, perhaps on an access visit, the non-custodial parent who has custody of the child for a short time then spirits the child away across the Tasman to New Zealand. Of course, the same devastating situation would apply with New Zealand non-custodial parents abducting their children to Australia.

In a situation in which children are snatched away, kidnapped, there is obviously an obligation on governments to assist the custodial parent. In relation to New Zealand, for example, it is now the case that if a custodial parent is of the view that the child has been spirited away to New Zealand, on contacting the Attorney-General's Department we are able to deal with our counterparts in New Zealand. Investigations will be set in train in New Zealand. One hopes that the child will be located and brought before the New Zealand court. The New Zealand court can make an order to require the child to be returned to the custodial parent in Australia. In that situation the New Zealand authorities will pay for the proceedings before the New Zealand court.

We have a reciprocal arrangement and would pay for proceedings being taken in an Australian court to aid a New Zealand custodial parent in respect of getting a kidnapped child returned to New Zealand. As Senator Bishop will know, the working out of those arrangements took some time. But the arrangements have been concluded. I believe that this will lead to the amelioration of a great deal of distress in circumstances where children are abducted overseas by non-custodial parents.

In particular, I refer to the Minister's claim that the NFF was committing millions of dollars of its members' money to a political campaign by a discredited housing organisation—a claim which has been totally rejected. ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that in the field of industrial relations, Senator Crane is getting the nickname `Kerbs'—every time he has a chance to stand on the kerb he dives into the gutter when industrial relations matters come along. This is yet another example of that type of behaviour.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

—Order! Withdraw please, Senator Crane. I ask the honourable senator to apologise.
—I withdraw.
—Order! I asked Senator Crane to withdraw unconditionally. I thought that he did. Did the honourable senator do so?
—I said that I withdraw.
—Order! I asked Senator Crane to withdraw unconditionally the expression that he used. I again ask him to do so.

—Order! I am asking him again. If he is going to do it, he will.

—Mr President, I said `I withdraw'. I did not say that I withdraw `as a prima donna'. I heard an objection by an honourable senator on this side of the chamber and I said, `I withdraw'. That is quite clear. I did not say that I withdraw the words `prima donna'.
—Continue.

PARA.TAB: Senator Walters interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If there were fewer interjections, I might hear better.

On 19 June, the headline of a media release, a copy of which I have here, under the letterhead of the HIA and the National Farmers Federation, said, `NFF and HIA join forces to oppose independent contractor legislation'. A $5m campaign is being run. Senator Crane has made allegations of misrepresentation. Let us go to the facts.
—But you lie all the time.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask Senator Bishop to withdraw her comment. It was heard all over this side of the chamber.
—Nobody heard it.
—I did.
—Senator Bishop, withdraw the remark.
—Mr President, did you hear the interjection?
—Yes, I did. I heard you—
—Was that the—

—Order! I heard you say, `You lie all the time'. I am ignoring a lot of comments to try to get some more questions through because that is what honourable senators come to me about. The point was raised, Senator Bishop, and I ask you to withdraw.

—Mr President, I will not do it conditionally, but I would put on the record as I do withdraw that Senator Cook ought to apologise to Senator Panizza for the things he said about him. Could we also ask for that to happen.

—Order! Senator Bishop withdrew.

—I am going to the evidence in this case. I guess that there is an effort to obstruct me getting to the evidence because that is not what people want to hear. That same joint press release by the HIA and NFF on 19 June said:

ANSWER.PARA: The NFF Executive Director, Rick Farley, said today—
and then the press release has quotations, so he is speaking in his own voice—
"The NFF will be applying its energies and resources in tandem with the HIA because we both believe that this cause—

and it goes on to propagandise. It says `energies and resources'. This is a $5m campaign and the NFF is applying its energies and resources. Therefore, on that basis, I immediately put out a press release with the headline:
NFF wasting millions of dollars of farmers money supporting exploitation and rip-offs.

The NFF has said `its energies and resources'. The word `resources' in this press release is a cute term, because `resources' quite clearly means its organisational and financial resources. In both cases, farmers who contribute to the coffers of the NFF are finding that part of their contributions is being used for this gross political purpose. I do not think that the boot is on my foot; the boot is on Senator Crane's foot. The boot is also on the foot of the NFF to explain to its constituency why it is misusing its funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I preface my question by referring to today's press reports stating that people who entrusted their savings to the Pyramid Building Society will lose at least two-thirds of the value of their deposits. First, is the Minister aware of the recommendation contained in the 1981 Campbell committee report that the Commonwealth should regulate and supervise building societies? Secondly, in view of the Federal Government's neglect to act on this recommendation, does the Minister feel any responsibility on behalf of the Commonwealth for the people who lost their savings in the Pyramid Building Society debacle? Finally, is the Minister now disposed to support my private member's Bill, entitled the Financial Corporations Prudential Standards Amendment Bill, which seeks to activate legislation that was passed by this Parliament in the 1970s but never proclaimed, and which is designed to protect small investors who entrust their moneys to building societies?

—There are a number of parts to that question. First, in dividing up responsibility for the Pyramid Building Society collapse, it should be remembered that at least two of the directors of that society are currently on trial. One would not want to say anything that might prejudice those trials. I am aware that the Campbell committee made a recommendation. Indeed, it made many recommendations, and not all of them were accepted by the Government at the time. There were some constitutional and historical reasons for that because this has been a matter traditionally dealt with by the States and that has proved to be inadequate.

PARA.TAB: In so far as the allegation of Federal Government neglect is concerned, the Government has been quite active about this issue. The Australian Financial Institutions Commission has been established and the Commonwealth has endorsed, pushed and actively supported the establishment of a nationally coordinated but State-based system of high uniform prudential standards for building societies and credit unions. I think it is fair to say that we have been the pushers in this, and the Premiers entered into a formal agreement in November 1991 to establish this new supervisory framework. This was, of course, after the Pyramid collapse, but was on the basis of the experience with that building society and others.

The Commonwealth endorsed the agreement, subject to the necessary legislation being consistent with the 1991 heads of agreement between the Commonwealth and the States on corporate regulation. The AFIC legislation meets this test. Subsequently, the Commonwealth-State ministerial council for corporations has asked officials to examine measures to achieve a more rational interface between the corporations law and the Australian Financial Institutions Commission legislation.

There have been different points of view expressed by various States. I understand legislation has now been reached in Queensland which meets the appropriate test and that legislation in other States is in the course of introduction. From my own knowledge, the Commonwealth has been putting a lot of pressure on the States to resolve this issue. If it is not resolved in the next month or two to the satisfaction of building society contributors Australia-wide, the Commonwealth may need to take some further action in the matter.

With regard to Senator Spindler's Bill, I have not looked at it personally and do not know whether it is the appropriate vehicle for dealing with this issue or not. However, in the light of what is currently in train, I think it may not be necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's answer, I believe that those who ignore history are bound to repeat mistakes, if I can paraphrase that saying. There has been the example of companies legislation being attempted to be done on a cooperative basis between the States and failing lamentably. Surely we do not need to repeat this performance of trying to coax States into doing something that apparently they are incapable of doing. I ask for the Minister's personal expression of opinion. Would it not be better for the Commonwealth to legislate and make sure that it has the power to regulate building societies and protect investors directly?

—I cannot express a legal opinion on this matter, but I think the Commonwealth powers under the corporations powers are probably not quite as sufficient as we would like. That is why the Commonwealth has followed the course which it is following. It is desirable that there be uniform legislation. If it can be negotiated successfully with the States, I think that will provide the best solution.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a delegation from the Parliament of Venezuela, led by Mr Rafael Tudela. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome the delegation to the Senate and trust that the visit will be both informative and enjoyable. At the same time, I draw the Senate's attention to the presence in my gallery of former Senator John Olsen.

ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I was actually quoting from the letter sent to me under the letterhead of the MBA of Australia and signed by John Murray as the Executive Director. TALK.START.PARA: —Neither do you.
—The first time Senator Macdonald represents the facts, it will break his duck.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. In the light of the rulings you have made earlier in the day, could you ask the Minister if he could tell the Senate the distinction between getting it wrong and telling a lie?
—There is no point of order.
—Do you mean to say we still can't say he is telling lies?
—Senator Walters!

—I raise a point of order in relation to the Minister's comments directed at Senator Macdonald. They clearly infringe the Standing Orders which require any person answering a question not to disparage a member of either House or to impugn motives to him.

—I wish to speak to the point of order, Mr President. Senator Macdonald made an interjection—I did not regard it as terribly offensive—and Senator Cook simply put the same interjection back to him. If Senator Macdonald is able to make the interjection and we do not take too much offence—and he did not object this time—I do not see why we should be arguing about it.
—Order! I took both points as debating points.

—I conclude by saying that I have just now received a note that says that the Age did not print the full letter. The last paragraph seems to have been paraphrased. I would need to look at the text of the paraphrasing to see whether it accurately represents the position. If the question is that the Melbourne Age did not print the letter in full, I am quite prepared to accept that and amend my position accordingly.

PARA.TAB: The facts are indisputable on this point. The facts are that, in substance, the Master Builders Association under its own letterhead—I have a copy of the letter and I would be pleased to incorporate it—says that the allegations being made publicly by the Housing Industry Association are not true. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is clear—and it has been clear throughout Senator Cook's answer—that his staff is aware that he misled the Senate on Monday. During his answer Senator Cook's staff presented him with what appeared to be a photocopy of the Age newspaper and a photocopy of the letter to which he was referring that went to him direct. I go back to the first question that I asked—a question which he has not answered and which I suspect he will not answer. When did he become aware that he misled the Senate? Was it when he left Question Time on Monday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not become aware that I have misled the Senate, although I accept the comments of Senator Lewis about the matter because I have some regard for him. The letter to which I was referring has the masthead of the Master Builders Association and begins, `The Editor, The Age, GPO Box 257C, Melbourne'. Then it goes on and reports the letter.
—Your staff knew about it. Why didn't you come into the Senate and tell the truth.

The whole point of this is to highlight the position of the Master Builders Association. —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins—
—And a jolly good Minister, too.

—And a jolly good Minister, too. Recent published statistics show that over the last 12 months national road fatalities have dropped to 2,055 and that on current trends they are likely to fall below 2,000 for the 1992 calendar year. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the reasons for the decrease in road trauma? How significant has the downturn in economic activity been in this reduction?

—As one who spent a large number of years picking up unfortunate victims of the roadway, particularly in the case of children, who are the victims of trauma—and there is hardly a worse way to die—I am particularly pleased to provide the Senate with this information. The number of road fatalities has continued to decline despite an overall increase in the general population, significantly higher numbers of vehicles on the road and an overall increase in the number of kilometres that are travelled.

PARA.TAB: Fatalities per 10,000 vehicles in Australia were 4.2 per cent in 1981 and by 1991 this figure had dropped to 2.1 per cent—the figure had been cut in half. Over the years, the average rate of improvement in Australia's road trauma has been better than that for both the United States and the United Kingdom. It has been suggested by some that the improvement has been largely the result of the recession. I think that my opening statement indicates that that simply cannot be sustained.

In addition, a study being finalised by the Queensland University of Technology for the Federal Office of Road Safety shows that of the 21 per cent reduction from 1989 to September 1991 only 7.7 per cent, or just over one-third of that, could have been ascribed to any reduced economic activity. The realities of the decline in road fatalities are largely the result of a combined package of government initiatives.

A number of factors are responsible for the improvement in road safety, including the mandatory wearing of seat belts. Without question the introduction of random breath testing has had a salutary effect on these figures. There have been a number of successful road safety education programs and campaigns. Furthermore, the States and the Territories have been introducing the Commonwealth's 10-point safety package, which includes a national 0.05 blood alcohol limit, and I look forward to the day when it is reduced to effectively nothing. Also we have had uniform speed limits, and a zero blood alcohol limit for young drivers—

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you a killjoy?

—A killjoy? No, I just do not like seeing people killed by drunk drivers. As I was saying, the package includes a zero blood alcohol limit for young drivers and speed limits for heavy vehicles. The 10-point safety package also provided States and Territories with a $110m package for funding the road safety black spot program. As well, the Prime Minister's One Nation statement provided an additional $70m for this same program. About 1,700 projects have been approved since this program commenced. To maintain the current downward momentum in road traumas, the Australian Transport Advisory Council in April this year endorsed the national road safety strategy. All States and Territories have agreed to participate in the strategy which forms the basis for further improving road safety performance into the next century.

PARA.TAB: Through sensible negotiation with the States and Territories, we now have a nationally coordinated road safety package. We have spent money on eradicating black spots and upgrading the national highways. I am sure all honourable senators will join with me in acknowledging the fact that it was not so many years ago that most of us in public life were despondent that the tragedy on our roads in terms of increasing numbers was simply going to continue to increase. The significant and continuing decrease in these numbers as a result of these positive programs provides encouragement to all governments, both State and Federal, to continue this positive action in improving our road safety figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Last year, the top seven ranked manufactured exports were either motor cars or their parts, aircraft parts or iron and steel products, with all these products being beneficiaries of either the motor vehicle plan, the iron and steel plan or the offset plan for aircraft parts. In other words, they had some form of assistance. The Minister has told the Senate on many occasions of the healthy state of manufactured exports. In answer to a question from Senator Maguire on 22 June, the Minister told the Senate that elaborately transformed manufactured exports were Australia's largest export earner at $10.1 billion by conveniently subdividing mining exports into suitable categories and dividing rural exports into meat, cereal, sugar and others. What is the position of manufactured exports when the subsidised motor vehicle, iron and steel, aircraft, pharmaceutical and TCF industries are taken out? Has the level of remaining manufactured exports risen or fallen in the last year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very detailed question and I would like to obtain further detail in trying to answer it. Senator Boswell referred to the seven top manufactures. Steel is the largest manufactured export item from Australia, with exports totalling something in excess of $1 billion. There was assistance for the steel industry up until 1986 but there has been no assistance for the steel industry since then.
—They export at marginal cost.

—As Senator Parer says, they export at marginal cost—of course they do. Most manufacturers do. Since 1986 there has been no special assistance for the steel industry. The motor vehicle industry is assisted by export facilitation and one can go through a number of other major manufacturers which are not in an assisted category.

PARA.TAB: The point about the elaborately transformed manufactured exports category is that the contributors to that figure of in excess of $10 billion are largely small firms across the country, many of which are not assisted in any way and some of which are assisted by the existence of a research and development incentive and things of that kind—assistance provided by generally available measures. I do not know what Senator Boswell's point is. Is it some ancient National-Country Party point from about the 1960s or is it some serious point?

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it is a serious point. Do you want me to elaborate?

—No, that is not necessary. If Senator Boswell's point is that somebody has somehow cooked the books to show that the contribution of the rural sector is not as great as it used to be, the fact of the matter is that it is as not as great as it used to be for a variety of reasons, very largely the question of access to markets.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, if the point is that the burden of manufacturing in terms of the levels of assistance supplied to it in the 1960s and 1970s is still there, the answer to that is no, it is not still there. The levels of assistance offered to manufacturing in this country are, by and large, competitive levels of assistance,

ANSWER.PARA: which are what are offered in Europe and a variety of other countries. I will certainly look at the details of the honourable senator's question in order that I might provide a more detailed answer, but I think the assumptions underlining the question are wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. There is no hidden agenda or innuendo in the question. All I ask is whether the top seven ranked manufactured exports are assisted. The Minister has come into this Parliament constantly saying that the Government's reform programs have lifted secondary industry exports. I am suggesting to the Minister that the secondary industry exports that have been lifted are the ones that have been subsidised by the Government's plans. Therefore, are the remaining manufactured exports that are not assisted down or up? It is a very simple question.

—If Senator Boswell wants to reduce his question to a simple one which would require a simple answer, let me say that the steel industry is not assisted in this country except by a tariff now that I think would average out at about 7 per cent across the product range. That is a lower level of tariff than, for example, the roughly 28 per cent that will be offered to the sugar industry in June—a much lower rate of assistance. I cannot go through all the seven largest exporters of manufactured products at the present time, but they are not all assisted. Certainly, the steel industry is not.

PARA.TAB: As to whether the other manufacturers' export performances are up or down, the performance of the manufacturing sector in exports is generally up right across the board. That is a very encouraging change, particularly as the increase in manufactured exports is not only taking place now but also took place through a period of high growth in the Australian economy during the latter part of the 1980s.
Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday, 22 June, Senator Hill asked me a question concerning Australia's foreign investment guidelines. The Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act and processes of the Foreign Investment Review Board do not apply to Australians. Senator Hill referred to annexure 2 of the guidelines, `Information Requirements: Foreign Investment Review Board'.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of the Act and the foreign investment guidelines, of which annexure 2 forms a part, is to ensure that foreign investors in Australia are appropriately screened. The purpose of the Act and the guidelines is not to screen Australian investors. Australian investors are purely incidental to the process.

In respect of the requirements or guidelines in annexure 2, the requirements that are set out there are maximum requirements. The Foreign Investment Review Board, in conducting inquiries, may ask further questions about particular matters which are responded to in the guidelines or it may—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is different from what I asked. I asked for a full explanation.
—The point of my answer is that there is no information required of Australians.
—What is your authority for saying that?
—The Foreign Investment Review Board.

PARA.TAB: I do not know what Senator Hill expected me to say about that, but I have had some inquiries made. Treasury officers have advised me that they have not been able to locate any correspondence dealing with Symons or this matter. They are making a further check before I can finalise this answer. But they have not been able to locate anything dealing with that matter at all.

REPUBLIC OF THE MARSHALL ISLANDS: ARREST OF MR GREG SYMONS
POSSIBLE QUESTION
Is it true that Senator Richardson has sought to lobby the Government of the Republic of the Marshall Islands to drop its charges against an arrested Australian. Mr Greg Symons?
TALKING POINTS
Mr Greg Symons, an Australian businessman, and Mr Paul Finch, an Australian lawyer, were arrested in Majuro, Republic of the Marshall Islands (RMI), on 2 April 1992.

Mr Finch was subsequently deported from the Marshall Islands, but Mr Symons has been charged with eleven counts of forgery relating to allegations concerning the sale of RMI passports in connection with a bogus business migration scheme.
Pending court hearings of the charges laid against him, Mr Symons has been granted bail but refused permission to leave RMI.
As an Australian citizen, Mr Symons is receiving consular assistance and has been visited by an officer from the Australian Embassy in Pohnpei, which is accredited to the RMI.
I have seen allegations reported in the press that Senator Richardson has sought to intervene with the RMI Government to drop its charges against an Australian citizen, Mr Greg Symons.
I am unaware of any contact between Senator Richardson and the RMI Government on this matter nor have the RMI authorities raised the matter with us.
RAISED
I understand that Mr Symons and Senator Richardson have known each other for many years, but I do not know the details of their relationship.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 June Senator Harradine asked the Minister representing me in my absence about an agreement between Brisbane and Beijing and the circumstances in which it was signed. I am now aware of the memorandum of understanding and friendship signed by Alderman Jim Soorley and the First Vice Mayor of Beijing, Mr Zhang Jianmin. However, my Department was not involved in preparing or facilitating the memorandum.

PARA.TAB: I do not believe that the people of Beijing or anyone else will read into the signing of that memorandum the significance which Senator Harradine has attributed to it. The Government has made clear on numerous occasions, most recently on 4 June in this chamber, its condemnation of the human rights situation in China and I believe that will be understood to be the view generally of the Australian people.

The Vice Mayor came to Australia as a result of an invitation by the Lord Mayor of Brisbane, which had been initially directed to the Mayor of Beijing, Mr Chen Xitong. The invitation was for the Mayor to attend a conference in Brisbane on 9-10 June 1992. The Brisbane City Council consulted neither my Department nor the embassy in Beijing before issuing that invitation. In the event, the conference was postponed and the First Vice Mayor, Zhang Jianmin, took up the Brisbane City Council invitation to visit. He led a Chinese commercial delegation to Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne.

My Department advises that no information has come to its attention nor to our Embassy's assigning any particular role to Mr Zhang Jianmin in the events of 4 June. I understand that Mr Zhang's responsibilities relate mainly to questions of finance, taxation, investment and relations with foreign countries.

The material that I wish to put forward today highlights clearly the fact that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has misrepresented the position of the National Farmers Federation in terms of the Housing Industry Association and the $5m fund.

PARA.TAB: I want to quote what the Minister said in his press release, and particularly to draw attention to its heading. He gets into the old, well-known trick of character assassination by referring to me as `Curvy down in the gutter', or something like that. The headline of his press release, which is quite offensive, says `NFF wasting millions of dollars of farmers' money supporting exploitation and rip-offs'.
The press release which the NFF put out in conjunction with the HIA, and which quoted Mr Farley, spoke of high principle. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: The NFF will be applying its energies and resources in tandem with the HIA because we both believe that this cause—which is really about the freedom of ordinary Australians to decide whether they want to work as independent contractors or as employees—is one of principle.

The Minister has clearly misrepresented the position of the National Farmers Federation and the Housing Industry Association's fighting fund. As the Minister well knows, the NFF put out a subsequent press release in its own name—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order.
—Come on, Robert. You are becoming like an old woman.

—I thought it was a pretty good stand down, actually. Mr President, I take no offence at all at Senator Lewis's remark because they all vote for me in the Senate election. Senator Crane has already been on his feet for two minutes speaking to a motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. He is only raising the subject matter of a subsequent debate if Standing Orders are suspended. It is his entitlement in this five minutes to indicate why the matter is urgent—why the matter should be discussed urgently now and not in the normal due processes.
—This is contrary to what you said yesterday.

—Senator Evans has prevailed on me on this issue. He talked to me about it this morning. Senator Crane is out of order. He should be brought to order and made to stress why this is an urgent matter and not just speak on the content of what he wants to say at another time.

—What a ploy by Senator Ray to use up my time. I have one minute to go. I mentioned why this matter was urgent when I rose to my feet. The reason why this matter is urgent and should be dealt with today is that it is a clear example of a Minister misrepresenting the facts. It should be dealt with at this time. I had to quote the Minister and the press release that the NFF put out to make my point in terms of urgency. Finally, I quote from the press release the NFF put out in its own name. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: The National Farmers Federation today totally rejected claims by the Minister for Industrial Relations that the NFF has given financial support to a housing industry fighting fund.

This is a matter of urgency. The Minister's press release clearly misrepresents the facts. He has the opportunity to correct that. I gave him that opportunity today. He chose instead to use gutter tactics in referring to me as `Kerbs' down in the gutter. This is a matter of urgency and I urge the chamber to support my motion in that light.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is clearly not a matter of urgency and everybody in the chamber knows it. I make the offer again that I made the other day. The only response I got was from Senator Harradine. If people want to carry on like this we ought to get on to the serious issues now and come back in July to debate matters like this. We have many more important Bills to get through. What Senator Crane is doing, and doing very well, is defending the NFF, which he has an interest in. He is entitled to have that interest. Even if what he said were true, it is not a matter of urgency that should be dealt with now. But it clearly is not true. Senator Crane may have an interpretation of a media release which he wants to talk about, but the media releases by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), and by the NFF and the HIA speak for themselves.

PARA.TAB: What the Minister is dealing with is a joint media release which stated that the HIA had announced on Wednesday that it had established a $5m fighting fund to campaign against the legislation and had resolved to take the unprecedented step of pursuing the issue up to and through the next election if necessary. The media release states:

SPEECH.PARA: The NFF Executive Director, Rick Farley, said today "The NFF will be applying its energies and resources in tandem with the HIA because we both believe that this cause—which is really about the freedom of ordinary Australians to decide whether they want to work as independent contractors or as employees—is one of principle".
That is the sort of statement which would be manna for a Minister who wants to make the point that Senator Cook did on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is, the ACTU calls the shots.

—No doubt, if the ACTU made a similar statement, people on the other side would be rising up and making a political point but at this stage of the year, and at this point of the program, we are not in a position to be taking up time making political points. It is not a matter of urgency—
—Of what relevance is the time limit?

—If Senator Crane wants to make his political points he is entitled to, but with the country in the state that it is now—and people have been protesting about unemployment—it is wrong to be raising what are very legalistic points at best; not points that are anything other than political. We ought to be getting on with our business.

PARA.TAB: I make the statement again, because if people want to come back early or if they want to wait until a little later in the month or into next month to do something about it, let us do it but, for heaven's sake, let us get on to serious points and not these peripheral points that this very clearly is. It is peripheral because, first of all, it is a very selective reading of the media releases—and I do not say that about Senator Crane in any pejorative sense—because I cannot see how he gets to his point. Secondly, even if he was correct, it is certainly not the sort of point that should lead to the suspension of the program that we are debating today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to press the subject of urgency because there is nothing more important in this place than that we do our best to ensure proper ministerial standards. The Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) has, time and time, misled the Senate; failed to take due care with his brief; usually got his brief from the Seamen's Union and usually in an inaccurate form; and come in here with all the authority of a Minister of the Crown and asserted it as a matter of fact, and we have found thereafter that it has been false.

PARA.TAB: Has this Minister had the stomach to come back in here, correct the record and apologise? On no occasion can I remember him doing so. The first occasion was the experience with Robe River, which must be almost 12 months ago. The Minister took the brief, came in here and, behind the privilege of this Parliament and the protection of this chamber, defamed Robe River because he got the facts wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Leader of the Opposition is now straying on to a question about Robe River, which is totally irrelevant to the issue that is before this chamber at the moment. He is not arguing urgency for the motion that Senator Crane has moved. I ask you to rule him out of order.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition is developing an argument and he only has five minutes to do it. I suggest that he continue.
—The point of urgency is—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Will Senator Austin Lewis withdraw his interjection because it is unparliamentary.
—I said that Senator Cook told lies about Robe River and I withdraw that. It is improper.

—Robe River is a point in issue because, time and time again, Senator Cook said that he would check the record, come back in here and put down a full statement. Has he done that? No. He said he would do it in this session. The last time that we were going to move a censure motion against him, he said, `Give me more time to examine the facts and I will bring back a full statement'.

PARA.TAB: Has he done that? Has he sought to correct the record because he knows that he has misled the Senate? He knows his defamation against Robe River was, in fact, that—defaming a company with some of the finest industrial records now in Australia, and an example to other Australian companies. He was not interested in the productivity gains in Robe River. All he was interested in was bringing Robe River down because the Seamen's Union had instructed him to do so. He misled the Senate on that occasion.

He then sought to attack Senator Panizza, without any basis at all, implying that he might have some proprietary interest in a particular company and that is why he was pursuing an issue. Senator Panizza got up and denied it. Did Senator Panizza get an apology from this Minister? Did the Minister correct the record in that instance? No, he did not again.

Then we get to the National Farmers Federation. The Minister took his brief again and got it wrong. He came in here and suggested that the NFF had taken a course of action which it had not. This has been pointed out to him today. Was he man enough to stand up and say, `I am sorry—I have therefore misled the Senate, I correct the record and I apologise'? No, he was not prepared to do that.

Then it happened again with Senator Austin Lewis's question. The Minister took the short cut. He said that he was reading from a letter in the Age. He was not reading from the letter in the Age at all. He was reading from a letter that he thought was given to the Age which he hoped had been reprinted in that newspaper. He got it wrong. But did he get up today and say, `I am sorry. I got that wrong also. I misled the Senate. I will explain to you how I misled it. It was not deliberate. I ask that the Senate recognise that this was not a deliberate act of disrespect for the Senate'. No, again he would not do that. He would not even acknowledge Senator Austin Lewis's question as to when he found out that he had in fact misled the Senate. He just left that open—he let it flow. This was put to him in a supplementary question. He had the specific opportunity to correct the record on that and he did not.

The urgency of this matter is the need to take this Minister to task for constantly misleading the Senate and for not being prepared to come in here and correct the record, put the record straight and apologise. SPEECH.PARA: MEDIA RELEASE
19 June 1992
NFF AND HIA JOIN FORCES TO OPPOSE INDEPENDENT CONTRACTOR LEGISLATION

The National Farmers Federation (NFF) today announced that it will be cooperating with the Housing Industry Association (HIA) in campaigning in the lead up to the Federal Election against the controversial independent contractor legislation passed by the Senate this week.

HIA announced on Wednesday that it had established a $5 million fighting fund to campaign against the legislation, and had taken the unprecedented step of pursuing the issue up to and through the next election, if necessary.

The NFF Executive Director, Rick Farley, said today "The NFF will be applying its energies and resources in tandem with the HIA because we both believe that this cause—which is really about the freedom of ordinary Australians to decide whether they want to work as independent contractors or as employees—is one of principle".

HIA's National Executive Director, Dr Ron Silberberg, added "The housing industry is a world class industry thanks to independent contractors, and are the reason why Australians can still aspire to home ownership.
Both HIA and the NFF oppose the independent contractor Bill which was rammed through the Senate by Senator Cook with the support of the Australian Democrats because it:

PARA.TAB: does not deal with "sham" contracts; it specifically and deliberately encompasses bona fide independent contractors;
extends way beyond any legitimate concerns to protect bona fide independent contractors who have been forced into fair or harsh contracts;
seeks to constitute independent contractors, independent business persons, as employees;
proposes that disputes of a commercial nature be referred to the AIRC for determination only in accordance with principles that are relevant to employees;
removes the right and freedom of independent business persons to compete in the marketplace without the intervention of third parties;
strikes at the very heart of the subcontractor and tendering process by introducing an unmanageable uncertainty into the tendering process;
provides a lever for increasing union involvement in the housing industry which has to date functioned extremely efficiently and harmoniously precisely because of the lack of union involvement;
to the extent that the amendments allow for union involvement in the subcontractor system there will be an enormous "blow-out" in new home costs.

SPEECH.PARA: The refusal of the Federal Government to pursue a simple and effective course of reform to address so-called "sham" contracts in preference to the proposed amendments indicates a continuing hidden agenda that is directly related to increasing union power and which ignores the costs of that hidden agenda upon the Australian public.
MINISTER FOR INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS
SENATOR PETER COOK
NFF WASTING MILLIONS OF DOLLARS OF FARMERS MONEY SUPPORTING EXPLOITATION AND RIP-OFFS
NFF financial support for the $5m HIA campaign against Government amendments to the Industrial Relations Act, must turn the stomachs of rural Australians.
While farmers struggle in the rural downturn, the NFF is committing millions of dollars of its members money to a political campaign by a discredited housing organisation—a campaign based on deceit.
Is the same NFF whose WA branch is so financially troubled that it is fighting at this very moment to save its Adelaide Terrace headquarters in Perth from the receiver?

What on earth do farmers think of this organisation which is prepared to waste millions of dollars of their money pursuing an ideological industrial relations and political agenda that is irrelevant to the lives of rural Australians.
Thousands of rural communities would cry to get their hands on some of this money so it could be used to truly improve the lives of country people.
This campaign is so politically transparent it is laughable.
The Government's legislation is not as wide as similar legislation which already exists in three states—NSW, Queensland and SA.

In NSW, this legislation has been in force for decades. Last year it was endorsed by the Greiner Government, which carried it over into its new industrial relations legislation. Why weren't the NFF and HIA protesting at Mr Greiner's door? The answer, of course, is that this campaign is political and deceitful. The facts are—
award rates will not flow to sub-contractors
sub-contractors will not be forced to join a union
contractors will not be converted to employees
unions will not have open slather in the housing industry
What the Government's proposals do is provide a means of redress to those people who work as independent contractors and who are being exploited.
Why do the NFF and HIA object so strenuously to proposals designed to protect the weaker and exploited members of the workforce?
Unfortunately, there are workers in industries such as transport, cleaning and clothing, who are under-paid and forced to work ridiculously long hours, often in atrocious conditions.
These people, including migrant women in the clothing industry working from home, are the victims of unprincipled and greedy bosses who are answerable to nobody and think they are above the law.
In NSW these shonks can be brought to account and are. Federally they cannot.
Genuine contractors and sub-contractors who work for themselves in the housing and any other industry, will not be affected by these legislative changes.

They will continue to work under the same arrangements as before. The only person who needs to be concerned is the rip-off merchant who mistreats or takes advantage of a worker for the sake of a quick profit.
The NFF involvement in the HIA's political circus is a disgrace.
The NFF should stand condemned in rural Australia for this absolute waste of its members hard-won dollars.
June 19

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. Government senators have repeatedly got up and called points of order on my colleagues who have been arguing urgency on the basis of debating the substance of this matter. The Government has denied us the right to do so. The Minister is not arguing the question of whether or not urgency should be allowed. He is arguing the substance of what we wanted to debate. He is doing what he denied us the right to do. I would ask you to rule him out of order. You should ask him to direct his remarks to why this matter is not urgent. He is making a case for it being urgent.
—Order! I will follow the lead of the President who outlined a course of action in relation to these five minute speeches. I call Senator Cook.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. What I am saying is relevant to the motion of alleged urgency. If the facts were on the record, the facts would speak for themselves and the argument about urgency would therefore be defeated by those facts. That is why it is relevant.

PARA.TAB: I want to refer to the joint media release on the letterhead of the HIA and the NFF. After the introductory paragraph, the media release says:

SPEECH.PARA: HIA announced on Wednesday that it had established a $5 million fighting fund to campaign against the legislation, and had taken the unprecedented step of pursuing the issue up to and through the next election, if necessary.
The next paragraph says:
The NFF Executive Director, Rick Farley, said today "The NFF will be applying its energies and resources in tandem with the HIA. . . .

The allegation that is made against me is that I have misled the Senate because the NFF in fact is not going to apply its energy and resources in tandem with the HIA in its $5m fighting fund. But this is what is said in black and white in the joint press release of the organisations.

PARA.TAB: It may well be that my rejoinder to the NFF, that was a waste of money of farmers who have contributed to the NFF, is uncomfortable and awkward for honourable senators opposite and perhaps for some officers of the NFF. But so what. They put out the release; they made the decision. They said that they were acting in tandem. They said that they would apply their energy and resources. If they want to engage in political debate, they can expect that people will reply to them.

I replied, but I still believe that it is a waste of the resources of the NFF. This whole campaign by the HIA is a sham. But what I am being castigated for here is that I have somehow misled those opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have. Again and again, and again and again.

—I have absolutely not—never. Not now and never before have I misled those opposite. The idea of incorporating the actual source document, the one over which there is controversy, seems to me unexceptional because it proves the point that there is no urgency and that a sham debate is being developed in order to have a go at me. Well, that is fine, honourable senators can do that, but they should do it in such a way that the facts are consistent.

PARA.TAB: The other point which seems to have incited the energies of those opposite is this question of the MBA and the Melbourne Age. I say just this: caution. Before those opposite proceed to make an allegation about what I said, they should read what I said carefully, because they will see that the insinuations of Senator Austin Lewis cannot be held to be true. The letter I referred to was the letter written to the Age, and that is clear in the Hansard. I then quoted from the letter written to the Age.

The uncomfortable and unpalatable political point is that the letter written to the Age by a reputable organisation, the MBA, does not support those opposite. If they are losing the political debate, they should not blame me, because they took this silly stand in the first place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by pointing out to Senator Faulkner, Senator Bishop and others in the chamber that we ran into difficulties over some considerable time in drawing a distinction between the matter of urgency and the substantive issue about which the matter of urgency was raised. We agreed among all parties that we would limit debate to 30 minutes and that we would not take points of order. That should be clearly understood.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, it is clear that, within the five minutes allotted and from the remarks made by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill), there has been an adequate opportunity for Opposition senators to make their points known to the chamber on this issue. Therefore, within the time constraints of that half hour, I do not think it is necessary to extend the time beyond that by granting the suspension of Standing Orders.

One thing stands out very clearly in connection with this matter: the behaviour in this chamber is occasioning some considerable concern outside. I do not believe that I am the only senator to be receiving large numbers of letters complaining about the behaviour of honourable senators. I have one in front of me to make the point, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Sir,

My wife and I watched last night's TV broadcast from Federal Parliament with great interest. We were, however, extremely disappointed in two matters. The first was your major speech. We were looking forward to a cogent analysis of policies from a man of education. Instead, we were given a rodomontade—
I confess that I am afraid I do not know what that word means—
consisting of trivialities with wasting of time by such silly remarks as your somewhat puerile reference to the PM as being upstairs having a siesta.
That is a letter sent to Dr Hewson, a copy of which was sent on to me. There is a similar one, which reads—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought they were referring to you.
—The letter sent to me was a copy of a letter sent to Dr Hewson from a constituent in New South Wales. Another letter says:

SPEECH.PARA: I have been appalled at the tactics of the coalition parties over the past few weeks. Now that Senator Richardson has been forced out, rightly or wrongly, the whole question of the Marshall Islands fiasco is a dead issue. I am enclosing a letter I have written to Mr John Howard which sets out my opinion as to why they have pursued these tactics.

The public generally must view the petty behaviour in the Senate with as much distaste as I do. I also am horrified at the bullying manner that at least one senator adopts when dealing with senior public servants.
So it goes on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does he name that person?

—No, the senator is not named. I have been receiving a large number of these letters. I do not believe that I would be the only senator to whom such letters are being sent. I simply say that I do not think the behaviour of honourable senators, particularly in Question Time today, was especially endearing to those who support us outside. I believe that a substantial improvement in the behaviour of the Senate is definitely warranted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, in the five minutes available to me, I am very pleased that Senator Coulter has received at least three pieces of correspondence. Many of us have received many more pieces of correspondence and many of them relate to the way the Democrats behave, as well as many other things. If this chamber is to get into the habit of having competitions as to who gets the better fan mail, perhaps Senator Coulter would like to take up some sort of challenge.

PARA.TAB: When Senator Coulter made the point about points of order being made during these five minute speeches, the only reason I raised a point of order concerning Senator Cook was the precedent set by the Opposition in breach of that agreement on each speaker on this side.

Very simply, this is a question of urgency. Why this matter is urgent is very simple. Senator Cook has a record of misleading this place. Every time we want to point out to the voters that Senator Cook uses language which, to put it mildly, conveys an untruth, and we attempt to use a word which has been said to be unparliamentary, he is very sensitive. He gets to his feet to say that we are not permitted to say in blunt terms that he tells untruths in the Parliament.

Today he chose to defame my colleague Senator Crane by saying that he stooped to the gutter. Perhaps Senator Cook has yet to get out of the gutter with regard to the terms he uses concerning Robe River and the way he has defamed Senator Panizza and refused again, again and again to apologise to Senator Panizza. He undertook on 19 December 1991 to come into this chamber and make a full disclosure and apology on what he had to say about Robe River, but he has yet to do that. Yet again today he is choosing to manipulate the wording, whereby he is attempting to say to the Senate that the NFF has positioned itself in a way that it has not.

Again and again this Minister stands in this chamber and warps the truth. We call him the Minister responsible for unemployment. We can also call him the Minister who is responsible for more untruths than any other Minister in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! That is unparliamentary and the honourable senator will withdraw that.
—I will withdraw whatever it is you ask me to withdraw, Mr Deputy President.
—The matter in relation to untruths.
—You mean `the Minister for untruths'? I will withdraw that.
—The honourable senator will withdraw the word `untruths'.

—I withdraw `the Minister for untruths'. Nonetheless, again and again we are placed in the difficult position of how to point out, in language which is considered to be parliamentary, that this Senate has been misled again and again by this Minister.

PARA.TAB: My colleague Senator Hill pointed out a long litany—the Robe River affair; the Senator Panizza affair; his promises to come in and get the record right; and his promises to Senator Crane that he would right the wrongs he made with regard to Robe River—yet today we have had two more instances. One might say that one is a small point. He came into this place and said he read from a letter published in a newspaper, but it was in fact not so published. Instead of saying that he thought it was published in the form in which he had a copy, he had to fudge the issue yet again. It is a small point, but it is indicative of the way he conducts his affairs all the time.

I will give honourable senators an example of the gobbledegook the Minister goes on with in his language to try to fudge issues. I will read from the Hansard of 19 December when he gave the undertaking to come clean on Robe River. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: A whole number of cases have gone through the Byzantine coils of appeal at various levels of the Industrial Relations Commission and the courts in this country. There have been different outcomes at different levels of appeal. In order to establish a factual outcome on the record based on what occurred is by no means a short matter; it is a long matter and requires clearly set out documentation.

A simple soul could work out that he got it wrong. A simple soul could work out that he has had from December 1991 until June 1992 and he still cannot comprehend the issue. He has chosen not to come into this place and set the record right. That is why it is important and urgent that we debate the record of this Minister. Quite frankly, I may or may not use language that you, Mr Deputy President, have said is unparliamentary, but to say that he does mislead this place is clearly factual.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate has been asked to suspend Standing Orders to take note of an answer Senator Cook gave to a question from Senator Crane. I can understand Senator Crane wanting to take note of anything Senator Cook says. Senator Cook is indeed one of the shining stars of the Australian Labor Party and of the front bench of the Government. I commend Senator Crane for his honesty in recognising the need to take note of Senator Cook's answer.

PARA.TAB: As to the matter of substance of whether the matter is urgent or not, quite clearly it is not urgent. Senator Cook indicated in his explanation of the point earlier this afternoon that, if in the answer to the question it had been misconstrued that he was talking about a letter to the Age rather than a letter that was redirected to him, he was quite happy to correct that matter and the Hansard will show that to be a fact.

The other matter of substance is whether the National Farmers Federation is operating conjointly with the Housing Industry Association in a campaign against the industrial relations legislation. It is clear from the evidence produced here this afternoon that the National Farmers Federation, the NFF, is part of that campaign. It has publicly claimed that it is part of the campaign by virtue of its press release. Indeed, from its perspective on industrial relations, it is clear that it is proud to be part of that campaign. As an organisation operating within Australia, it has every right in the world to be part of that campaign.

So when Senator Peter Cook stands up in this place and claims that money from the National Farmers Federation is being used in a campaign in conjunction with the campaign sponsored by the Housing Industry Association against the industrial relations legislation, he is absolutely correct. He is agreeing with the National Farmers Federation.

I do not know whether political points are to be scored by Senator Crane, a former official of the National Farmers Federation, on behalf of the National Farmers Federation in bringing this matter here this afternoon and claiming that it is urgent, but if there are he has scored them. So I congratulate him on the second point. The first point I congratulate Senator Crane on is his recognition of the talent of Senator Cook. As I said, he is a shining star on Labor's front bench, a shining star in the Keating Government.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The time for the debate has expired.

Senator Lewis—I seek leave to move a motion that the Senate take note of Senator Cook's answer to my question in Question Time.
