SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the contingent notice of motion standing in Senator Hill's name, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to a motion to take note of an answer to a question without notice.

SPEECH.PARA: I intend to speak to the motion for suspension of Standing Orders to enable me to speak to this matter. I hope that Senator McMullan remains in the chamber because some of the things that I have to say I hope to address to him. But I also wish to address some of the things to the Australian Democrats and, in particular, Senator Coulter.

PARA.TAB: I am speaking to the reason why the Senate should suspend Standing Orders. I say to Senator Coulter that, because he and the other Democrats will not support this motion, the Senate has got itself into the situation where instead of debating the motion—that is, that Standing Orders be suspended—we end up finding a way around that so that for 30 minutes we debate in effect the issue that we were seeking leave to talk about. I say to Senator Coulter, with all due respect, that it is because he will not support this suspension of Standing Orders that the Government believes that it is going to end up getting away with this procedure.

I direct these remarks to Senator McMullan, who I hope will listen to me. In the last debate Senator Crane raised a particular matter. I believe that Senator Crane would probably have been the only person on our side of the chamber who would have addressed that matter. I bet he would not have taken advantage of more than about five or six minutes to talk to it. The Government would then have had five or six minutes in which one of its senators could have got up and responded, or Senator Cook could have got up and responded if he wished, and the Democrats could have spoken. The whole debate might have taken 10 minutes, 15 minutes or 20 minutes at the most.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't happen like that.

—With all due respect to Senator Kernot, it was happening like that. That is exactly what was happening until the Government decided that it was not going to grant leave. The moment the Government decided that it was not going to grant leave, we moved the procedural motion, and we will continue to move the procedural motion. We will use the Standing Orders to exercise our rights, notwithstanding the support which the Democrats continually give to the Government on these matters—
—On the gag, too.

—And on the gag, too, as my colleague says. I say to Senator McMullan that Senator Crane and maybe one other senator on our side would have spoken, but the Government has forced this debate which will now go on for one hour. Of course, we are able to use words to explain why we are debating properly the subject of the motion—that is, that Standing Orders be suspended—because we are professional politicians. Does the Government think that we are not capable of taking advantage of the Standing Orders to make sure that the points we wish to make will be made? If those opposite would only try to cooperate, we might be able to get somewhere.
—Ha, ha!

—Senator McMullan giggles, but let me talk about cooperation. Has Senator McMullan ever heard such rubbish as that which we are continually being given in Ministers' answers to questions? Senator McMullan knows that Ministers, when giving answers to questions, are on that idiot box—the television. Regardless of the question asked, the Government is continually campaigning for the next election against the Fightback package. If Ministers continue to misuse Senate Question Time along those lines, then our people will have no alternative but to use the procedures of the Senate to respond to the misuse of Question Time by frontbenchers—Government Ministers.

PARA.TAB: If the Democrats would please address the question I raise, they would recognise that the Opposition is entitled to respond to these political answers given by Ministers. For the reasons I have outlined, the Senate should agree to this suspension of Standing Orders. We can then debate the misleading of the Senate by Senator Cook in his answer to Senator Aulich on Monday and the Minister's failure today even to respond to the question which I put to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose this motion to suspend Standing Orders.
—That's a surprise.

—Senator Macdonald may be surprised because he is too dim to think reasonably or rationally about any issue. This is just another stunt by that rump of the Liberal Party whose leadership is out of control in this chamber. Robert Hill is just a stooge up front who has no control over the Liberal Party in the Party room. Until today I always gave Senator Lewis credit for the fact that he was not part of the mad rump, the dingbats in the Liberal Party, such as Senator Bishop, Senator Walters, and Senator Macdonald. Senator Lewis was a frontbencher at one stage and he has gone to the back bench in anticipation of retirement. I am surprised that he got up and made such a stupid speech and has been wasting the Senate's time, when we have a number of important Bills to deal with.

PARA.TAB: The Broadcasting Services Bill which is before us today is the first major rewrite of the Broadcasting Act in Australia since the 1940s—the first in 50 years—and Senator Lewis wants to debate for another hour the Minister's answer; he wants to argue over a few words. It has now been an hour since the end of Question Time. The Minister has given his answer. Senator Lewis may not like it but the answer has been given. We may not like Senator Lewis's comments. We have spent nearly one hour debating an absolutely trivial matter; it is a semantic debate which 99.9 per cent of Australians could not give a darn about. Senator Crane has a particular view that he has to show his mates in the National Farmers Federation that he is earning his keep here as a professional politician, to show that he is always supporting the Federation. He has made his hairy-chested remarks; he has beaten his chest for an hour. Let us now get on with the real business of the Senate; let us deal with some legislation. I repeat that the Bill before us is very important—the first rewrite of the Broadcasting Act since that legislation was introduced 50 years ago.

I am astonished that Senator Lewis says that we are professional politicians and we have the right to speak. Of course we are professional politicians—we are paid by the Australian taxpayer. I have known only a couple of people who could be described as amateur politicians. The old mate of those opposite, Mr Fraser, had enough money stashed away down in the western districts of Victoria so that he could be an amateur politician; he could sit here day in and day out without being paid. I could not do so, and I know that all members on this side of the chamber could not be here if they were not paid. I suspect most Democrats could not be here unpaid either. Even a large number of Liberals would have to be paid as professional politicians. So Senator Lewis should not give us this tripe that because he is a professional politician he has the right to talk about this matter because he thinks it is something important. Senator Lewis demeans the profession of politics when he and others front up with this sort of tripe as a stunt.

I heard Senator Coulter read out a couple of letters. I thought it was hilarious. He did not actually name the senator, but we all know who it is. She jumps up every Question Time with 15 points of order, or something in that range, because she knows she is on television. Of course, she self-identified herself. Senator Bishop jumped up immediately and said basically, `It's not me'. We all know that is her stunt, that what she wants to do is go around the Liberal branches of New South Wales saying, `Did you see me in Question Time jumping up on points of order, getting stuck into the Government no matter what?' That is all the stunt is about. That is why it is on the idiot box, as Senator Lewis calls it, so that the biggest idiot of all, Senator Bronwyn Bishop—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Order! It is not parliamentary to call another senator an idiot. I ask you to withdraw that remark, Senator Schacht.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw. Senator Bishop is a stunt merchant of the first order. She is not interested in decent debate in this place on any issue of substance. All she is interested in is establishing a reputation that she is tougher than anybody else in asking a question and in disrupting the procedures of the Senate. In the way Senator Bishop carries on, she is doing more to ruin the reputation of professional politicians, as Senator Lewis would call them, than anybody else in this place or in the other place. She has surpassed even Senator Walters and a few others in the rat pack of the Liberal Party over there on the other side of the chamber who are out of control.

PARA.TAB: I think it is about time the Liberal leadership in this chamber told that rump of the back bench in the Liberal Party in the Senate room to pull their heads in and let us get on with some decent legislation and some decent debate about policy. I oppose the suspension of Standing Orders so that we can get on with dealing with decent legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are used to the tirade from Senator Schacht, but let me tell him that I have been insulted by experts and he is far from expert. We are suggesting that Standing Orders should be suspended so that we can deal with a very important matter—the misleading of the Senate by Senator Cook. I do not think there can be a more important matter than the misleading of the Parliament by a Minister. It is for that reason that I believe this is a very urgent matter that should be dealt with straightaway.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter has come in here reading his fan mail, telling us that people are concerned about the behaviour in this place. I think people are extremely concerned about the behaviour of politicians. The ministerial group on the Government benches never hesitates to mislead the Parliament. Let us have a look at what has happened since they have been in government. There have been Murphy, Mr Young, Senator Richardson and the Premier in Western Australia, Mr Burke. All these people have misled people and have behaved in such a manner that the Australian community is fed up and very concerned about the corruption in the Government. It is terribly important that the matter before us at the moment should be debated—
Honourable senators interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Order! There are too many interjections. I ask Senator Walters to continue with her speech; she has just two minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The trouble we have on this side of the chamber is that Senator Cook has been censured more than any other politician in the Senate. He has been censured in this Senate and I believe—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. On a matter of accuracy, I think Senator Walsh has been censured by the Senate more than Senator Cook, and Senator Walsh regards it as a badge of courage.
—That is a debating point; it is not a point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Cook is completely incapable of admitting that he has ever done anything wrong. When he has very clearly misled the Senate he has never come into this place and apologised.
—Do you ever admit you're wrong?
—Senator Schacht always opens his big mouth and interjects.
—Have you ever done anything wrong in your life, Shirley?

—Let me tell Senator Schacht that, on one occasion, I accused Senator Crowley of not having shown any great concern in this Senate about domestic violence. I went out and looked at the Hansard, admittedly quite some time ago, and found she had indeed spoken in this Senate on domestic violence. So I came in and apologised to Senator Crowley that I had missed one of her speeches that was reported in the Hansard. So my answer to you, Senator Schacht, is yes.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order in two parts: firstly, not one of these comments by Senator Walters has been directed through the Chair; secondly, I take the point on the question of relevance. Really, who cares about this issue of Senator Crowley and Senator Schacht? I do not think anyone in the chamber can follow a word of what Senator Walters is saying. But it is drawing an extraordinarily long bow on this motion for a suspension of Standing Orders to be debating an issue about Senator Crowley and Senator Schacht. I ask you, Madam Acting Deputy President, to call Senator Walters to order and to ask her to address the motion before the Senate.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator whatever-his-name-is, the last speaker—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Senator Faulkner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner—thank you—has already been told once this afternoon that those sorts of interjections and points of order are disorderly. Madam Acting Deputy President, I ask that you bring Senator Faulkner into line again and take some action if he is going to continue making disorderly points of order.
—I move that so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Walters having an extension of time.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Order! Senator Baume, I am advised that you cannot do that when we have a motion to suspend Standing Orders already before the Chair. Before I give the call, I would like to say that I have only just come into the chamber so I do not know what has gone on before. However, I remind honourable senators again to address their remarks through the Chair and to make their remarks relevant to the matter being debated, which I understand is a motion to suspend the Standing Orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I rise more in sorrow than in anger about this, but it seems the Opposition does think that offence is the best way of defence. The Opposition has a hang-up about industrial relations, it is ideologically disposed in this area and, as a consequence, I come in for my fair share of bucketing. All I can say is: fine, I do not mind that. I repeat: at least while those opposite are attacking me they are leaving some other person alone—so be my guest.

PARA.TAB: Of course this is not an urgent matter. To establish that beyond any reasonable doubt, I seek leave of the Senate to have incorporated in Hansard a letter to the Melbourne Age by the executive director of the Master Builders Association, Mr John Murray, along with an excerpt from the letters column of the Melbourne Age of 22 June, which is a report of the letter by Mr John Murray. If I have leave to do that, at least the source documents over which this debate is occurring are on the public record.

I would think the source documents speak more eloquently than any other senator in this debate—and certainly more eloquently than I. In doing so, they make it clear that the allegation being propounded as a matter of urgency is in fact wrong. I am happy to rely on those documents and what appears on page 4,143 of the Senate Hansard of 22 June, in the penultimate paragraph on the inside column. All of those three documents or references are the material questions here—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook, before you proceed, you are seeking leave to incorporate. Is leave granted?
—I ask the Minister whether, at the same time, to be fair to all concerned, he would also have incorporated the National Farmers Federation press release in relation to the same matter.

—I am being asked whether I will be fair. I will always be fair, but I do not know what that document is. Perhaps one of the other speakers opposite can seek leave to have that document incorporated, and in the due way that can be done.
—Is leave granted to incorporate the documents?
—Madam Acting Deputy President, we have not agreed to that as yet.
—Senator Alston just agreed.

—I have not agreed, and it takes only one senator to say no. Has Senator Cook shown our shadow Minister what he wishes to incorporate? That is the usual courtesy. We are always asked to do that. Indeed, Senator Lewis has already asked Senator Tate's permission to incorporate the article he wanted to incorporate. I request that Senator Cook show us what he wants to incorporate.

—I pass over the documents to which I have referred to Senator Alston, if the Clerk will take those, and those opposite will see I have accurately described what those documents are. My reason for wanting them incorporated is that I think this debate would be mightily informed if the source documents were on the record so that the dimensions of this claim can be clear.

PARA.TAB: I accepted what Senator Lewis told me in Question Time, as I indicated in my answer in Question Time. When I now read the Senate Hansard, I see that I was ill advised to so straightforwardly accept the allegations of what I said from Senator Lewis. What I said, in fact, is in that paragraph I referred to a moment ago. I quote it now:

SPEECH.PARA: In the Melbourne Age today, a letter from Mr John Murray, the Executive Director of the Master Builders Association, was published which makes that point very explicitly.
The fact that a letter was published in the Melbourne Age from that gentleman is true and a fact, and one of the documents I am having incorporated establishes that. Then I went on to say:
I conclude my answer by quoting from the letter by John Murray.

I then proceeded to quote, and the quotes in the Hansard are from John Murray's letter. That will now be in the record because that is the letter that I am having incorporated—from John Murray, the Executive Director of the Master Builders Association.

PARA.TAB: The allegation against me—God help me—is that the letter that I quoted from did not appear in the Melbourne Age. What appeared in the Melbourne Age was an edited version of the letter, but what I said I was quoting from was not the Melbourne Age, but `the letter by John Murray'. The Hansard makes it quite clear:

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude my answer by quoting from the letter by John Murray.

I then proceeded to quote from that letter. What seems to be the problem here is that those opposite find politically inconvenient the things I said when I quoted. They find that politically inconvenient. Bad luck. It is inconvenient because it demolishes their case.

The Editor

Dear Sir

In the Age of Friday, 19 June, an article by Ms Karen Middleton states that "The HIA and the Master Builders'—Construction and Housing Association have set up a $5 million trust fund to pay for a television advertising campaign against [independent contractor legislation].

This is completely untrue. Master Builders, together with other like minded employer organisations was successful in persuading the Federal Government to remove most objectionable provision from this Bill. The Bill now retains only a limited provision allowing the Industrial Relations Commission to review individual harsh and unconscionable contracts at the request of the contractor involved—a provision similar to, but narrower than those which already exist in NSW, SA and Queensland industrial legislation, and which have been operating for some years without any ill effects.

John Murray
Executive Director.

PARA.TAB: I support Senator Lewis in terms of this matter being urgent. We have just heard from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) an incredible attempt to justify a position that he adopted. Anybody of reasonable intelligence reading from the documents which the Minister just quoted to us could only come to the conclusion that in fact the Minister was quoting, when he answered this question—which I believe he thought he was—from the letter which was published in the Age. That is the only conclusion any intelligent person could come to.

This is a matter of urgency because Senator Lewis asked the Minister, Senator Cook, a very simple question today. That simple question was: when did you become aware of the fact that the letter that was printed in the Age was not the same as the one that had been sent to the Minister by John Murray from the Master Builders Association? The Minister refused to answer that question and he still refuses to answer.

This debate has been turned into a charade, because if the Minister had answered, Senator Lewis would have got up, made his comments in a very short period and addressed the subject matter before us, instead of us going on for half an hour justifying why this is a matter of urgency.In the previous debate when I wanted to take note of an answer given during Question Time, I wanted to incorporate three documents. It would have taken me two minutes. I have now incorporated them, so it will save me doing it in the adjournment debate tonight.

We continually have answers put before us, particularly from the Minister for Industrial Relations, that do not represent the facts accurately. They are a distortion of the facts. That is why this is a matter of urgency and that is why we on this side of the chamber wish to put the substantive side of the matter on the public record to correct the misrepresentation that we have consistently had before us in this place.

I can run through a number of them that I have been involved in. Robe River is a classic. I will not go through that again now, other than to say that at about this time in the last Parliament, when the Minister was forced by our action to table some documents, he made a commitment—it is clear in Hansard—that he would return to this chamber because he needed a full half hour in the adjournment debate to put his particular case down. He has not done so.I can also refer to what happened previously with the National Farmers Federation. I am not going to be drawn by the nonsense that Senator Schacht carried on with with regard to my previous position in the Farmers Federation. I do not care whether it is the Farmers Federation or anybody else—I just do not care; but if it is a case of the Minister misrepresenting its position, I do care.

This is a matter of urgency. Quite clearly, the Minister refused to answer the substance of the question asked by Senator Lewis today. Therefore, it should be debated in this place as it is a matter of urgency. It is about time that this Minister was forced to reply to the questions asked of him, in the proper manner in which Question Time is meant to be used.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think any of us have a real objection to taking note of answers. I think even the Government has been beaten by a war of attrition on this. I would like to ask the Opposition why we cannot agree on a time limit. Yesterday, while waiting to debate the superannuation Bills, we had about two hours of taking note of answers. Nobody on the Opposition side today has said, `I seek leave to take note of the answer and, in view of the legislative program, I would like to confine my remarks to half an hour'.

PARA.TAB: Senator Austin Lewis asserted that he would take only six minutes, the Minister would take only six minutes and we should all be terribly reasonable and know this would happen. The problem is that it never happens unless we agree to a time limit beforehand. It is extremely childish of a senator to say, `I'm a professional politician. If I can't get my way this way, then of course I'm going to twist the rules and take advantage of Standing Orders to get my way another way'.

Why can we not just be a bit civilised about this? Nobody is denying the right to debate. Why can we not stop trying to hijack the legislative program and get on with business? This is not as urgent as the Opposition believes it is. I believe that the number one priority of this chamber today is for us to get on to the broadcasting legislation and then on to the second Government response to Aboriginal deaths in custody. We have not even had an opportunity to debate the first response.Nobody wants to stop members of the Opposition from taking note of Minister's answers, but could they please exert a little discipline and confine themselves to a time frame?

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur with the remarks made by Senator Kernot on this motion. It seems to me that the best example of the problem we face at the moment is the motion moved by Senator Parer to take note of answers given during yesterday's Question Time. Debate on that motion went for two hours and two minutes. At least debate on this motion for the suspension of the Standing Orders has only gone for half an hour. The real point is that at times there are obviously issues that are substantive and substantial, and that deserve the time of the Senate and one or two hours of debate. There are other issues that can only be regarded and described as trivial, and they get the same response from the Opposition whenever they are proposed. So a trivial matter might lead to one hour or two hours of debate before the chamber, which is a sheer waste of time.

PARA.TAB: At the moment the Government is being flexible. This is the Government that extended the time for debate on the superannuation package by half an hour. We have also agreed to extend the time for debate on the Territories Law Reform Bill by another half an hour. The Government is being reasonable and flexible on these issues of management of the chamber. Unfortunately, what Senator Lewis and Senator Crane said about the one or two minutes they would speak for in the chamber on a motion to take note of answers has no basis in fact or experience. On every occasion that the Government has granted leave, the leave has been abused.

SPEECH.PARA: The pace of technological change is ever-accelerating. Who knows? It could be anything from euthanasia to dramatic forms in bio-technology. . .

In making that reference to euthanasia, I was responding to an interjection which specifically put forward that very proposition and which I was then at pains to point out was an abhorrent notion to our side of politics. SPEECH.PARA: This annual report, which at times is wrongly labelled as the 1990 report, is in fact the report for 1991. I stress that the major changes taking place in the structure of this Institute, particularly the way it affects the Canberra School of Music, are matters that I want to talk about as shadow Minister for the arts. I note that in the report the Director of the Canberra School of Music says:
It is pleasing to note that this evolutionary process has taken place in the university environment—
that is, becoming a part of the Australian National University on 1 January this year—
without the need to compromise in any way the original charter of the School to develop as a performance school at the international level.

It is absolutely vital that coming into a much more academic environment does not diminish in any way the performance elements of this school which have, in fact, resulted in a very large number of its graduates being regarded within the arts as of extraordinarily high quality. Dealing with this year, the report states:

Undergraduate students have won major prizes in competitions across Australia and have represented the School with credit as professional members of the country's major symphony orchestras. A student wind quintet was selected to represent Jeunesse Musicale (World Youth Orchestra) in Montreal, Canada, while 1991 graduates have won scholarships for study in the leading schools in USA, Austria, United Kingdom, Japan and Germany.
The report also says:
The busy public concert schedule was maintained during the year with the presentation of 348 concerts, recitals and broadcasts.

However, in the midst of this, I would like to draw attention to the happy link that has existed in the past between the school and the Canberra City Opera. I hope that there is no truth in suggestions of some reduction in this association which has been built up so magnificently over the years by Mr David Parker, who is the head of the Voice Department, and Marie van Hove, while both of them have been that department. By establishing this link, these people have been able to give performance opportunities to students and graduates of the school which I believe is invaluable to them. The report notes:
In 1991, the Canberra City Opera rehearsed each week at the School of Music under the direction of the Head of the Voice Department, David Parker.
I hope that continues. The report continues:

In July, the School of Music joined the Canberra City Opera in presenting the world premiere of the specially commissioned opera, A Summer Carol, by Colin Brumby to a libretto by Thomas Shapcott. The producer was David Parker and conductor Marie van Hove. The production featured students Christina Wilson, John Brunato, Lotte Latukefu and John Handley with the School of Music Symphony Orchestra. Other vocal students joined members of the Canberra City Opera to form the chorus. This was the final production before the retirement from the School of Music of David Parker and Marie van Hove. The work has since been broadcast on ABC FM.

I regret the fact that there is nothing else in this report which pays tribute to the outstanding work of David Parker and Marie van Hove, both of whom, frankly, did not wish to retire, but were required to retire by achievement of an age limit which, I thought, merited being ignored. This was particularly so as at least the temporary replacement of Mr David Parker, the outstanding expatriate singer John Cameron, is well over Mr Parker's age. This outstanding contribution should have merited some comment in this annual report. I imagine that my colleague Senator Michael Tate would also endorse the outstanding achievements by Mr Parker and his wife, Marie van Hove, in their time at the Canberra City Opera and at the School of Music.

PARA.TAB: I mention in passing that I was also glad to note that the list of visitors to the Australian Centre for the Arts during 1991 included Miss Mardi McSullea, a flautist from Melbourne, who worked with David Worrall on a new compact disc to be released as part of the anthology of Australian music on disc for 1992. I welcome that disc. I congratulate Mardi McSullea on her achievements and for what she is doing for this anthology, which I look forward to hearing in the near future.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, on behalf of the President, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Audit Report No. 47 of 1991-92, Efficiency Audit—Energy Management of Commonwealth Buildings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I again congratulate the Auditor-General, who has a wonderful record on these sorts of audits and, particularly, the efficiency audits which he does on various aspects of Government. Report No. 47, Efficiency Audit—Energy Management of Commonwealth Buildings, is no exception. The Auditor-General points out that the total cost of energy used in Commonwealth occupied buildings—and I congratulate him on even coming up with a figure on this—is $258m per annum. He claims that, with some investment in efficiency management improvements, there is the potential for saving between $29m and $46m per year. Those figures are very significant.

PARA.TAB: If those opportunities are available, and the Government departments via their Ministers are not doing something about it, they are being remiss in that they are yet again wasting taxpayers' money. Of course, part of the proposal of Fightback! is to look at all these inefficiencies and wastages that go on and correct them. The Hewson coalition has taken the view that if we can see opportunities for saving other people's money—when I say `other people's money', I mean money contributed by the taxpayers of Australia—and the government of the day does not go to great lengths to minimise those costs, then it is remiss and corrupt in its handling of other people's money.

I find it fascinating that we did not see the Australian Democrats contribute anything on an issue as important as the saving of energy. They come in here and waffle on about other things that they think might gain them the support of their tiny constituency in this country, but they do not even bother to come into this chamber and talk about something as important as this.

What comes through in the report is that the amelioration of the environmental problems that exist in our country—they are not really as bad as a lot of the extremists would lead us to believe, but certainly the saving of energy is a very important one—can be achieved through market forces: by the necessity of the market, by the shortage of money and by budget constraints.

One of the people who has proposed this for some years now is Alan Moran. Alan Moran was best known as a person appointed by the Hawke Government to the Business Regulation Review Unit, where he did an absolutely magnificent job advising the Government—sometimes in a confidential way but sometimes publicly, whatever his brief was—on the effects of Government legislation on the business sector and the costs that would be incurred by legislation if it were enacted.

The Business Regulation Review Unit was shut down because, I think, it was some sort of embarrassment to the Government, and Alan Moran went to the Industry Commission, where he did excellent work for some time. He subsequently ended up in the Tasman Institute. He was the one who propounded the theory that if we were to correct the major environmental problems in the world—I am not referring to problems within Australia today—it would be by market forces. This caused great trauma for a lot of extremists in the greenie movement who relied on promoting or exaggerating environmental problems for their own existence.

The then Minister for the Environment and the Arts, Senator Richardson, got up in this place and maligned in a way that I have not seen for some time Mr Alan Moran, who is one of the great thinkers in Australia. Mr Moran is absolutely correct when he says that there is no doubt that in the next 10 years or so the problems that we strike in regard to the environment will be corrected by market forces. Anyone who wants to see that in action would be well advised to go to Japan. Market pressures have caused the Japanese to look at energy usage. Anyone who goes to Japan will find that the Japanese have even regulated energy usage in buildings during the winter time and the summer. They have done this mainly because of cost savings. I would say that that is the way to go.

This is quite the opposite to what our friends the Australian Democrats would do. They take the view that if we are to do something about energy use we should start to increase the price of electricity until we reach the stage where people stop using it. This is exactly the wrong way to go and it will not work. The Democrats are talking about doubling or tripling the carbon tax. They live in their own little world. They are called by people on the other side of this chamber fairies in the bottom of the garden. I prefer to see them as little pixies who have no understanding of the real world.

But, more importantly, we should remember that the Democrats will never ever be in the position of governing this country. As a result, they can afford to be extravagant. I think they are an absolute anachronism. When we were dealing with the suspension of standing orders today they spoke as if they controlled this parliament. The fact that people who receive 6 or 7 per cent of the vote can come in here and determine what this Government or a coalition government, when it gets into office, will do and what legislation will be passed is an absolute abomination. For those out in society who look at the luxury—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you support changing the voting system so that parties with 6 or 7 per cent of the vote do not get elected?

—It is my belief that we cannot have a situation in which people who receive 6 or 7 per cent of the vote control the Parliament. This sort of thing will wreck democracy as we know it.I was about to say that people who have the luxury of acting in this way do not realise the implications of going down that track.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that there are ways in which government departments can make massive energy savings. The Auditor-General, to his credit, has identified savings of the order of $29m to $46m a year. This Government should give priority to looking at where those savings can be made and to making them.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

—On behalf of the President, in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901 I present the following report of the Auditor General: Report No. 49 of 1991-1992—Efficiency Audit—Department of Administrative Services—Management of Sydney Central construction project.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Like my colleague Senator Parer, I too congratulate the Auditor-General on drawing to the attention of the Parliament what seems to me to be an absolute disgrace—in this instance, the management of the Sydney Central construction project. As a member of the Public Works Committee, I am very alarmed at the laissez faire attitude that seems to be taken by some government departments towards building construction projects.

PARA.TAB: The Auditor-General's report before the Senate today is but a further example that some government departments are not approaching complex tasks with the professional standards which we as a parliament should require. It should be of no comfort to honourable senators on either side of this chamber that the Auditor-General has concluded his report with 45 recommendations. There have been two reports and 45 recommendations just in relation to the letting of a tender and the construction of one building—the Sydney Central construction project. It is even more alarming that the Australian Construction Service seems to have agreed with virtually every one of these recommendations.

I cannot help but ask myself why these problems could not have been identified by the Australian Construction Service. One would have to ask why the Minister, Senator Bolkus, has not reported to the Parliament on the concerns that have been raised by not only the Auditor-General but during the hearings of the royal commission that looked at this building last year.

The Auditor-General has concluded that because the Commonwealth Government's risks were not properly documented in the construction contract and because the project was not managed effectively, this resulted in indirect holding costs and a direct cost to the Commonwealth of the order of $12m. When I say that it is a direct cost to the Commonwealth, I mean, of course, that it is a direct cost to the taxpayer. As chairman of the coalition waste watch committee, I can tell honourable senators that $12m would go a long way to helping a few of our unemployed people.

Essentially, what occurred was that the Department of Administrative Services, through the Australian Construction Service, set about a major construction project without securing the necessary tenancies to make the project viable. This is pointed out in one of the key findings of the report. The Auditor-General stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal to build Sydney Central should have been based on firm commitments from departments to occupy space in it. When the construction contract was awarded in 1989 there were no tenancy commitments for the building, and DAS has continued to have difficulty in securing departmental tenants to fill the building.

This afternoon I took the opportunity of ringing Mr Richard Williams of Australian Estate Management. He was very cooperative. He informed me that since this report has been written, most of the building has been let to government departments. The major tenant, of course, is the Australian Customs Service. Also DEET, the Department of Industrial Relations, AIDAB and Australian Archives will be moving in. It is gratifying to know Australian Estate Management has been able to fill up the building. It is also pleasing to note that nearly 50 per cent of the retail space has been filled, even though the departments have not yet moved in.

PARA.TAB: As a direct result of the inadequacies of the Australian Construction Service, there were problems with fitout as the building was continually re-designed to meet the needs of new prospective tenants. Ultimately, as I said earlier, it is the taxpayer who has to foot the bill to the tune of something like $12m.

At the time construction was commenced it was assumed that the Australian Tax Office would be a major tenant. But when officers of the Tax Office appeared before the Public Works Committee we were advised that this probably would not be the case. Nevertheless, other government tenants have been found. But as the Auditor-General points out, the fitouts had to be altered to fit in with these tenants, and as a result it has cost the taxpayer an extra $12m.

Another great concern to me is the fact that directions given by this Parliament have been flouted. DAS was required to keep the Public Works Committee informed of the actual cost of restoration of heritage elements retained, the progress of fitout requirements and cost of the project. The Audit Office has raised the point—and I would have to concur; I have checked this with the Secretary of the Public Works Committee—that the Public Works Committee has not been informed of any progress in regard to the fitout cost requirements. I am sure that the Chairman of the Committee, Mr Hollis, would be absolutely appalled at this whole shemozzle.

It is interesting to see some of the problems that arose during this tendering process. The Auditor's report states, for instance, that Australian Construction Services decided in 1987 to engage a consultant quantity surveyor. In the report, the Auditor-General points out that the consultant was originally employed at an initial fee of $5,600. This increased to $821,225 over the course of the project.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?
—It is $821,225. The reason I am concerned about that is that no expressions of interest were sought from any other consultants; in fact, the tender process was completely ignored.
—What consultancy is this? We can all go and join it.

—Yes. The Auditor-General points out that the procedures used by Australian Construction Services in appointing a consultant did not ensure that the expenditure gave the best value to the Commonwealth—in other words, the taxpayer—as expressions of interest were not sought from other consultants. A rise from $5,600 to $820,000-odd is quite a significant increase.

PARA.TAB: As if that were not enough, the same situation arose with the engagement of a consultant programmer. According to the Auditor-General's report, he was engaged on a time basis to an upper limit of $36,800. The contract was then extended by $45,000. By the end of February 1989, it had been extended by a further $400,000. This again occurred without any competitive quotes from other consultants. So, under these circumstances, one would really have to ask whether Australian Construction Services and the Department of Administrative Services is doing the right thing by the taxpayer. I am also very concerned at the Royal Commission into Productivity in the Building Industry in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that consultancy would be described better as a nice little earner.

—Yes. To return to the Royal Commission, its inquiry into productivity in the building industry in New South Wales obtained evidence that there were secret agreements between the tenderers for this project to build the Sydney Central building. In 1991, the Royal Commission obtained evidence that the successful tenderer—who is not named in this report by the way; I have read through it in the short time I have had it and I cannot find his name—effectively paid off unsuccessful tenderers to the tune of $750,000 each and a further fee of $1m was passed on to the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors. So payments totalling $3.25m were included in the tender price for Sydney Central but were apparently unknown to Australian Construction Services. I understand that this aspect of the project has been referred to the Australian Government Solicitor with the idea of trying to recover those moneys. It makes one wonder just how efficient this Department is when it was not even aware that those monies paid were kickbacks.

PARA.TAB: Another area that concerns me—it is not in the Auditor-General's report—is the attempt to fill this building with firstly Australian Construction Services and now Australian Estate Management. Further, the major tenant which will move into this building in about a month, the Australian Customs Service, already has a lease on a property at 117 Clarence Street, Sydney. This lease does not cease until 14 September 1995.

I was handed an advertisement last week which appeared in the Australian Financial Review announcing `a unique sublease opportunity'. This should be totally unacceptable to this Parliament. The advertisement reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Premises are available from August 1992 to 14/9/95 at a sacrifice rent—just name rental you are prepared to pay—plus generous incentives.

In other words, because we had this embarrassing situation where we have a huge building that cost almost $200m and it had no tenants, the Australian Customs Service has been rushed into it. On top of the $12m that the Auditor-General has identified and the $3.25m in kickbacks that have been paid to buy off the other tenderers, the rent forgone will be paid to the owners of 117 Clarence Street, Sydney for the next three years. Somebody will certainly get some very cheap rent there.

PARA.TAB: I feel we should all take note of this matter upon which the Auditor-General has reported. It is a matter that is of great concern to me as a member of the Joint Committee on Public Works. I am sure that we will be hearing more about it. As Senator Parer said, it is very good to see that the Auditor-General is doing such a wonderful job in identifying to the Parliament the absolute rorts in our system that the Government should be bringing to our attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak briefly to the Auditor-General's Audit Report No. 49, Management of Sydney Central construction project, to support the remarks of my colleague Senator Calvert. As pointed out by Senator Calvert, this is really a damning report by the Auditor-General of an organisation that is one of the stars of Senator Bolkus's commercialised operations. Australian Construction Services has been commercialised. It now comes under a type 2 trust account, and it has proper profit and loss accounts, balance sheets and so on. That is a direction that the Opposition supported. The Auditor-General's report, which talks about the changed environment with the organisation becoming commercialised, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Given the new environment in which it now operates—
that is, Australian Construction Services, and I presume from this that this is the project services part of ACS—
ACS needs to adopt a more commercial approach to the provision of its design and construction supervision services.

That is a fairly damning remark from the Auditor-General. I find it absolutely amazing that the Australian National Audit Office has to point out to what should be a star commercial operator within government how to do its job. If people wonder why auditors are able to do that, I might tell them that it amazes me that auditors find themselves in the position of showing commercial operators how to operate. It is not as if the Auditor-General is remiss or does not know what he is talking about because, of the 45 recommendations, Australian Construction Services agrees with most of them.

PARA.TAB: Why does an organisation have to wait for the Auditor-General to come in to tell it how to run its operation? If these people, under the recommendations made here, were in the private sector, they would have gone broke. They would have crashed with the other big players in the property market who went under in the crash that occurred in the last couple of years. The only thing that saved ACS is the fact that it can come back to the public purse through the Budget and survive. That in itself is an indictment.

I will not go through the 45 recommendations because of time constraints. Some of them are plainly things that any organisation should do as a matter of course. It reflects what happens when commercial operations operate within the public sector. It does not mean that there is anything wrong with the individuals who work in the public sector. Many of those individuals are top operators who would go well in any organisation. This has been proved by those who move out of the public sector into the private sector and are eminently successful. People such as Mr Besley come to mind. He had a lifetime within the public sector and has done extraordinarily well in the private sector. But there is a whole range of those people at all levels. One does not have to be a Tim Besley.

The Auditor-General's report reflects on the bad management of the construction of the Sydney central office block. All it does is reflect the bad management of this Labor Government and what it has done to the Australian economy. One mirrors the other. Who else would go out and spend $166m of other people's money—taxpayers' money—on a building without firm commitments from any tenants to occupy the building? I find that absolutely extraordinary. It is the sort of extravagance that this country cannot afford. The taxpayers cannot afford it.

The Auditor-General points out that the indirect holding cost and direct costs as a result of this alone run into $12m because of the lack of effective management. That is an absolute disgrace. We are talking about other people's money. All levels of government in this country have to come to the realisation that when they spend money they are not spending something put out by the Mint. They are spending money contributed to them by people across a broad spectrum of Australia—by people making as little as $5,200 per annum up to whatever level one wants to nominate. Other people's money is being spent, and it is about time that governments started to ask themselves whether they have to spend certain amounts of money. If they do, what is the most cost-effective way to do it? If they do not go down that track—and I have used this term before—they are corrupt in the use of money. All governments, whether they be State, Federal or local, are trustees of other people's money and assets. They have an absolute obligation to spend that money wisely.
The Auditor-General's report vindicates the Hewson Fightback package, with its privatisation of government commercial operations and the significant cuts that it will make in government expenditure.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—On behalf of the President, in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 50 of 1991-92—Efficiency Audit—Internal Audit in selected Commonwealth organisations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This report before us deals with the results of a review of internal audits in eight Commonwealth organisations. In fact, Madam Acting Deputy President, it is the second of a three-stage review of internal audit activity in the Commonwealth public sector undertaken by the Australian National Audit Office in response to the recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in Report No. 296, The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament—Reform of the Australian Audit Office. As you may recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, this report was tabled in April 1989.

PARA.TAB: As Vice-Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, over the years, I have been concerned at the low level of resources devoted to internal audit in the past. This theme has been consistent with many other reports over the years. In fact, Audit Report No. 6 of 1991, A Survey for Internal Audit in the Commonwealth Public Sector, stated that there was a need for some authority to establish and promulgate internal auditing relative to the public sector.

Not only has this view been noted in many reports over the years during the 1980s, but also it is a view that has been shared by the Institute of Internal Auditors. There is a most definite need for the work of internal auditors to be not only encouraged but also recognised.

Consequently, when I examined this report before me today, although being pleased that there is an increased recognition of the value of internal audit—because managers and boards do want additional assurances on the adequacy of financial and other management controls—I am nevertheless disappointed that this report does not seem to provide any advancement on the findings reported in 1989 and 1991 in both aforementioned reports. It is now 1992, and we still have the same findings.

To be constructive, what is needed, instead of a restatement of what has been happening, is actually a more rigorous assessment of how internal audit is progressing in the Commonwealth. I was therefore disappointed to note that several of the large spending departments were actually omitted from the sample of the eight organisations reviewed. For example, Defence, Social Security, and Taxation have not been reviewed. If these departments had been reviewed, I believe the findings and the result of this sample may have been somewhat different.

I am sure we can all remember the concern expressed by the Australian Taxation Office at its forthcoming audit by the Australian National Audit Office. An extension had been requested, which was later withdrawn, and the findings of the National Audit Office that internal audit performance had improved since its 1990 survey, especially in the areas of audit planning, organisation, staffing and relations of line with the management, may well have been different. The very careful remarks that there is scope for further improvement, especially in staff productivity and training, task management and quality assurance, may have been much more severe, for example, if the departments of Defence, Social Security and Taxation had been reviewed.

I am concerned as to why this Report No. 50 has not questioned why we only have a restatement of what has happened in the previous reports. Many of the conclusions and recommendations of the report are exactly the same as those reached in the IDAC papers issued in the 1980s. If the report were to question why these earlier recommendations and conclusions had not been more rigorously implemented, the report would then have had substance and there would have been a definite value in terms of the document that we have before us today.

I am therefore disappointed that the report cannot report any progress in the findings with regard to the Department of Finance. It was first noted in the 1989 survey of internal audit that the Australian National Audit Office considers that the Department of Finance should play a more active role in the development of internal audit in Commonwealth organisations. The report is still giving its findings as to what should happen in the future:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Department needs to develop its own expertise in internal auditing and to establish a broadly based consultative process for advice on internal audit issues.

Why has the report not investigated why this has not occurred and discovered the reasons why? In 1991 Audit Report No. 6 stated that the Department of Finance should assist in developing the information and skills of internal auditors in the Commonwealth Public Service and to provide financial assistance to smaller agencies to encourage them to enrol auditors in the Institute of Internal Auditors and to make use of the institute's quality assurance program. As I have already stated several times, this Report No. 50 merely reiterates what has been said before.

PARA.TAB: The entire situation could be improved and addressed if more formal dialogue were to occur between the public and private internal auditors and if the recommendations which have been given over the years were actually instituted. The phrases used in terms of the need for communications are motherhood statements. They need to be developed, and it should be explained why these communications have not taken place on a more meaningful basis.

I conclude by saying that the report makes much of the independence and need for objectivity. We support this wholeheartedly. There is no question about that or about the accuracy of the report. However, it fails to delineate a definite contemporary role for internal auditors in the context of the current accountability regime of the Australian Public Service and with respect to a host of other management review and fraud control imperatives of government. In fact, it gives no recommendation as to the effective plans for incorporating internal auditors into this particular role.

Therefore, while I welcome the report, I believe that it is no more than a mere restatement of what has taken place. It does not really show the direction for improvements in objectivity and increasing recognition of the important role of internal audit, particularly in government organisations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to make a few brief comments about the Audit Report No. 50 1991-92—Efficiency Audit—Internal Audit in Selected Government Organisations. My friend Senator Watson has made many of the points that I would have made and I certainly concur with all of his comments. This report is the second in a three-stage review of internal audits by Commonwealth organisations which is being carried out within the Commonwealth public sector. The first stage was a questionnaire survey of internal audit in the Commonwealth public sector carried out in 1989-90, which was reported in Audit Report No. 6 of 1990-91. The next stage, the third stage, will be the publication of a best practice guide for public sector organisations which will be published in August this year. That guide will be based on the main lessons from this particular review. So this is an important review, and I share Senator Watson's disappointment about some aspects of it.

PARA.TAB: I am interested in the eight organisations that were actually chosen for the audit. They were the Australian Customs Service, the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, the Australian Trade Union Training Authority, CSIRO, CSL Ltd, the Department of Administrative Services, the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Special Broadcasting Service Corporation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are the big ones?

—As my colleague comments, some of those are hardly major Commonwealth organisations in terms of spending. They are all important in their own right, but some are fairly small organisations. I wonder how representative they are of the public sector as a whole and certainly of the larger cross-section of spending agencies. Yet, as I understand it from the review, the findings of the review into the internal audit of these particular eight organisations will form the basis for the best practice guide for internal audit that is to be published in a couple of months' time.

PARA.TAB: I have some concerns about the limitations of this review and report. On the other hand, there are some worthwhile findings that should be noted. The review found that senior managers treated internal auditing with appropriate importance and, even though in some cases there was some uncertainty about exactly what activities the audit should cover, that in itself I think has flushed out a need for greater specificity in that area of determining the audit activities which it would be desirable to cover. Reflecting the importance accorded to internal audits, managers have improved their audit, planning, staffing and reporting since the questionnaire survey that was conducted a couple of years ago. That is an improvement that is worth noting and applauding.

By way of further improvement, the Audit Office recommends in this report that organisations should give attention to improving management information systems, to improving the business and technical skills of auditors, and to improving audit quality assurance arrangements. Although there were, as one would expect, some differences between organisations, essentially what the Auditor-General found in relation to the effectiveness of internal audits, so far as can be judged by this particular survey, was that they are treated seriously—one would hope that that is so—that they are proving useful—one would certainly hope so—and that some further improvements can be made. With that I would concur.

The Department of Finance is reported in the Auditor-General's report as supporting the general direction of the Audit Office's recommendations, although it does disagree on some details. The eight organisations that responded welcomed the ideas put forward but cautioned against necessary or further legislation being too prescriptive. That relates to the recommendations from the Audit Office. The recommendation states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Department of Finance propose to the Government that:
(1)the new financial administration legislation require all Commonwealth organisations to:

PARA.TAB: (a)develop and maintain appropriate internal audit plans or programs
(b)establish appropriately constituted audit committees to, among other things, monitor and review internal audit plans or programs.

SPEECH.PARA: It has also recommended the issuing of directions specifying the objectives and standards governing internal audit programs and the operations of audit committees, and the establishment and support of a consultative group on internal audit in the public sector.

PARA.TAB: The coalition supports very strongly the further improvement of internal audit procedures within public sector organisations. The audit function is often regarded, and I guess rightly so, as a very dry sort of function that does not have much interest to the general community. But audit is the essential watchdog of the proper use of taxpayers' funds because they are the only funds government has to spend. Therefore, both internal audit and audit done by the Audit Office and other audit agencies of the public sector are very important functions indeed.

The coalition will certainly continue, when it reaches government in a few months' time, the process of strengthening the internal audit function, and indeed the audit function of the Commonwealth generally. We are on record time and time again as supporting the Audit Office, and for requesting the Government to get on with the job of properly reshaping the legislation that it said almost two years ago it was putting in place to review and update the necessary processes concerning the Audit Office.

There has been at least a year's slippage in that work. Whilst the new Audit Act and accompanying legislative arrangements were supposed to be in place as from 1 July this year, there has already been announced a slippage for 12 months. The way things are going, that could well slip out even further. I think that is a very serious problem because it is causing the Auditor-General and his office grave problems as there is not a proper definition for the Auditor-General of his mandate and role. The sooner the Government gets on with the very important job of finalising those new audit arrangements on behalf of all taxpayers of Australia, the better off we will all be.

Although it is not directly relevant to this particular report, No. 50, I hope that the Minister at the table, Senator Collins, may receive on behalf of the Government yet another request from the coalition to do all that it can to finalise those arrangements, put them in place and get them up and running on behalf of us all as soon as possible.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: PUBLIC WORKS COMMITTEE
FIFTY-FIFTH GENERAL REPORT
TABLING SPEECH BY SENATOR JOHN DEVEREUX

The Committee's 55th General Report covers the activities of the Committee during 1991. The Committee presented 12 reports during the year on a range of public works such as Defence facilities, the Australian Embassy in Jakarta and the Australian High Commission in Islamabad, Pakistan, CSIRO laboratories in Melbourne and houses for the Defence Force in Western Australia.
The estimated cost of the proposals on which the Committee reported during 1991 was $231 million.
The Committee met on 53 occasions during the year to conduct public hearings, carry out inspections, to consider reports and be briefed by departmental officials.
As in past years, the report raises a number of matters of concern which emerged during the year. I will briefly mention a few of them.

First, the construction of a shell filling facility at St Marys Munitions Filling Factory in New South Wales. This facility, estimated to cost $7.7 million, was referred to the Committee in October 1988. Not long after that, in December, the Committee held a public hearing into the proposal at which officials from the Department of Defence assured the Committee first, that the facility was required, secondly, that despite urban encroachment, the factory would remain at its location and thirdly, the merits of the proposed work had been assessed as essential even though the establishment of Australian Defence Industries was in the offing. Accordingly the Committee recommended to Parliament that the work should proceed.

The Committee was amazed when it was advised by the Department of Defence in May last year that the shell filling facility, which had meanwhile been completed, was no longer required. Apparently during 1990 the newly formed ADI had carried out an extensive review of its operations to rationalise and improve efficiency which resulted in the St Marys Munitions Filling Factory being no longer required.

The Committee believes the project was a debacle of monumental proportions. The new shell filling factory was proceeded with in a climate of uncertainty based on erroneous assumptions. The Committee accordingly gives notice that all public works referred to it for consideration, be they for the Department of Defence, or for other departments or agencies, will be required to withstand the `St Marys test.' That is, the need, justification, benefits and public value of public works will need to be rigorously tested by the management of departments and agencies before they are referred to the Committee.
This incident also demonstrates the risks involved in departments proceeding with the provision of major facilities during a period of organisational establishment or reorganisation.

A second matter for concern involved another incident involving the Department of Defence. It relates to the refurbishment of Endeavour House, a former migrant hostel, located in Coogee, NSW, to provide accommodation for junior sailors in the Sydney area.

The scope of the work was originally costed at $5.8 million in August 1988, but due to a litany of what can charitably be described as unfortunate circumstances, by January 1991 the cost had blown out to more than $7.2 million.
Following a briefing by Defence officials, the Committee concluded that:

PARA.TAB: a.some effort was made to adjust components of the project to keep it below the $6 million reference limit
b.the scope of the project was poorly defined

c.inadequate administrative procedures in Defence had caused a project estimated to cost at least $7.385 million from being referred to the Committee—contrary to the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Defence subsequently advised the Committee that the Secretary of the Department had been asked to review administrative processes for the control of both capital works and repairs and maintenance.

A third matter of concern relates to the approval of designs by non-Commonwealth authorities. During 1991 Australian Construction Services, formerly the Department of Housing and Construction ceased to be the Commonwealth's design and construction authority.

Departments and agencies are now free to select design and construction agents from the private sector. The Committee believes that in this environment there is scope for the rigorous oversight of the design of major works, formerly carried out by Australian Construction Services, to be diminished.
In the past Australian Construction Services was responsible for the application of planning and design principles with some measure of consistency.

At one hearing a witness submitted that there now appears to be generally no formal process by which the community can be assured that Commonwealth building work will conform to current community standards. Buildings and facilities planned and constructed for the private sector are subject to a number of formal processes such as applying for building approval, the checking of plans, inspections and the issuing of certificates of occupancy.

Whilst under the principle of the `shield of the Crown' the Commonwealth is not required to seek formal approvals and pay fees, now that departments and Government Business Enterprises are regarding buildings and facilities as saleable assets, for the full value of these assets to be realised, they would need to formally comply with local government and state government regulations.
The Committee accepts that there are constitutional issues involved and will shortly write to the Minister for Administrative Services on this matter.

The question of the provision of work based child care facilities continued to be pursued by the Committee. In a number of instances departments and agencies demonstrated that they are aware of their responsibilities to their employees. It was particularly gratifying to see a report during the year from the Australian Taxation Office, one of the largest public service employers which stated that:

The ATO sees the provision of child care facilities for employees as good human resource management practices, enabling optimal returns on the Office's investment in recruiting, developing and retaining staff.

The Committee continued to focus attention on the energy efficiency of buildings and reiterates that sponsoring departments and design and construction authorities must be more energy conscious in the design of buildings. The Committee therefore gives notice that in future more details of energy conservation principles and measures will be given close examination.

In conclusion, I would like to pay tribute to my hard-working colleagues—the Chairman, Colin Hollis—Member for Throsby, Bill Taylor—the Honourable Member for Groom, and the Honourable Members for Indi, Greenway, Grey, and Maranoa as well as my Senate colleagues—Senators Burns and Calvert. I think members of the Committee will join with me in thanking the dedicated Secretariat staff for their professional
approach to the numerous challenges during the year.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
