DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING SERVICES BILL 1992BROADCASTING SERVICES (TRADITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992

TALK.START.PARA: —Before lunch I was referring to recommendations by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure relating to the need for consultation prior to appointments to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, which under this legislation will be replaced by the Australian Broadcasting Association. I was also indicating that this issue of the representative character needed on these boards and tribunals was referred to by the Law Reform Commission, the Joint Select Committee on Video Material and other inquiries that have been undertaken.

PARA.TAB: Persons appointed to these tribunals and to the ABA should be able to truly reflect community standards based on extensive surveys and knowledge of community attitudes to matters of taste and decency. The matter of terms of office is also a matter of concern. That matter was referred to by the Law Reform Commission, as was the need for a more representative nature of appointments to the Film Censorship Board, which was referred to in the report of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies which was presented to the chamber yesterday.

I simply refer the Senate to the evidence that was given on 1 June by Messrs Dickie and Haines of the Film Censorship Board. Most States would have thought that the Film Censorship Board was tightening up guidelines in respect of violence when it changed them in 1988. The statement was made very clear by the officers of the Film Censorship Board that that was not so; that it was an arrangement—I cannot recall the words—to simplify and make more readily understandable the guidelines. But it was not to tighten up the guidelines. I think most States would have thought that that was what was going to happen.

Whilst the Film Censorship Board indicated that the States after 1988 said that the interpretation of the guidelines should be tightened, we did ask how many of the films and videos out in the community, out in the stores, had been recalled to apply that test and had been reclassified. The answer was `None'. So we need to have regard to these matters.

One of the persons concerned, Mr Haines, has been on the Board for 12 years. That runs completely contrary to the views that have been expressed by all of those committees that there should be a change of membership. The Deputy Chairman of the Film Censorship Board, Mr Haines, has now pointed to the ABT's inquiry into classification of program material on TV. One can obtain that expertise and one really does need to have others who are fresher in approaching that particular area.

My main concern is the need to provide a high priority for the protection of children against material that is likely to be harmful to them. Information that was supplied to me today from the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal survey, which I think was published yesterday—it was certainly published this month—shows some quite remarkable figures. During the period 7.30 to 8.30 p.m., which is PGR time, ratings for children are at their highest for the day with a peak between of almost 45 per cent. But the interesting thing is that between 8.00 and 8.30 p.m., ratings for children begin to decline but are still over 40 per cent of the potential child audience. That is quite remarkable. I will be referring to that later when I will be proposing amendments relating to the protection of children. The pay TV matter has been covered in terms of program standards by Senator Tierney, and I do not propose to deal with that particular question.

In conclusion, I simply say and acknowledge that some very good work is done by those in the television and radio industries in Australia and that has to be acknowledged and greatly encouraged. My real concern, however, is that there are villains in the piece who are pushing the boundaries of propriety as far as they can to make a fast buck. My concern is that, if we give the industry a freer hand in program standards, this could well result in more violence and exploitative sex programs being transmitted over television into Australian homes.

The Bill gives to the new Australian Broadcasting Authority even less control over program standards than is currently exercised by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. The Government might argue that it is putting the onus on the industry to clean up its act. That is desirable, of course, but I have certain amendments which would empower the ABA to come in at an earlier stage to rectify a certain problem. At this point in time, the public, particularly parents, are becoming fed up with the diet of violence and smut that is being dished out by certain television stations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which ones?

—I will mention them. Channel 9 in Sydney is one example. The fact that the public is fed up is shown by the enormous number of complaints received in respect of the programs on those particular channels, and about the promotions of AO programs screened by those channels within viewing times when the child audience is quite massive and where there is considerable influence over children.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I mention the matter about restoring into the legislation the provisions, so far as they can appropriately be restored, in respect of items which are blasphemous, indecent or obscene. I am particularly interested to ensure that that occurs because that amendment would cover the ABC and the SBS as well. Those responsible in the ABC and the SBS would, one would think, rely to some extent on those provisions and point them out to persons developing programs in our national broadcasting scene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the Broadcasting Services Bill 1992 and the Broadcasting Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1992. This is a major piece of legislation. It has taken a long time to arrive in the Parliament. There have been a lot of discussions within the industry and amongst members of parliament. As a member of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party transport and communications committee and broadcast subcommittee, I thank the present Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) and previous Ministers over recent years for the way they have allowed Caucus members of the committee to be involved in a very detailed discussion relating to the composition of this Bill.
—What about Richo?

—Richo was very, very good. Senator Richardson went out of his way to have endless meetings with members of the Committee during his short period as Minister. Before him was Mr Beazley and now we have the present Minister. Members of the Caucus committee came to achieve a quite detailed level knowledge about both the technical and legal aspects of broadcasting which in the end enabled us to make some judgments about what the content of this Bill should be. Any Bill that is a major revision for the first time in nearly 50 years will not satisfy everybody. I am sure that in six days time or six weeks time someone will find a clause that should have been written somewhat differently. That is the case with any major legislation that deals with an industry which is forever changing. There is no time reached when one can say, `This is it, we have covered everything possible'. I suspect that this legislation will last for a few years and then it will need further major revisions, as technology overruns any piece of legislation in this area.

PARA.TAB: I will deal with a number of matters relating to this Bill, including some of the amendments proposed by the Opposition and some other honourable senators. As to pay television, I certainly support the Government's proposal. I think we have achieved a reasonable balance. In establishing a new communications industry in Australia—that is, pay television—we are ensuring that there is diversity of ownership and good competition policy to ensure that the industry can get going and can be competitive; and we are not using the old models of establishing a monopoly and then giving some lucky commercial interest, by law, the rights to run that industry and basically dominate it without competition from anybody else.

In view of the information available as to where technology is at the moment, we have found a reasonable balance between the issue of diversity of ownership—establishing new players in the media industry in Australia—and enabling new, large amounts of investment in a competitive model so that no-one grabs all the bickies for themselves.

One of the things that has to be mentioned is that the model in this Bill will probably last for several years but certainly will not last for the decade because technological development will override it. Within three or four years digital compression will turn the programs coming off six transponders into 24 signals coming off those transponders. That means a much greater diversity of program content going into people's homes. Just as that is occurring, I suspect by the end of the decade, Telecom and Optus will be arranging for people in their homes to receive, via fibre optic, many more channels.

Also, I suspect that by the turn of the century new forms of narrowcasting using microwave and so on will make further channels available to people. Above all else, no matter what regulatory models we provide in Australia, internationally there will be unlimited amounts of program material coming in via satellite. Unless one wants to go and pull down everybody's satellite dish from on top of their houses, it will be very difficult to control people having direct access to overseas programs, whether we like it or not. Some people may think that this is a fearful prospect, that program content may contain material that they do not like. I would also say that there is an upside to that.

In the last few years authoritarian regimes around the world have fallen because people in those countries have, through new technology, access to information they previously did not get that has enabled them to put pressure on their authoritarian governments to make changes in favour of democracy, pluralism and human rights. So there is a very big upside to the new developments in telecommunications and in communications around the world, and that should be acknowledged. It will make the world a much better place; it will be much better for all people to have access to that information; and it will make it harder for the authoritarian regimes to cover up their mistakes and atrocities.

In the pay television model one area which is of concern to everybody is the development of industry policy, firstly as to the program content—so that we get encouragement for the production of Australian programs to be on pay television—and also as to the equipment itself. Under this Bill, as drafted, the Minister is able to set very clear cut specifications on the industry side about the technical equipment. For example, within this competitive model where we might have six companies providing through satellite or through cable, he can ensure that we do not have to have six black boxes or decoders sitting on top of our television sets, but a common black box through which all forms of pay television or subscription television can be received.

A great opportunity exists with those specifications to encourage the development of Australian industry. Ultimately, it also could develop into an export industry with the provision of that equipment overseas in the expanding market of our own region—that is, the Asia-Pacific.

I will say a few words about pay television in terms of the report tabled yesterday by the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technology. I was a member of that Select Committee and disagreed with the report that was tabled yesterday in a number of major ways. I have put in a dissenting report as I believe Committee members allowed their own prejudices about what they want to see on television and pay television affect their judgment on what the community should generally see.

I make no bones about the fact that many of the witnesses brought before the Select Committee were prejudiced fundamentalists who want to impose on everybody else their own sexual views about the way a modern society should operate, quite contrary to any notion of democracy, of pluralism, of choice amongst consenting adults. I am disappointed that in a number of the recommendations the Committee has accepted some of those views.

The most compelling evidence received by the Select Committee was given by people whom I consider to be proper professional experts with international credibility, such as Ms Eva Goldberg, a clinical psychologist dealing with sexual matters, and Professor Brent Waters. I found their evidence much more compelling and balanced than the ratbaggery which came from people like Dr Judith Reisman, an American who seems to be more interested in imposing a limited, narrow, fundamentalist view on the rest of a modern community. Her assertions could not be backed up by fact; they were just a prejudicial view.

Mr John Dickie, the Chief Censor, and other members of the Film Censorship Board and the Office of Film and Literature Classification are to be congratulated and supported by this Parliament for the work they have to do in a very sensitive area. They carry out that work with great discretion and great judgment and are overwhelmingly supported by ordinary Australians, who believe that we do have basically right the classification of material that is provided and available in Australia.

The situation is not as was said in evidence to us by some of what I call the ratbags: that the Office of Film and Literature Classification basically allows anything to be shown on television, heard on radio or printed in the media in Australia. The Office made it very clear that it has very simple but understandable rules that are applied to classification. For example, one of the great myths and lies that is told by certain people is that X-rated videos are violent. They are by definition, under the classifications the Office of Film and Literature Classification uses, not violent. If there is any violence in them, they do not get a classification and, if distributed, they are illegal. With the R-rated material, there is violence allowed within their general context, but again it is limited.

Pay television is quite different from free to air television. With pay television, firstly, we pay to receive it; and, secondly, when we receive it, through the black box we can ensure that R-rated and X-rated material cannot be made available to children. Devices on the black box and the provision of silicon chips can ensure access to parents but prohibit it to children.

I do not believe that the Parliament of Australia should make rules, on the basis of a very small minority comprised of a few irresponsible parents, that ban all else for the rest of the community. Unfortunately, in the hearings we had—and it is on the record—it became apparent that certainly Senator Harradine, Senator Tierney and Senator Walters want to impose that view on everyone else. The remark was made in one of the hearings that although the Communist Party of the former Soviet Union has now been disbanded and there are no Stalinists left in the Soviet Union, views expressed by those senators may mean they are the last Stalinists left in the world who want to restrict people's access to information and want to impose their views on the rest of the community. As I put in my dissenting report, I do not believe in a modern society that that is reasonable.

In the time available, I quickly turn to a couple of other Opposition amendments. The Opposition is to move an amendment to remove from the legislation the provisions on the advertising ban during election campaigns. I strenuously oppose that and, in doing so, want to point out to the Opposition that since the Bill was carried there have been quite a few elections in Australia. There have been two general elections—those of Tasmania and ACT. There has been a by-election at the Entrance in New South Wales; the Federal Wills by-election in Victoria; the Ashburton by-election in Western Australia; two by-elections in South Australia, in Kavel and Alexandra; and a Tasmanian Upper House by-election. There may even have been more. In every one of those cases, not one member of the public has complained about the operation of the political ad ban Bill.

In fact, we have people on the record from the Liberal Party actually saying that it is not a bad idea. Mr Lister, the Tasmanian Liberal campaign director, has stated that he did not believe the ban caused any disadvantage for any particular party. As recently as June, Mr Everingham, President of the Liberal Party of Queensland, said:

SPEECH.PARA: But I think perhaps what the Federal Government has done with electronic advertising laws will suit the Liberal Party because we are going to depend very much on our own resources rather than the power of the big purse.

Even Mr Everingham, President of the Liberal Party of Queensland, former Leader of the Liberal Party in the Northern Territory, former member of the House of Representatives, has said that there is a positive aspect about this ban that helps the Liberal Party. I think the operation of the ad ban has already proved very successful, and that amendment should be defeated and despatched forthwith.

PARA.TAB: I also note that the Government, through the Minister, has circulated a very welcome amendment today to remove the clause which would have given the ABA certain powers to enable journalists to be investigated, for them to be called to provide information. I believe that the Government amendment to remove that clause will assuage many of the fears of journalists. Of course, journalists are not above the law. If someone wants to take them to court in an effort to get them to divulge the sources of their information and to sue them, they take their chance in a court like everybody else. I believe that that amendment which will be moved today will overcome that problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look, you put the gag on, for heaven's sake. Abide by your 10 minutes.

—If Senator Walters keeps interjecting, I will just keep going until all my time is taken up. The Opposition has a lot more speakers on this list than has the Government. One of the other amendments that is to be moved by the Opposition to which I strongly object—I notice Senator Harradine has also put this amendment in—is to reinsert that matters of broadcasting cannot be `blasphemous, indecent or obscene'. I believe the present drafting of the Bill is more than adequate. The powers of the ABA will be able to deal in general with community standards in this area.

PARA.TAB: On the issue of blasphemy, that is a word that really has come out of the war of religions of about 300 years ago. That some still want to have the power of blasphemy in an Act of parliament when we have it quite clear that there is no official religion in Australia, that the separation of the church and the state has long been established in this country, and when at least 30 per cent of Australians declare themselves to be non-religious, I find rather odd.

I believe that as far as general community standards are concerned, matters of religion will be dealt with as program content in the broad balance of issues so that debate will take place. I find it extraordinary that people in the latter part of the twentieth century want to put into a Bill an opportunity for somebody to say, `You can't have a program that may be criticising a religion or a figure of religion because it is blasphemous'. That is out of date and undemocratic. I think the term `blasphemy', in particular, has long since served its purpose and relates to a period several hundred years ago when people killed each other in the name of religion. I think those particular amendments ought to be opposed.

Although the Bill is not perfect—no Bill as complex or wide-ranging as this could ever claim to be 100 per cent perfect—I believe that the Government has put forward a Bill that enables broadcasting communications to deal with the new technologies that are rapidly developing in the latter part of this decade. The Government is to be congratulated for being the first government in nearly 50 years to have a complete rewrite of the Broadcasting Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time available I would like to make a couple of points about radio services in rural and remote areas. We are debating the Broadcasting Services Bill 1992 and the Broadcasting Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendment) Bill 1992.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Schacht and others have pointed out, this is the first complete rewrite of the Broadcasting Bill for 50 years. One of the reasons why we needed a complete rewrite is that technology has progressed so far. Communications are global, as are the industries making communication outfits. The previous regulations were set up when there were quite a few bidders in a more compact market. With the technology that is around now, there is a lot more space available and a lot more takers.

This Bill will establish the ABA, the Australian Broadcasting Authority, which will not be quite as restrictive as the ABT. It will be set up to deal with this new technology and, most of all, to encourage competition between suppliers of services. It is a step forward, but it does not meet all our requirements in terms of the future of broadcasting policy.

I am particularly concerned about the different needs of regional and remote areas relating to radio. The country radio stations do not have the resources, including finance, that are available in the metropolitan areas. FM in regional and remote areas is a very scarce commodity. AM is generally available but its listeners are scattered far and wide in a radius of up to 200 kilometres from the main transmitter. These main transmitters in rural and remote areas are generally set up in towns with populations of 3,000 to 5,000 people. They broadcast to towns with populations of 100, 50 or even 30 people with very little in between, although homesteads can pick up these broadcasts as well.

In Merredin in Western Australia, the commercial radio station 6MD has an AM licence and broadcasts to places up to 200 kilometres away, but it is not in a position to have an FM service. If it did have an FM service, it would supply the town of Merredin, which has a population of around 4,000 people, and do nothing for the little towns and homesteads further out. It is not in a financial position to provide translators which will broadcast into those small towns.

If people in a small town with a population of 1,000 or 500 want a translator to pick up a commercial transmission from a capital city, or even the ABC, they are not allowed to because the main holder of the AM service in the centre holds the licence and they cannot just step over its territory. The licence holder is the only one that can apply for an FM licence in that region. FM, whether it be ABC or commercial, is available in these areas because the microwave links run east-west through a carrier and the satellite. Unfortunately, the smaller communities are not allowed to get together and put such a service on.

I believe that such a service is necessary these days to cover small country towns, isolated homesteads and isolated mining camps. There are more of them these days on the fly-in, fly-out system that we have, thanks to this Government and the fringe benefits tax. They can tap into the FM services quite easily with earth stations which do not cost a great amount for a single camp or a single homestead. Small earth stations will rebroadcast in small areas and they are badly needed. Hopefully, the Government will do something about that in the near future.

In the limited time available, I wish to briefly address the pay TV system that is about to hit Australia and, no doubt, is hitting the rest of the world. I was a bit surprised when this morning Senator Powell said—she is in the chamber now—that she would not have it in her home but her kids might have it in due course. I cannot understand anyone not accepting technology as it comes along.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't pay for something you can't watch. You have got to pay for it.

—I know that you pay for it, but there are other things in the house that you pay for such as running water. Did Senator Powell ever deny running water coming into the house and say no, she would cart it up from the pump instead? It has about the same correlation. I am the world's worst watcher of television. I take it as it comes. The only things I watch on television are news, current affairs, football—when my favourite team is playing—and the weather. At this time of the year, the weather is my favourite program. I cannot be bothered watching the rest of it. But there may be a few selected things that I would watch on pay TV and as the technology is available, why not use it?
—I can't afford it; you have more money than I have.

—Okay. I believe that the footprint of pay TV will go inland. From the briefings I had—and I am talking about Western Australia—the footprint will not go far inland, but will go to the heavily populated areas. I would like to be assured that it will cover isolated areas where there are big towns, such as Kalgoorlie, with 30,000 people, Port Hedland and Karratha, as well as smaller towns.
—Don't forget the Northern Territory.
—I represent the State of Western Australia—
—And very badly.
—I do not think too many will agree with the Minister on that point.
—Everyone over here.

—I will leave it to the Minister to represent the Northern Territory. I believe that pay TV will provide isolated towns with the amenities which they lack. It can be beamed into camps and other isolated places by satellite. Pay TV will also be available by MDS, the microwave system, and by optic fibre, although for most of our lifetime optic fibre will be available only in the main capital cities.

PARA.TAB: Pay TV is fairly cost efficient. I am told from briefings that it will cost between $200 and $250 to set up a dish on a homestead. I presume that the more remote one gets, the bigger the dish which will be needed, and that will cost more—$40 to $45 a month. Senator Powell should know that we will pay for what we use. I do not believe that it will be costly. I like the idea of retaining one of the transponders for the ABC. I have always supported the ABC. I know that ABC radio is starved of funds these days.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you're going to cut fifty million bucks a year off it.
—The Minister should not worry about what we are going to do. We are going to spend the money more efficiently.
—I do worry about what you're going to do, as do a lot of other people.

—I know you worry. You worry because you know that you are going to lose the next election. Mr Acting Deputy President, you may remember that the other day there was a football game at the Melbourne Cricket Ground which was broadcast back to Western Australia. The equipment broke down. I believe that the ABC could not afford a technician at the game and the commentator had to broadcast the game back to Western Australia by telephone. The telephone dropped out two or three times. I admire the commentator's fortitude in keeping going. It is time the Government looked at these small things in broadcasting that do not cost very much money. Keeping a technician at the games on Saturday afternoons would cost very little relative to the whole broadcasting budget.

PARA.TAB: As I said, I have always been a supporter of the ABC. I want to see a transponder for the ABC. When digital video compression comes along—much sooner perhaps than was expected, because technology will not stop on 30 June, 1992; it will progress—I would like SBS also to have that technology available. The Minister can shake his head as much as he likes. Competition would be possible for other satellites that may be available, such as Intelsat and others.

There is concern about the sort of material that may be broadcast on pay TV. I am pretty relaxed about what is available on pay TV or video as long as it is controlled. But, as I have told Senator Harradine before, there have to be safeguards and we have to draw the line somewhere. I heard the Minister use a term the other day. I forget what it was. I think he said that, if they want crude, they can have crude—

TALK.START.PARA: —Crud, I said—`crud'. Just drop the `e'.

—All right. I am pretty open-minded, but I believe that there has to be a cut-off point somewhere. I would not want to see the airwaves opened up to all the trash that some fear may be broadcast. I have a report here which contains certain recommendations. I am not going to go through them, but I believe that they are probably worth looking at. I hope that commonsense prevails in regard to pay TV. I certainly look forward to seeing pay TV come into action in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Broadcasting Services Bill 1992. It is a most important Bill. I think it will stand Australia in good stead in the next decade, although amendments may have to be made in that period. It has been a very extensive Bill involving very extensive restructuring. We are in the middle of the guillotine. The Government and the Democrats have moved for the guillotine of this Bill and so our time is very limited. On this side of the chamber we all decided that the backbenchers would talk for 10 minutes each. But Senator Schacht would not abide by that. He spoke for nearly double that time. When the Government moves the guillotine, I believe that it is inappropriate for one senator to take more than his fair share of time.

PARA.TAB: Because the time is so short I will speak on only one section of this Bill, and that is program standards. What the Government has decided in this regard is that the ABA will determine the standards of programs for children and the Australian content of programs. Only those two areas will be covered by decisions of the ABA. The Government has said that the industry itself should develop codes of practice. Those codes of practice can be looked at by the ABA and the ABA must be assured that they are in accordance with community standards.

The Government laid the Bill on the table some time ago for people to be able to respond to it. There have been several alterations in the new legislation compared to the old, and this is one of them. The old Bill said that programs must be in accordance with `prevailing community attitudes to matters of taste and decency'. But that has gone. Now it is `in accordance with community standards'.

The Government has said that the ABA may conduct surveys to establish these standards, but immediately pre-empts the ABA's decision in establishing community standards by saying that pay television may have R rated material only when it is accessed through the use of a pin number, smart card or whatever.

The Committee of which I was Deputy Chairman and which looked into the standards of pay television has come down with certain recommendations. Of the three recommendations that are most important to this Bill, one is that it agrees with the Government that X rated material should not be considered suitable for pay television. When it came to R rated material, we said that we had such conflicting evidence in this regard that we believed that community attitudes to taste and decency should be established once and for all.

Senator Schacht has one view; he was entirely on his own in this area. The rest of the Committee believed that the community has never been allowed to express its views on community standards. The Film and Censorship Board, Senator Schacht assures us, has the complete support of the community. But when we asked its members how they came to this decision, they said that they talk to people—they travel on buses and talk to people in bus queues. I do not believe that is an appropriate way to establish community standards.

Our Committee has recommended that the ABA conduct extensive, Australia-wide qualitative and quantitative community research on community standards of taste and decency in relation to the classification of pay television, on what levels of violence and depictions of sex should be allowed and on what other matters should be included for viewing by adults and children in various classifications. I believe that that is a very important recommendation because, as I said earlier, it has never been done before and we have no idea what the community believes. As I go around my electorate, the majority of people say to me that the amount of violence on free to air television is too strong for their taste. The Governor-General made the same statement—that, as he goes around the countryside, he finds that people are concerned about the level of violence that there is on television.

Senator Schacht said today that he took great note of the evidence of Professor Brent Waters. I could not agree with him more. When questioned about the use of Smartcard and PINs and whether that would save children seeing unwanted material, Professor Waters—who is a professor of child and adolescent psychiatry and lived in Canada for some time where pay television exists—said that he thought that parents often did not understand them and that this, coupled with a lack of supervision, told him that children were more at risk and created greater concerns. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: While I believe that R rated material is probably harmful to some individuals and may have some harmful effect on the incidence of violent crime, the behavioural science studies have not been of sufficient quality to either affirm or discount this. My view would be that if Pay TV offers unrestricted access to children, harmful effects are more likely to occur.

As I said, the intention of the Government is to have R-rated material available solely with the use of a PIN or Smartcard but, as Professor Waters said, this really is not secure enough to shield children. As I say, we had a tremendous amount of conflicting evidence. We had members of the National Women's Consultative Council say that they were particularly concerned. They believed that the pervasiveness of violent images was a contributing factor to the normalisation of a physical and sexually violent culture affecting the security and safety of women. Mr Lark, who always turns up at these things—he is one of the big lobbyists in Canberra—said, `No, anything goes. Put in X, put in R, put the lot in'. That was the evidence he gave. Because of this conflicting evidence, we made the recommendation and I believe that this is the way we should go.

PARA.TAB: We cannot rely on the industry making the decision. We cannot rely on the ABA being able to assess community standards any more than we can rely on the Film Censorship Board assessing community standards. The Film Censorship Board has never been able to establish that, and I believe that the reason we came up with this recommendation was most important. I would like to read—I hope the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), who is at the table, will listen to this—a judgment brought down not very long ago in a murder case. Part of the judgment says:

SPEECH.PARA: At about 9.30 that morning the prisoner watched a video he had hired from a Wagga Wagga video shop. It was called "Nightmare at Shadow Woods". It was an unpleasant, violent film in which the major character was a psychopath who roamed the area with a large knife killing a number of people in extremely ghoulish circumstances.

PARA.TAB: Having watched this film the prisoner took a knife, known as a butterfly knife, and walked across the paddocks to —

SPEECH.PARA: the name of the victim's—
home. He went to the front door and spoke to—
the victim—
about some stray sheep which he said he had penned.
Further on, the judgment states:
The prisoner apparently left but did not return home. Instead he waited outside—
the victim's—
home and about five minutes later removed the flyscreen from a bedroom window and climbed in. He encountered—
the victim—

in a hallway. She ran towards the kitchen in an unsuccessful attempt to reach the telephone. . . . She was clearly no match for the frenzied strength of the prisoner. He stabbed her again and again. Even when she was on the ground . . .
Further on, the judgment continues:

PARA.TAB: Her two young children were sitting at the kitchen table watching it all and screaming. They were still sitting in the same place in the presence of their dead mother when—

SPEECH.PARA: her husband—
arrived home with the two older children about four hours later.

I do not have time to read a lot of the judgment, but two psychiatrists gave evidence in the case. Both of them said that they believed the violent video triggered the patient's violent outburst. The psychiatrists, one who was acting for the defence and one who was acting for the Crown, both agreed that the video had emotionally aroused the prisoner and had triggered the action.

PARA.TAB: The decision was that the prisoner was quite able to distinguish right from wrong. He was a very disturbed young man but was not psychiatrically certifiable in any way. The judge said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not so easy to absolve a system which allows for such a violent and unmeritorious film as "Nightmare at Shadow Woods" to be viewed indiscriminately by members of the community regardless of their underlying problems or susceptibilities. It was a film with no discernible artistic material at all. As far as I could see it was nothing more than a vehicle for depicting gratuitous, mindless and ghoulish violence.
The judge went on to explain that both doctors thought that the film had acted as a trigger and that it was a disturbing agent in the prisoner's already disturbed brain. The judge said:

I cannot help wondering what benefits society can derive from having such a mindlessly violent film as this generally available to be viewed by anyone, no matter how disturbed he or she may be. The potentially devastating effects can be seen in the events of 27 February.

I read that judgment because I asked the Chief Censor of the Film Censorship Board, Mr Dickie, whether he had read the judgment and reviewed the film. He said that he had been aware of both the judgment and the film but still believed that that film should be available under the M category. Unless we do something about the violence that we are presently seeing both in the videos that are available and on television, I believe we are leaving our community open for similar situations to arise.

PARA.TAB: We all know that very behaviourally disturbed children attend our schools. They are not certifiable, but they have behavioural problems of violence. In allowing children growing up to view such films, I believe we are running a tremendous risk. It is because of my great concern in this area that I was so pleased to see the majority report of this Committee come down so strongly in the way it did in making sure that we can assess the general view of the community before we make any decisions as to what should and should not be allowed on pay television.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—While I welcome the shadow Minister into the chamber, I note once again that he cannot trust, as is his want, his opposite number in the Senate to carry the Broadcasting Services Bill and the Broadcasting Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill through unassisted and appears once again in the adviser's box. I have to say that Kim Beazley, when he was the Minister for Transport and Communications, never did that to me in the two years I was taking his stuff through this place. I would like to welcome the honourable member to the Senate. It is very pleasing to see one of these rare birds from the House of Representatives gracing us with his presence.

PARA.TAB: I welcome the general support that has been provided by all speakers in this debate for the legislation. There is widespread support for this legislation. Everyone who has come through my door in recent weeks has supported the thrust of the reforms, and the previous Ministers for Transport and Communications found the same level of support, as was alluded to in a debate earlier today. This Bill goes back a very long way. This Bill has been years in the making. Given the amount of consultation that has taken place on this legislation, it is not surprising that this level of support has occurred.

The Bill is significantly different from the exposure draft—it is different and it is better. It has been changed by the Government in response to views put forward by community groups and the radio and television industry. The Government was not prepared to accept every criticism levelled at the Bill. But I firmly believe that we have struck the right balance. What made the job a lot easier was the widespread belief that reform of the Broadcasting Act 1942 was long overdue. I thank all people who were involved in that exhaustive consultation process for their ideas and their cooperation. The Government will be moving a number of amendments today in response to further consultation and to tidy up certain drafting problems.

I would quickly like to go through as many of the substantive issues as I can that have been raised in debate. I must address immediately the question of the exclusivity provisions that have been so strangely criticised by the Opposition. I say `strangely' because, as Senator Powell pointed out, the Opposition's current proposal is ludicrous. The Opposition has vacillated wildly on a range of options that are supposed to protect the viability of the first pay television licence that will buy a four-transponder satellite service. I was therefore totally amazed to sit in this chamber this morning and hear the Opposition put forward a truly bizarre proposal that demonstrates a clear misunderstanding of what pay TV is all about. I cannot honestly believe that the shadow Minister is in favour of this; I am sure that he must have been rolled in his party room on this one.

In fact, as I have said, Senator Powell drew our attention to this pig in a poke bundling—which I think was the expression used by Senator Alston—of individually sold single transponders for pay TV. The Opposition appears to have missed completely the point about what pay TV is about. Experience internationally has demonstrated this, if it has demonstrated nothing else: to be commercially successful, pay TV is about a multi-channel choice, letting viewers watch what they want to, when they want to and on a number of channels. That is how it works in the rest of the world. This proposal is world unique and that is why everybody certainly wants four transponders.

The industry might have views on exclusivity. It also has views about wanting to access immediately 94 per cent of the Australian population with the technology now available on more than one channel. That is why everybody wants at least multiple transponders. Everybody also wants some market protection. I might say that that has also varied wildly and widely in the representations that I have had. Not surprisingly, the people who want to get this exclusivity want a lot of it. I have had serious representations made to me for 15 years of protection.

This morning I asked Senator Alston, by way of interjection, how his bundling proposal would work. The Hansard will demonstrate that he was very specific in his response. He said, `We will not allow alliances between the single transponder users'. The proposition which the Opposition has put up is not only unworkable but also it is quite bizarre. Senator Alston was very specific—and Senator Powell also commented on it afterwards—that there will be no alliances allowed between the individual operators who might get all of these single channels. So, until digital compression is available, any of these people who are expected to try to establish a market, to try to invest this amount of capital, to try to get market penetration, to try to drive what the technology is going to be, will be able to broadcast on only one channel.

Senator Alston said that the Opposition will not allow any alliances between them. Senator Alston said—and this is a scorched earth approach—that there has to be absolute maximum choice. It is a bizarre proposal which is entirely unworkable. I must say that I just do not understand what is driving it. How could a single channel service possibly be marketed?

There are wildly varying views—and views have been put to me—about digital compression. People say that if we want to pay for it, `it might be available in two years'. But there is wide consensus in the industry that in terms of affordable digital compression—that is, a technology which provides quality which people will actually be able to pay for—is somewhere between four and six years away.

It is worth pointing out that all of the proponents in 1982—I remember them very well—said that optic fibre was just around the corner in every home in Australia. I have files full of assertions that were made in regard to that. But 10 years later there is now a widespread industry view that that technology will never ever arrive in that sense. Experience around the world—and Senator Alston knows this—is that it is the hybrid systems which have proved to be the most achievable. I am talking here about optic fibre to a distribution point and normal cheap coaxial cable from that point on. So I would treat these statements with some degree of suspicion and doubt. Assuming that digital compression is four to six years off, the fundamental proposition on which the whole pay TV service advanced by the Opposition is based is not only unworkable but is bizarre.

So far as the free transponder for the ABC is concerned, let me say at the outset that the Government has demonstrated its support in a very substantial way for ABC involvement in pay TV. The difference between us and the Opposition is that we want the ABC to do it on sensible commercial grounds. Anyone who knows anything about pay TV and understands where the ABC is coming from on this—and the ABC has a very detailed proposal—knows that the Opposition's proposal is ludicrous. We have to make sure that this new service requirement is provided to the ABC with a sensible business plan, with access to the necessary equity capital and so on.

The Broadcasting Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill that is before the Senate paves the way for the ABC to play a part in pay TV. We have also made available $12.5m to enable the ABC to get started. Under Fightback, the Opposition will axe the ABC by $50m a year recurrent. But, more importantly, the Government will accept no risk exposure from this commercial operation, nor will it allow the ABC's charter activities to be compromised. I cannot have been stronger in my public views on that.

Personally, I have no doubt that what is driving the Opposition in terms of its determination to have the ABC in pay TV is its desire to see the ABC become more and more commercial so that it will have an excess for axing the ABC's budget. There is no question in my mind about that. People keep talking about quality programming. If we really want to see quality programs, why, under the Opposition's proposals, are we going to force SBS to wait until digital compression is available? As I have said, the consensus view is that commercially this is four to six years away.

Why does not the Opposition be up front and include SBS in this proposal as well as the ABC? As I have said before, the fundamental thing that is driving the Opposition in its desire to push the ABC into pay TV is the opportunity to further cut the ABC's budget. There is no question about this.

I might add that we have concerns about the hasty drafting—and I will allude to that in a minute—which is in the same schedule of amendments that contain the ABC amendments. We are not in a position simply to agree after being given five minutes notice. We have a little bit more concern about this matter. We do support the involvement of the ABC in pay TV in the way in which we have already outlined. We have some real budget commitment for the ABC to do it properly. But we cannot at this time support the amendments that are currently proposed by the Opposition.

In regard to the report of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies—the 0055 committee report—I am not going to get bogged down once again in discussing a subject which has been canvassed to such an extent in this House. But the Government does endorse the Reynolds committee recommendations on X-rated material. Under this Bill, X-rated material is banned on all commercial and subscription television broadcasting services in Australia.

We also agree that the ABA should conduct Australia-wide qualitative and quantitative research on community attitudes in relation to classifications for pay TV. However, the Committee recommends as an interim measure the use of current free to air television standards for pay TV. Banning R-rated material would reduce, without any question, the attractiveness of pay TV and deny viewers access to mainstream blockbuster movies such as The Godfather, Taxi Driver, Apocalypse Now and even Australia's own Don's Party.

I absolutely agree with Senator Walters that there is a lot of rubbish in the R-rated category—there is no question about that—but there are some absolutely spectacularly good movies for adults that not only should adults have the right to watch but some of which they should watch. I am sure that Senator Walters would agree with me—or maybe she would not—about one R-rated movie we saw on the committee dealing with X-rated videos. It dealt with the horrendous problems of rape for women and was so thought provoking that not only should people have the right to watch such movies, but, in my view, it would be advisable for them to do so.

What is at the bottom of our proposals on R-rated movies is quite simple. We can have this debate about whether we should have R-rated movies, but why should anybody argue about pay TV, which is a discretionary service that is basically moving the video shop on the corner to a black decoder on the top of the television set? People should at least have the same access to the programming that is available straight off the shelf—tons of it—from the local video store. It makes no sense otherwise.

There needs to be a device which enables absolute security in terms of the choices that the adults in a house make about what they will watch. Senator Walters is shaking her head, and I know why. I am not going to get bogged down in this, but I refer to an interjection that Senator Harradine pounced upon in his contribution earlier when I said, `The parents are responsible. Why are you putting all the onus on the TV?'. Senator Harradine talked at length about the dreadful problem with children in Australia watching so much television and having access to this material. The problem is this: in the real world—the world I live in—yes, Australian children do watch much more TV than they should do. Who is responsible for that? Their parents are. Australian children watch far too much R-rated and M-rated material that they should not watch. Who is responsible for that? Their parents are responsible. That is who is responsible.

I will tell honourable senators what happens in the real world—and I am not condemning these people; this is just what happens. An adult goes to the video shop, walks out with an armload of $7-worth of M-rated and R-rated videos for seven days and leaves them lying all over the house. Kids have greater access to R-rated material in the real world now, courtesy of their parents, than they could possibly have under this system, which can only be accessed with a Smartcard or some enabling device which is as secure as a Bankcard—and kids only get that when their parents want them to, too.

I make this point for the last time in this debate: ultimately, it is not a question for this Parliament to start denying TV. Senator Panizza spoke about waiting until more technology is developed. If we took this attitude, we would still be locked up with our crystal sets where we all started from 40 years ago. That is an extraordinarily stupid position to take.

I have views on R-rated material, particularly in terms of violence. Senator Harradine knows them, as does Senator Walters. That is the crud that I am referring to in blockbuster TV movies. It does not stop them being box office hits, but you would be a fool to equate box office success with quality. It is the violence in those movies that I object to.

Pay TV is a separate issue. Pay TV, at least sensibly, should have as much access to that material as the local video store down on the corner does. Otherwise, people will still do what they do now and just get the R-rated material, leave it all over the house, as they do now, and the kids will watch it. That is the parents' fault; it is not the fault of the television channel that provides material.

The Australian Democrats proposed that the 10 per cent Australian drama requirement be introduced on all subscription services from day one. That is not a workable proposition. We learned from the VAEIS system and the Canadian experience that, if we over-regulate at the outset, we may drive services out of business. NBS and cable technologies will be extremely limited in the early years of their audience work—and they will. Some services will also be limited by the fact that they will only want to pursue niche markets, particularly ethnic services where such imposts would only exacerbate their marginality. Some that I know will be totally at odds with what they are trying to provide for their markets anyway.

In my view, the Government has taken the far more sensible approach of legislating for a review in 1997 of the appropriateness of the current regime. At that time, we will be better placed to assess on the basis of experience the extent to which the fledgling industry can bear such costs.

With regard to the suggestion that we should define `new', I would have thought that this word was well understood by the regulator and the courts. Of course, the Government will be expecting new produced-for-pay-TV drama to emerge. In fact, most of the serious operators say that the only way they will succeed is if they do that. No doubt the ABA will be issuing guidelines for licensees.

I reiterate here, as I did in the second reading speech, that the Government has made it fundamentally clear that, as far as the four-transponder service is concerned, the Government will be providing guidelines which will result in Australian industry having a substantial involvement in this process. I am told—and I think it is probably right—that up to 4,000 jobs can reasonably be expected to be created. My own view, for what it is worth, is that pay TV will take off in this country; everything else similar to it has. I think that 4,000 jobs will be created as a result of this industry. This Government is absolutely determined to ensure that they are Australian jobs and that we will provide those standards.

As far as the ABA's powers to investigate the content of programs is concerned—and this is our concern about the much argued journalists' privileges—the concern we have about the Democrats' amendment, and I hope on reflection they agree with this, is that it goes well beyond the protection of journalists' notebooks. That is the problem with it. The main concern is that it would effectively neutralise the ABA's powers in relation to program standards and complaints. For example, the ABA could not use its powers under clauses 171, 175 or 193 to effectively police standards, particularly Australian content and children's programming.

Broadcasters could refuse to produce documents such as scripts and videotapes under this amendment, which would be vital for any such investigation, making it impossible for the ABA to enforce standards. Therefore, for that reason, and only that reason, the Government feels that we cannot accept the Democrats' solution to this problem.

I am on the public record—and I assert it again—as having a view about journalistic privilege. It is something we need to have a look at. In my view, the experience over the years has been that, in genuine cases of investigative journalism, when journalists have run foul of the courts, the law has ended up on every occasion looking like an ass and the journalists like heroes. But it is not as simple providing for that protection as people think it is. A classic example of how to stuff it up has been provided by the Opposition in the debate here today. We cannot accept—

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at 201.
—I know what 201 says. We cannot accept the Democrats' amendment for the reason that I have given. It goes much further than journalistic notebooks.As far as circulated amendment No. 5 is concerned—
—We are not pursuing 200. If you want to save time, we are not pursuing 1 to 200.

—No, I am not going to save time. I cannot resist rubbing the noses of those opposite in it. Frankly, the only reason they are withdrawing it is that I pointed out the bloody stuff-up.I am doing it not to embarrass the Opposition but to point out the difficulty, as have a number of journalists, of jumping in and saying, `Look, all you have to do is this, that or something else and you have fixed the problem'. I am delighted that the Opposition is withdrawing its circulated amendment. I saw the shadow Minister for communications leave the chamber with Senator Alston and fix it, and I am delighted they have.

PARA.TAB: As drafted, the amendment that was going to fix this exempted a journalist from any requirement to answer a question or produce a document where the answer to the question or the production of the document would disclose the identity of a confidential source of information. That amendment was to be made to clause 200 of the Bill. As the heading makes absolutely clear, the entire section is dealing with providing protection for the members of the panel, not witnesses.

As was pointed out to me by legal counsel, the effect of that amendment would, arguably, have been to have provided a penalty of a year in gaol for any person asking a journalist to produce information that might disclose a source. For example, a journalist in the dock before a judge in Perth, who is charged with an offence under the relevant Act on insider trading, could have demanded and got an exemption from providing that information under this provision. The amendment does not restrict this exemption of journalists to their journalistic activities.

This is a wide-ranging amendment that exempts journalists from having to answer a question about confidential sources even if it has nothing to do with their work. It is a piece of nonsense. Not only would it exempt the journalist from providing that information in a court, but it could conceivably sentence the judge to a year in gaol under this amendment for even asking for the information. It is a piece of nonsense. I am glad the Opposition is withdrawing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've taken five minutes to bag the draftsman.

—I know Senator Alston is embarrassed by it. So much has been said about this in the past week that it is worth saying that, in order to provide the necessary protection of journalists—which I have consistently publicly asserted should be provided—it is not as simple a solution as the Opposition might have us believe. That is why Opposition members have made such a comprehensive mess of it in trying to introduce it into this legislation.

PARA.TAB: I commend to the Senate the Government's suggestion, which is a far cleaner solution. I invite the Opposition to withdraw its second amendment in the light of this proposal, and I ask the Democrats for their support to delete the entire clause from the Broadcasting Services Bill. That is precisely what the Government is proposing to do.

So far as advertising is concerned, the question is whether we have to go back to a mandated advertising time. I have made the Government's position clear. We would prefer to allow the industry to develop a code of conduct, but—consistent with the fact that the industry did not stick to its own arrangements previously and the tribunal had to reimpose a mandated code—we have put the industry on notice. I have personally said to representatives of the networks, and they accept it, that if they provide a code, which obviously would have to be largely consistent with the current standards, and they transgress it, we would expect the ABA immediately to pull them to heel on it.

I think clause 181 is the relevant clause as it allows the Minister to have an inquiry into a matter if he wants to. I do not mind advising the Senate that the Government would not hesitate to provide for this inquiry if the ABA did not move. Personally, I am confident that that would be totally unnecessary. I have no doubt that the ABA would move if the code of practice proved not to be complied with.

As for the question of complaints about the ABC and SBS, the complaints provisions in this Bill are sensibly balanced between providing an independent adjudicator of complaints about the ABC or SBS and the need to preserve the editorial independence of those organisations. The balance is achieved by giving the ABC and SBS autonomy over development of their own codes of practice. The ABC and SBS are required to notify codes which the ABA will use as a benchmark. If a complaint is proven, the ABA can ask the national broadcasters to take corrective action. If they do not, the ABA will report to the Minister who must table that report in the Parliament. The threat of public exposure should encourage the national broadcasters to abide by their codes, and I think it will.

If the Democrats' amendment to remove this court of last resort were adopted, it would still not solve the problem of handling complaints. It is, however, very likely that a far more costly mechanism would be needed elsewhere. If the Opposition amendment of parliamentary disallowance of ABC and SBS codes were accepted, this may be an unwarranted intrusion—and in my view would be an unwarranted intrusion—into the editorial independence of those organisations.

The Parliament approves the charters and enabling legislation of these bodies. To go further could lead to political interference in the day-to-day services of the ABC and SBS, and it should be rejected by this Parliament. The wording currently proposed in the Bill at clauses 148 to 151 is a balanced approach between these two extremes. I commend it to the Senate.

So far as the enforcement provisions are concerned, people have approached me suggesting that the penalties, which can be as high as $2m a day, are too severe. The Government believes that breaches of key provisions of the Bill, given the influence of broadcasting services, and television in particular, should be the subject of significant penalties as a disincentive. I stress that the penalties of the Bill are the maximum that can be imposed. Also, they would not be imposed by the regulator but by a court which would take into account the severity and importance of the breach. The degree of regulatory intervention and associated penalties reflect the power of the service to influence. There is a sliding scale of penalties consistent with this principle and similar penalties are included in the Telecommunications Act.

However, the Government is moving an amendment to reduce the daily penalties, while retaining the maximum penalty. I believe this is an effective and reasonable compromise. To do this would reduce the daily penalty for ongoing offences to one-tenth of the penalty for the principal offence, but leave the maximum penalty in place for the initial breach. It reduces the maximum daily penalty from a potential $2m to $200,000, still providing the incentive to rectify breaches.

I must say, with respect to the Opposition and giving them the benefit of the doubt, that this is possibly another Opposition stuff-up, but the Government cannot support the Opposition's proposal to allow the banning of advertising for a limited period. The difficulty with that is that when there is an effective monetary penalty, why should people who want to advertise their products be disadvantaged? It may well be that it is the only channel in town that can do it for them, and they want to advertise and promote their products. Why should the innocent bystanders be made the victims by not allowing their products to be advertised because the TV channel is being punished? It makes no sense. I ask for that not to be supported, because we have adequate financial penalties to impose on the TV channel without punishing the advertisers themselves.

The Opposition is still proceeding with its amendment to put a cap on the maximum. That is crazy. To suggest that the maximum that can be charged on a daily penalty should be capped will mean that the daily penalty will run out after two days. Again, giving the Opposition the benefit of the doubt, I regard this as a mistake.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've got three minutes left.

—I am the Minister, for what that is worth, and, not surprisingly, Senator Alston took the time allocated to him to put the Opposition's view. I am obliged to provide as substantive a response as I can at this stage to save time, and I do not hesitate to do so.

PARA.TAB: I suggest that the Opposition should rethink that amendment. The difficulty in having a cap on a daily penalty is that the cap is soaked up after two days of continuing penalties. It is then finished, and it is not much of a disincentive in terms of a daily penalty. The Government's proposals are far more acceptable.

As far as 100 per cent audience reach for television is concerned, the Labor Party is having a continuing debate about it. We do not think it is possible to support it at this stage, because we are worried about the effect it might have on remote TV services. We want to look at it before we move to it.

I will conclude on the question of AM-FM conversion because I have received a number of representations from individuals and industry on the issue of AM to FM. As a result of those representations, I accept the arguments that have been made and the Government will introduce an amendment to address this issue.

It has taken four years to get this legislation into the Parliament. I wish to acknowledge the enormous amount of work put into this exercise by my Department. Those who work in it are often forgotten, and certainly more often they are criticised in terms of having unwarranted power and all the rest. But the fact is that a very dedicated group of professionals have devoted the past four years of their professional lives to producing this piece of legislation. I am pleased to say that people on both sides of this Parliament—and indeed outside this Parliament—have acknowledged that this is a good piece of legislation. I thank those concerned for the invaluable contribution they have made to it. The end result of all of this work is that we have a regulatory framework that will take Australian broadcasting into the twenty-first century. It is a landmark reform package for radio and television in this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee will consider the Broadcasting Services Bill 1992.
—Mr Chairman, might I seek your guidance. I think we would all be assisted if the Minister could give some indication of the time that he is proposing to make available. We did have a discussion—
—The time on the clock is all that we have left under the guillotine.
—We had an agreement with Margaret just half an hour ago. The time will be 7 o'clock. That is the original guillotine time.

—We did have informal discussions about taking the matter a little further and, in view of two developments, I will be moving that we extend the sitting time until 7.30 p.m. I will do so for two reasons. One reason is that there are a huge number of amendments—
—Senator Alston, you cannot move that the time be extended. The Minister can.
—I was simply indicating that when the time arrives I will be seeking leave to move—
—I think you probably could do that at the end of the time.

—I am simply indicating that, in view of the fact that Senator Collins took every second of 30 minutes when he had made it clear to me that he was not proposing to do that, we have therefore compressed the time to the point—
—That is nonsense, Richard, and you know it. I said exactly the opposite.
—Senator Collins comes over and says that he will keep his remarks short and all of those encouraging but utterly incorrigible comments. I am simply—
—That is a total misrepresentation, Richard, and you know it.
—I am afraid that all I can say is that the Minister does give indications at one level but they are never delivered in terms of time.
—That is nonsense.
—I do not want to pursue it now. I am just saying that Senator Collins has taken the maximum amount of time. In view of that fact—
—It is hardly surprising.
—The Minister can say that here but it is not what he says privately.

—I will address all of these issues. First of all, it is a total nonsense to suggest that that was done. It is a silly point to make because convention, apart from commonsense, would dictate that what always is tried in this chamber and often fails is that the lead speakers from both sides and the Democrats are given—
—Are we in committee?

—An explanation was asked for, Senator, and I am giving it—and we are in committee. The lead speakers from both sides are given time. What I said to Senator Alston—and what I did—was that, in order to make the committee stage of this Bill flow as well as we could, I would cover all of the amendments moved and give the Government's position on all of them in my final speech on the second reading. I asked Senator Alston to do the same and he was kind enough to do it, which is why he took most of his allocated time—
—That's right.

—I thank Senator Powell, who has confirmed that that was the agreement. Senator Powell did exactly the same thing. All I have done is abide precisely by the agreement that we reached in order to expedite the committee stage. I have done that.

PARA.TAB: So far as the guillotine is concerned, we did negotiate an additional half an hour. That was before all the procedural nonsense that occurred here in this chamber this afternoon, which ate all the time up. As our Whip will attest, the Opposition Whip came over here just 10 minutes ago and agreed that the debate would conclude at 7 o'clock. That is precisely the agreement. It was reached with the Opposition Whip only 10 minutes ago, and that is what we will be sticking to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a suggestion to the Committee that we proceed and that we have a cut-off time of 7 o'clock. If the Opposition wishes to make some motion then in relation to the time, that would be the time to do it. I would suggest that we just go now until 7 o'clock and see what happens. I would suggest that the first Bill we have before us, the Broadcasting Services Bill, be taken as a whole. Is it the wish of the Committee that that be done? There being no objection it is so ordered.

INTERJECT.PARA: BROADCASTING SERVICES BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the amendments to be moved by the Government to these Bills. I also table a further supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to an amendment and a new clause to be moved by the Government to the Broadcasting Services Bill 1992, including a correction to the explanatory memorandum, and a further supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to an amendment to be moved by the Government to the Broadcasting Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1992.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have 11 amendments to move to the legislation and the Minister, in his reply, has not addressed any of them. I have sent to him a brief explanatory note in respect of these and I will just go very briefly through that. The first amendment adds the words `prevailing community attitudes to matters of taste and decency'. These words were contained in the exposure draft. The insertion of these words in the objects clause would reinforce the duties of both broadcasters and the ABA to be aware of community standards. The word `respect' has been replaced with the word `reflect' which was the word used by the House of Representatives Standing Committee. The word `any' has been included before the word `program' so as to restore the need for programs to meet program standards both in part and in whole.

PARA.TAB: The second amendment simply reflects my desire to reinforce the power of the ABA. It proposes to amend the objects clause, clause 3, by substituting `encourage and ensure' for `encourage'. The third amendment adds the following paragraph to the objects of the Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: to ensure that providers of broadcasting services place a high priority on the protection of children from exposure to program material which may be harmful to them.

My fifth amendment is to clause 121 and it would require the broadcasters to adopt `methods of ensuring that the protection of children from exposure to program material which may be harmful to them is a high priority'.

PARA.TAB: The fourth amendment reintroduces the relevant portions of section 118 of the current Act but does so in a manner which will enable the ABA and others with locus standi to take appropriate action. Under section 118 of the current Act, it is an offence for any person to have broadcast over radio or television any matter which is blasphemous, indecent or obscene.

The sixth amendment simply enables the ABA to deal with codes of practice as well as standards. This amendment simply deletes the word `convincing' which is currently in the Bill before the word `evidence'. I believe that deleting the word `convincing' will limit unnecessary litigation being taken by the industry against ABA decisions. Again, amendments 7 and 8 simply add the words `codes of practice' to the provision. Amendment 9 also adds the words `codes of practice', and it adds section 120 codes of practice to those measures which are disallowable instruments, thus providing the Parliament with an ongoing overview.

Amendment 10 enables the ABA to require prior approval of programs if necessary, as in fact the ABT at the present moment is empowered to do. The eleventh amendment reflects the view of the House of Representatives Standing Committee inquiry and other inquiries about the need for wide consultation so that members of the Authority can reflect community standards. I understand that the Opposition is moving a further amendment relating to transmission of R-rated material over subscription services and I will be supporting that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I may be able to assist the Committee. Clearly there has been a misunderstanding and I do not want to compound it. The fact is that there was an agreement reached only a short time ago with the Opposition Whip because there is apparently a joint view that there is another piece of business that everybody wants to get through this chamber tonight before 7.30 p.m.

PARA.TAB: What I propose to do in the normal way at the expiration of this debate, which will be shortly, is to have the Government amendments put in the normal way and voted on. Also the Government will give leave to Senator Alston to make a general statement in respect of the Opposition's amendments, which is consistent with our joint desire to get this other piece of legislation through. This also applies to the Democrats if they wish to take that course by leave.

TALK.START.PARA: —And to have our amendments put.
—Yes, to have the amendments put.
—Order! In accordance with the order agreed on 16 June 1992, the time for consideration of these Bills has expired.
—Mr Chairman—
—There should be no debate. Senator Alston will have to seek leave.
—I seek leave in accordance with the indication given by the Minister.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —From this point on I shall assume honourable senators have leave as outlined by the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I turn to the second set of amendments standing in the name of the Opposition. I indicate that we will not be pursuing amendment No. 2 and amendment No. 5. Amendment Nos 1 and 3 are about reserving a special transponder for the Australian Broadcasting Commission and subsequently allowing SBS to access a channel following the introduction of digital compression technology. Amendment No. 4 requires broadcasters to keep records of written complaints. Amendment No. 6, we would argue, is superior to the Democrat approach in relation to the protection of journalistic privilege. It preserves what we believe to be the common law situation.

PARA.TAB: To the extent that the Government might take the view that the matter ought to be pursued by way of reference to a select committee or the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, that can take place at a later time. We would strongly argue that this will provide adequate protection, at least for the time being. That is why we prefer it to the open-ended approach as described by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) in relation to the Democrats' equivalent amendment.

Amendment Nos 7 and 8 relate to a review of television broadcasting technology. In other words, we reject the 1997 moratorium in relation to free to air television and the use of satellites. Amendment Nos 7 and 8 are designed to free up those areas. I move:
