TALK.START.PARA: —The next amendment in the name of the Opposition, if passed, would ensure that we do not have X-rated programs on pay television unless and until the completion of a full inquiry by the ABA into the impact on viewers of such programming guidelines. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 2, page 95, part 6, paragraph 10(1)(g), at end of paragraph add the following:

PARA.TAB: "but for the purposes of this Act, this paragraph must not take effect until the ABA has completed a full inquiry into the content and the impact on viewers of both `R' and `X' program material transmitted via subscription television broadcasting services".

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be supporting this amendment. We believe this is another Opposition mistake. The problem with it is that it would mean there would be no disabling devices on the equipment if they were needed after the review. So if the review says that there should be an R rating, there would be no disabling equipment on the machine.

—I also have difficulty with this amendment, though not necessarily the spirit of it, for that and other technical reasons which I have not been able to check out since I received it after 6 o'clock here in the chamber, and also because I believe that X-rated material is prohibited by the legislation in any case.

—I point out that this amendment is an addition to schedule 2, page 95, part 6, and leaves intact the provision relating to the disabling device which is contained in the legislation. So there is no technical problem. The provision in the schedule which relates to the disabling device is retained there. I could not quite follow what the Minister was saying because this amendment is simply an addition.
—I will put the amendment.
—Before you put that—
—Seek the leave of the Committee.
—I am working on the assumption that if the contributions are brief leave will not be necessary.

—We had been led to believe that the Australian Democrats were supporting this amendment. Indeed, I had spoken to members of the Democrats and they told us that they would. If Senator Powell still has a problem with the wording of the amendment after Senator Harradine has explained that the enabling device is in the schedule, then I would seek extra time. This is not the way to go about legislation when two of the parties want an amendment and, because of the guillotine, are unable to have their wishes put into legislation. If we could have time to word the amendment so that the Democrats agree to it, then the legislation would go through in a proper fashion. I ask for just a few minutes so that we can seek the cooperation of the Democrats in rewording the amendment, because I know they are of the opinion that the amendment should go through.
—I have no leeway except to put the question, which I am going to do. The question is that the amendment be agreed to.
—Mr Chairman—
—The Democrats have indicated, by staying in their place, that they are not going to support it.
—I would like Senator Powell to indicate to us that she has no intention of cooperating with us to find the correct words, because I am sure her colleagues would like to support us.
—Order! The question is that the amendment be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question put:

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. It was put to me that there was confusion in that last debate as to what was being voted on.
—There was no confusion.
—Order! There is a point of order before the Chair which the Chair would like to hear.

—I wonder why Senator Tate is so keen that it not be voted on again. I know he is emotionally involved in this issue. I am looking for the standing order relating to recommittal. Pursuant to that, I am asking that the vote be recommitted—in fact, that it be voted again.
—There is no such standing order, actually. However, if there is leave of the whole chamber, the matter can be recommitted.
—Mr Chairman, the procedure is that decency prevails, and where there has been a misvote or an accident, invariably the Government is prepared to recommit the vote.
—There was no confusion.

—There is. Mr Chairman, I ask that the Democrats be given the opportunity to revote. I have been told that there was confusion when they first came in and that the vote would be different if it was recommitted. If the Democrats have indicated that the vote would be different if it were recommitted, then surely the Government will be decent enough to allow us to recommit the vote.
—They do not know what they think.
—Then have a vote and find out.
—Order! I am going to ask Senator Coulter or Senator Powell whether either of them would like to make any statement in relation to this.

—Perhaps I could save some unnecessary indications at this point by foreshadowing that I will be moving a fourth amendment in the name of the Opposition, which will be substantially similar to the one that we have in front of us headed `amendment No. 3', but with the deletion of several words. It will be in that same form. We can accept the result of the ballot that has just taken place, but I am indicating that there will be a further opportunity to express a view on amendment No. 4.

—Are there any honourable senators who want that last vote recommitted? I am addressing my remarks to those who would like to have the vote recommitted because they would like to vote in a different way to the way they voted in that division.
—Yes.
—I would.
—I would.
—Under those circumstances, I am going to put the motion again.
—Mr Chairman, now that one senator at least has indicated a wish to have the vote recommitted—
—Not one, two.

—Wait a minute. Just listen. At least one senator has indicated a wish to have the vote recommitted for the purpose of changing a vote, and it is my view the vote should be put again. Mr Chairman, I think your ruling is correct.
—I am going to put the amendment again. The question is that the amendment, which is on a piece of paper headed `additional amendment No. 3', be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that agreement has been reached between all parties that the Bill now proceed through all stages. I table the explanatory memorandum to the Bill and I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Bill is to remedy a problem created with respect to the definition of "carrier" appearing in the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. The current definition of "carrier", which was inserted in the Interception Act by the Telecommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1991 ("the Transitional Act"), refers to carriers licensed under the Telecommunications Act 1991. From the commencement of that definition in the Interception Act on 1 July 1991 until the coming into force of licences issued to carriers by the Minister for Transport and Communications under section 57 of the Telecommunications Act, the corporations which became subject to those licences (which, at the time, were Telecom, OTC and AUSSAT) did not fall within the Interception Act's definition of "carrier".

As a result, there is some doubt about the authority conferred by warrants under the Interception Act to intercept communications during that period. There were in fact a number of warrants issued and executed during that period, and information intercepted under those warrants would, in due course, be relied on in prosecutions for serious offences. Since the Government is concerned at the possibility that any such prosecutions might fail simply because of a technical defect with the operation of the provisions in the Transitional Act, it has acted, with the understanding of the Opposition and the Democrats, to ensure that there is legislation in place to remedy the problems before the prosecutions commence.

Accordingly, the Bill seeks to do two things. First, it continues in operation during the relevant period the Interception Act's definitions of "carrier" and "Corporation" (meaning Telecom) that were in force immediately prior to the relevant period. Secondly, it applies the new definition of "carrier" provided for by the Transitional Act immediately after the relevant period. The Bill does these things in a way which will ensure that the operation of the Interception Act's substantive provisions relating to the issue and execution of warrants may be taken to have continued in a seamless way throughout the period between 1 July 1991 until the coming into force of the carrier licences granted by my colleague the Minister for Transport and Communications on 22 November 1991.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not be opposing this Bill, which the Government is introducing in an effort to head off a potential problem arising from the definition of `carrier' inserted last year in the Telecommunications (Interception) Act. In that Act, the definition refers to carriers licensed under the Telecommunications Act 1991. The definition was inserted by the Telecommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1991 that came into force on 1 July 1991. Unfortunately, the licences issued by the Minister for Transport and Communications did not actually come into force until nearly five months later, on 22 November 1991. I understand that technically, therefore, Telecom, OTC and Aussat were, arguably at least, not carriers for the purposes of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act during that time and that warrants issued during those five months for interceptions may have been invalid.

PARA.TAB: This Act corrects that defect by making clear that, notwithstanding the provisions of the transitional Act, the old definition of `carrier' continued until the licensing time on 22 November, when the new definition commenced. All agencies, therefore, will effectively have been carriers for the purposes of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act and none of the warrants issued will be technically invalid on this ground. From the Minister's second reading speech, we understand that the Government is concerned to prevent the possible failure of any prosecutions relying on evidence gathered from telephone interceptions undertaken on what might prove to be technically defective warrants. Therefore, we support the Government in its move to correct the defect through the passage of this Bill before the commencement of any such prosecutions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight because I had a phone call after lunch today from one of the senior management members of the Civil Aviation Authority. He wanted to see me and bring a team along to explain the CAA's position in relation to the TAAATS contract. It is really a bit late when we are 18 months into a contract for that approach to be made. The other side to it is that the Civil Aviation Authority was on numerous occasions afforded the opportunity by this Parliament to put its case—to the Public Works Committee, to the Senate Estimates Committee and during the committee stage of the Appropriation Bill. Not only did it have the opportunity, but also it was requested to do so, and it failed to do that.

PARA.TAB: In the course of what was a long conversation, it became quite apparent to me that there is an inadequate comprehension by the people concerned as to how public affairs are conducted in this country. It may be that, because they come from another country and are not long term career public servants, they do not understand the system here. Maybe that is one of the reasons for the mess we are in.

Some of the matters that were raised with me clearly need to be addressed in public. But first I would like to refer to Senator Cook's press conference today at the Press Club. I did not hear all of it because I was engaged in a conversation with one of the senior managers of the CAA, but I did understand Senator Cook, in response to a question as to whether he would freeze the negotiations between the Civil Aviation Authority and Thomson Radar while the inquiry was held into the selection process, to say that, while he initially thought such a freeze would be a good move, he is now convinced that that is not the correct option because it will involve the country in very high cost penalties. By implication, I draw from that that there will be political penalties.

I am quite alarmed at that interpretation of events. Any sense of propriety demands that those negotiations be put on hold until the inquiry is held. Senator Cook's statement today, as I understand it, says very clearly that Thomson is driving the whole program. It is driving the CAA management, which in turn is driving the Minister. That is a deplorable state of affairs. There is no argument at all for the negotiations to be carried on at the present time. There is no increased cost and, if Thomson is going to blackmail the Government with an increased cost, let us drop it here and now. Let us go to Hughes, Siemens, IBM, Raytheon or any other company where we will not only get a lower bid but also get the work completed much quicker and to a higher technical standard.

It is intolerable that we should be blackmailed by a company on that line. There is no technical reason why speed is of the essence; why speed has to be pursued in this way at this time. The facilities in Brisbane and Sydney are old and run down, but emergency systems can be moved in to cope with that in the short term. Indeed, some of the tenderers did offer to do that. It is just part of a general blackmail move. I deplore those sorts of actions by a tenderer, which should not be in the position where it can exercise so much power, or really any power at all, over the client.

I have no intention tonight of recapitulating the history of these long, extensive and involved tender negotiations but, as I said when I first expressed an interest in this, my initial concern was the announcement that there would be no Australian prime contractors in it. In March 1992, when it was announced that the preferred tenderer would have the lowest Australian content, I was again concerned. There has been a lot of nonsense talk by the management of the CAA about how they are not wasting money. They make the point that the taxpayer no longer funds aviation; that the aviation industry does.

The point to be made is that there is a great deal of waste coming from the mismanagement of the CAA. The difficulty—or the impossibility—for the Parliament is to measure how extensive that waste is. We are not presented with a balance sheet in any meaningful form that we can take before an Estimates committee. We have no Estimates coming before the Parliament so we cannot see what budgeting system exists, how much money these people are wasting. We can only get a glimpse of it here and there, and we can only assume from the small glimpses we have that it is considerably larger.
For example, an article in the Canberra Times on 11 September 1991 by Verona Burgess says:

SPEECH.PARA: The board of the Civil Aviation Authority agreed to buy the controversial new $300-$400 million two-centre air traffic control system without a full cost-benefit analysis, according to confidential documents obtained by The Canberra Times.

PARA.TAB: The board also agreed to write off up to $48 million by cancelling more than $200 million worth of contracts intended to upgrade the current system, the papers show.

SPEECH.PARA: That was $48m written off.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the CAA disputes that figure and says that it is about $25m or $28m. The point is that that is money wasted. The CAA delightfully referred to it as sunk costs, but it is my money and it is your money that has gone down the tube for no benefit at all. The CAA counters that argument by saying, `Well, by throwing out the system that we were going to spend that money on, we have saved $100m'. But that is a hypothetical argument and really has no substance. We have lost that money, and we have lost it through mismanagement.

Most of the evidence about waste is indirect. Evidence given at the hearing of the Joint Committee on Public Works in Brisbane on 8 April was that the CAA lost $13.9m on a building contract. It is also interesting to note the CAA's view that it is not taxpayers' money but that of the aviation industry. On page 103 of Hansard, the witness Mr Brown, said:

It is a freehold building on freehold land, owned by the Civil Aviation Authority. It was not paid for by the taxpayer; it was paid from charges to the aviation industry and, as I said, it met commercial justification. The plans were to accommodate some 200-odd people, including warehouse. The warehouse site was sold recently for in the order of $1.3m, and the purchase of the land was $0.5m. The building costs were in the order of $8m and then there was fit out. I cannot give you the exact figure, but I do not believe it was $13.9m. It was significantly less than that.

SPEECH.PARA: We cannot as a parliament get a handle on this waste, but it is quite clear that there is mismanagement leading to waste.

PARA.TAB: The relevance of what I am saying tonight about this waste is that one of the reasons why Australian primes were not included, and why the CAA selected a tenderer with a minimal Australian subcontracting content, was that it said it did not waste money. Yet here it is wasting tens, if not hundreds, of millions of dollars through its management program, and it is not prepared to give Australian industry a chance.

I am a very strong defender of Australian industry. Unlike the principals of the CAA, I happen to live in this country and I intend to go on living in this country; I do not have a contract which will expire in a year or two. I am interested in seeing Australian industry developed. I am prepared to pay a reasonable premium to ensure that Australian industry has the opportunity to develop. If the country of origin of air traffic control systems does not buy those systems, particularly in the electronics field, that equipment cannot be sold abroad. This is the dreadful situation that companies like AWA face at present. They are rejected in their own country and their overseas prospects are thereby significantly circumscribed.

As far as I can work it out, there is no premium in having a high Australian content in this TAAATS contract. I have talked to most of the principal tenderers, apart from Thomson, and they all tell me that the Australian companies were screwed down to the barest minimum figure. They were competitive with overseas contractors in every sense, particularly in a price sense. So it seems quite reasonable to assume that there was no premium to be paid for Australian content.

The central point of this whole dispute that has been dragging on for such a while before the Parliament is the accountability of the Civil Aviation Authority. That would never have arisen if there had been more intelligent management. I do not find it strange that there is a major inquiry currently in the New Zealand Parliament into the administrative practices of Messrs Baldwin and Edwards while they were running the New Zealand Aircraft Corporation. I am not saying that there was anything dishonest in what they did, but that probably, on the evidence we have seen in Australia, it was very badly organised. If it was organised to such a degree that there had to be a parliamentary inquiry, which is running currently, it must have been a pretty formidable exercise in mismanagement.

The argument of the management of the CAA at present is that it is a government business enterprise. Somehow there is an aura of untouchability about being a GBE. It is not accountable to anyone but its shareholder, which is the Commonwealth of Australia. That is the end of the story.Well, it is not the end of the story, because the Parliament represents the Commonwealth of Australia and the people of Australia. The attitude that is held by management—that as a GBE it is accountable to no-one—is carried on down the line and instilled by management. My earlier quotation from the Hansard of the Public Works Committee hearing reflects the point of view that the CAA is not really accountable to anyone; that it is not spending the money of the taxpayer but of the aviation industry. That notion seems to flow through the Department at present.

I have heard of numerous speeches that the Chief Executive Officer, Mr Baldwin, has made where he has defended his GBE concept and the lack of any need to answer. In fact, on the second page of a speech made to the Australian Aviation Club in Canberra on 28 May 1992, a copy of which I have here, Mr Baldwin, when talking about the CAA, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The principal purpose was to take it out of being managed and operated as a bureaucratic government department and convert it into what the name suggests—a business enterprise—along the lines of the private sector, and accountable through the board of directors to its shareholder—not through parliamentary committees of inquiries.

The legal point is that GBEs are not excluded from accountability to the Parliament. Government business enterprises are statutory authorities. A statutory authority is a body set up under statute. In lay terminology, that is a body set up by an Act of the parliament—in this case, an Act of this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: There is nothing in the Civil Aviation Act 1988, which is the Act that sets up the Civil Aviation Authority, that excludes the Civil Aviation Authority from accounting to the Parliament for its actions. It does not prescribe any special cases where it shall not be accountable. Therefore, it follows that it must account to the Parliament when it is called to account. It was called to account on a number of occasions by the Public Works Committee this year, and it refused to comply with those requests. It refused to supply the information requested at the Estimates hearing of this Senate earlier this year. It refused to supply information in the committee stage of the Appropriation Bill in this chamber a few weeks ago.

For the information of the senior management of the CAA, who seem to be totally incapable of understanding this point, I want to put this in its historical perspective. In 1971, the Senate resolved that there is no area of expenditure of public funds by statutory authorities which cannot be examined by Parliament or its committees. This declaration was reaffirmed on a number of occasions—in 1974, in 1980 and in 1984. In the 1980 resolution, the Senate declared that there are no areas of expenditure of public funds where statutory bodies have a discretion to withhold details or explanations from Parliament or its committees, and that this principle supervened any right of privacy. A similar resolution concerning the duty of statutory authorities to cooperate with parliamentary inquiries was passed in 1986.

Those resolutions of the Senate mean what they say. They have the force of law and any person who breaches them is put at risk of a charge of contempt of the Senate. As a consequence of that such a person can be brought before the Senate and fined. He or she can be put in gaol if the Senate so chooses, because refusal to cooperate is a rejection of the power of the Senate.

The arguments that the CAA has advanced against this are a litany of the old singsong of commercial-in-confidence, contractual obligations, the cost to Australia and all the other dissembling cliches that can be trotted out in such a situation to try to evade its responsibility. The point is that none of that will wash. It has a responsibility to be accountable to the Parliament. I cannot understand why, having been made aware of this on a number of occasions, it still persists with it. The arguments that the CAA uses of commercial in confidence or contractual obligations simply will not stand up to any sort of analysis at all.

This Parliament has been in business since federation in 1901. We have dealt with thousands, if not hundreds of thousands, of contracts with the Commonwealth Government in that time and no authority has ever tried this dissembling action on the Parliament. No authority is ever going to try it on and get away with it, because the importance is that, if the Parliament loses its responsibility to account for the expenditure of public funds, then the Parliament loses any authority it has in the land.

The rule of law in this country is supported by a voluntary act of the citizens and for the Government to enforce the rule of law, its authority and its probity has to be beyond dispute. We cannot afford this Parliament being seen to allow the upsetting of tendering procedures and procedures in relation to the assessment of tenders. These procedures have been worked out over 30 years and provide accountability for the expenditure of public funds by ensuring that an honest and correct evaluation has been made of those tender proposals. We cannot allow them to be set aside because in this case an authority pleaded that it had a special case and could not conform to the tendering procedures laid down by the Department of Administrative Services, and then refused to explain in detail, step by step, how it came to its decision. That is what the CAA is doing at the present time.

We cannot allow that pattern of contract assessment to become the norm for Australian tender evaluation. To do so would be to cede all the accountability the Parliament has for the expenditure of funds. This is a most fundamental issue and that is why the move taken by the CAA at the present time must be subjected to an independent evaluation along the lines proposed somewhat tentatively by Senator Cook and the Parliament must satisfy itself on this occasion that the integrity of the assessment process has been beyond dispute.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to deal briefly with the remarkable sensitivity that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is at present showing to criticism. I will not extend this debate into any imputations about motives or anything like that. I simply want to put on the record some extraordinary responses to media criticism of the Prime Minister in recent days.

PARA.TAB: I do not know whether the Senate is aware of the fact, but at the weekend the Sunday Age had a front-page article about the Prime Minister and his wealth in an article called `Inside the PM's piggy bank'. Apparently, the Prime Minister was far from pleased about the article and mid-morning on Sunday he rang the deputy editor of the Sunday Age, Mr Bruce Gutherie, to vent his anger. The Prime Minister then announced a ban on the paper. The deputy editor, Mr Bruce Gutherie, was interviewed on radio station 3AW and had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, I was a little flabbergasted—
that is, at receiving a call from the Prime Minister—

it was around about 11 o'clock Sunday and Mr Keating sort of arrived on the doorstop as it were and announced that he thought this was extraordinarily sensational journalism that was clearly not in the public interest and that somehow we were trying to paint a picture that he had acquired his assets sort of as illgotten gains. And I was sort of dumbfounded to be very honest, I would have thought that he had other things to do on a Sunday morning.
I think he was obviously hunting for someone's head to kick and I was the most convenient one. It was a forceful conversation—
this was of course by telephone—

bordering on arrogance, and I'd like to say I gave as good as I got, but he is a difficult man to converse with when he's in full flight. . . all we'd done was to bring together in one part of the newspaper public information about his assets, all this stuff had been published elsewhere before.
. . . certainly Mr Keating didn't challenge the accuracy of the piece apart from challenging a throwaway line where we suggest that his home had a harbour view in Sydney. . .

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the answer?
—The answer was no, he does not have a harbour view, apparently because of some new buildings. The journalist then asked Mr Gutherie:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . he basically declared some sort of ban on dealing with your newspaper, didn't he?
to which Mr Gutherie replied:

In the most vivid way, I think the expression was that Michael Gordon, who is our Canberra Correspondent, will be, quote, `cut dead', and through the duration of his Prime Ministership there would be no contact between his office or any members of our staff or indeed John Dawkins' office because we no longer deserved to be treated seriously. I mean, I felt, and the reason we did this story is that Paul Keating himself repeatedly in the Parliament has challenged John Hewson's wealth and in the last week Michael Baume, the Liberal Senator, had made accusations that Mr Keating was worth more than $2 million. . .
The interviewer said:
It sounds like you've touched a bit of a nerve with Mr Keating?
Mr Gutherie replied:

I think we have and I must admit I'm surprised because having had his go at me, he then had a one hour discussion with our editor, Steve Harris. So Mr Keating has spent the best part of 2 hours of his Sunday talking to two newspaper executives about a story which was really a collection of public information, surely he's got better things to do.
Mr Gutherie then went on to say:
I suspect that maybe the piggery which is a long way removed from the Paris Option was probably his life boat.
He has just chosen that he will no longer deal with us, but then again I think we can get by without him.
The interviewer then said:

Just one last thing Bruce, I would think it's all very well to say we're going to have a ban on one area of media, in this case, your paper, but I don't think that people who work within the media should sit still for it, it doesn't matter whether they work for `The Sunday Age' or not, I don't think the Prime Minister has any right to be selective in what he says.
to which Gutherie replied:

Yes, I think there is something in that John because he hasn't proved any inaccuracies here, it's just a disagreement with the tone of the piece and I think you can't have Prime Ministers going around selecting what newspapers, indeed any media, are going to cover.
The journalist ended up by saying:
. . . what a petty and petulant thing for Keating to do, hard to believe that the man is the Prime Minister when he carries out acts like that.

PARA.TAB: This morning there was an interview between Mr Steve Liebmann and Mr Harris, the editor of the Sunday Age on this matter in which Mr Harris said that clearly Mr Keating believed it was an invasion of his privacy. Mr Harris then said that Mr Keating said in the conversation with him that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the paper would be banned from any communication with his office and that of the Treasurer from that point on.
Mr Harris said:

Yes, I mean basically what he was saying was that we'd get no cooperation from either his office or the Treasurer's office, which would have made it very difficult obviously for our Canberra Correspondent, Mike Gordon, and other reporters based in Melbourne to operate effectively. We could have lived with that, it wouldn't have stopped the paper coming out and we certainly would have maintained our normal political coverage but it wouldn't have been made any easier. I am pleased to say that as of late yesterday some cooler sense has prevailed and the ban has been lifted.
Mr Harris went on to defend the printing of the article that offended Mr Keating by saying:

I think the reason why this sort of material should be in the public domain is that I think the public is entitled to make its own view as to sort of, what is the difference between the presented imagery, well polished imagery of our political leaders and what is the reality.
When he was asked:
In spite of the tongue lashing and the threats of bans which either were there but have now been lifted, you don't regret doing what the paper did last Sunday?
Mr Harris replied:
No, not at all and under similar circumstances we'll do it again.
Could I say how much I commend the journalists involved, particularly the editor, for standing up to this kind of heavying by Mr Keating.

PARA.TAB: It is not an isolated example. Mr Keating had been, in fact, notorious for expressing in vigorous terms his displeasure with newspaper articles and for, to use a popular expression, standing over journalists who chose to write articles which were not useful in Mr Keating's view, particularly in terms of invasions of his privacy. Obviously, there are some instances where, without doubt, there is an invasion of privacy which I think all politicians would regret. There is a widespread acceptance that politicians' privacy can be invaded and so, to an extent, one can sympathise with some elements of Mr Keating's concerns. One cannot, however, sympathise with the manner in which he responds to them. This was evident in recent times—for example, in his response to Mr Bruce Jones only last September when Mr Jones reported some facts about the use of a car. I quote from a newspaper report at the time which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The former Treasurer, Mr Keating, has issued a veiled threat to have the Tax Office audit journalists who wrote stories critical of him.
Mr Keating raised the prospect of audits on the press to a journalist who had revealed details of his car expenses.
On Sunday afternoon—
that is, in September—
the Sun-Herald's political reporter, Bruce Jones, received a phone call from Mr Keating.

A story by Mr Jones published that morning said Mr Keating was still using the Commonwealth car service almost two months after stepping down as Treasurer, and he had clocked up a $4,000 bill in just one month.
Mr Keating is believed to have said he was tired of journalists accusing people of rorting the system.
He is understood to have said that it would be `interesting' if the Tax Office audited the journalists in the parliamentary press gallery and examined some of their `bodgie' deductions.

This sort of standover tactic is not really the sort of thing one would expect from a man who, at that stage, was not Prime Minister but who apparently appears to have an excessive sensitivity every Sunday. Sundays are obviously Mr Keating's bad days and I suggest to those in the Press Gallery that they should avoid writing any articles critical of Mr Keating on Sundays because they will get a spray. I quote from another article by Mr Fred Brenchley which was in the Sydney Morning Herald. It reads:
You have hurt me and I will hurt you; you can count on it . . . you have given me a boot up the arse and I will make sure you get one.
The article goes on:
That's no bar-room brawl. It's a report of ex-Treasurer and putative Prime Minister Paul Keating threatening a Fairfax journalist, Sun-Herald Canberra correspondent Bruce Jones—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Senator Baume, even though you are quoting from a press article, I think you should have deleted one particular word.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is no defence; I have committed the same sin.
—I think I would prefer that you withdraw that particular word even though you are quoting. You could have put in a bleep.
—Can I say, I withdraw `the arse'—whatever connotation that might have in the circumstances—and I replace it with a bleep. The article says:

SPEECH.PARA: It's a report of ex-Treasurer and putative Prime Minister Paul Keating threatening of Fairfax journalist, Sun-Herald Canberra correspondent Bruce Jones, over his revelation that Keating as a backbencher had run up a Commonwealth car bill of $1,000 a day.

Unfortunately, it's not only typical of Keating's attitude to journalists and newspapers, but also of the Hawke Government's consistent approach to media of rewarding its perceived friends and wounding opponents.
The report goes on:

Keating, of course, was very bitter about Fairfax reporting of his Elizabeth Bay house and his private life. After his cross-media rules of the mid-1980s had driven the H&WT into News Ltd and promoted young Warwick into his disastrous privatisation of Fairfax, Keating remarked to Fairfax executives: `I've hurt you more than you hurt me.'

I just mention that I did a quick survey of the press gallery to see whether this sort of standover tactic has been going on as it used to and as, certainly, it still was last Sunday and last September. I was told that, in fact, these last two instances are reversions to type and that this sort of thing had not happened on a large scale for quite some time. Some journalists have said to me that Mr Keating used to be notorious for this sort of thing but had not, as I said, done so for a while until the Bruce Jones and the Sunday Age incidents.

PARA.TAB: As I said, there have been some other instances. Recently, I think, a couple of journalists have been harassed over the pig story and there have been some colourful expletives to various journalists describing their physical characteristics. But it does seem to me worth raising with the Senate the question of whether this sort of behaviour is appropriate. As I said, I do not intend to go down the track which would encourage any question of whether imputations are being put, but it seems Mr Keating is highly sensitive to criticism. It is for the public to determine whether this kind of response to such criticism is appropriate for a Prime Minister and whether it is reasonable for members of the media to be stood over in this way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to detain the Senate for long, but I want to make a few comments on the matters that my colleague Senator Baume has raised because I think they are important. The first comment I would like to make is that some days ago in the Senate I was accused by Senator Button of promoting the politics of envy. The reason Senator Button said that was that I had raised in the Senate this issue that we have a very wealthy man as a Prime Minister. On our side of politics—
—Who have we got as Leader of the Opposition?

—I will come to that in a moment, Senator Collins. On our side of politics we think that the acquiring of assets in an honest manner is fine. In fact, one of the views of the Liberal Party is that the creation of wealth is a very important value in human society and should be encouraged. But the problem is this, and it relates to Senator Collins's interjection: if one is a wealthy man—and I do not think there is any dispute that Mr Keating is a wealthy man—one cannot really run the class war line. That is actually the problem.
—The worst thing about it is that you can't get into heaven.

—Senator Collins has raised an interesting point. He was referring to the comment in the Bible that it is harder for a wealthy man to enter the kingdom of heaven than a camel to fit through the eye of the needle or words to that effect. I am glad that Senator Collins is on record as thinking that Mr Keating might find it difficult to go to heaven. I think that was a very bold comment for Senator Collins to make.

PARA.TAB: The point I am making is that this issue has arisen because when Mr Keating came into office he made a feature of raising the class war issue. He attacked Dr Hewson and John Howard for being class traitors. He made a big feature of this. We remember his attacks on John Elliott and others—and very robust attacks they were. The point I was making—which I think Senator Button failed to pick up and which I think Senator Collins is picking up; he is noted for being one of the brighter people on the front bench—is that it is a bit rich for a multi-millionaire Prime Minister and a multi-millionaire Treasurer to go out into the community, bag other people for being wealthy, and then effectively try to identify themselves as authentic spokesmen, to use Mr Keating's terms, of the scrubbers of this world.

I want it on the record that I do not bag Mr Keating for being wealthy. As far as I am concerned, good on him if he has acquired these millions. I do not argue that we should not have a wealthy Prime Minister. But I do argue that for a wealthy Prime Minister, who ceaselessly tries to hark back to the jargon of the class war, to raise wealth as an issue in public debate, is a little bit rich, if those opposite do not mind me saying so.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the worst pun I have ever heard.

—I do not believe that the community is going to wear it. The reason that Mr Keating is so upset is that he has been caught out by his own rhetoric. Every time Mr Keating goes out and runs this class war line, as he did time and time again in the Parliament, people will say, `But you're a multi-millionaire and your Treasurer is a very wealthy man too'. That is the point I wish to put before the Parliament this evening.

PARA.TAB: The second point I wish to put before the Parliament also relates to a matter raised by Senator Baume. Mr Keating has a reputation as a head kicker, and I do not think anyone in this Parliament disputes that Mr Keating is a head kicker. Those opposite voted him into office not because of his public policy success—no-one could have voted in Mr Keating because he had a success in public policy; he was the guy who planned our recession—but because they thought, `Here is a guy who can really kick heads. Anyone who puts his head up attacking the Government can be given a good kick'. That is how those opposite defined leadership.

The problem is this: if you have a man whose reputation is based on being a head kicker, if you give it out you have to be prepared to take it. I believe that Mr Keating is the classic schoolyard bully. He can dish it out to all and sundry, but as soon as someone else gets up and gives it back to him we find that Mr Keating has the proverbial glass jaw.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! Senator Kemp, I do not like to be pedantic, but I believe you used an expression that is unparliamentary.

TALK.START.PARA: —What expression was that?
—Schoolyard bully.
—Is `schoolyard bully' unparliamentary?
—Yes.
—That is certainly news to me. Is the word `bully' unparliamentary?
—I presume it is, too.
—Can we seek guidance on that?
—I ask Senator Kemp to withdraw and bring his remarks to a close.

—Is the word `thug' unparliamentary? Mr Keating has classically showed that he is the man who can dish it out to people, and he is a man with a name for that. But when he has to cop it we find, as Senator Baume has so well expressed to the Parliament this evening, that Mr Keating starts to howl. I think Senator Baume brought two very important messages before this Parliament this evening which gave us a better perspective of the man who now runs this country.

—I certainly do not make a practice of rising in the adjournment debate, and I will be brief this evening. I want to speak now because I will not be here for the adjournment debate tomorrow. I simply want to pay tribute, on behalf of not only all honourable senators in the chamber but also all members of the House of Representatives, to a person who has become an institution in this Parliament. He is spending his last day at work tomorrow. That person is Bruce Webster. He has become the public voice of this Parliament—and a very pleasant and gentlemanly voice he is, which often does not reflect the reality of the Parliament that he has so ably and so enthusiastically represented over a long period publicly on a number of radio stations.

PARA.TAB: One of the reasons I say this is that, for a person who puts as much into his job as Bruce Webster does, the end of his working career and his last day at work is obviously an experience which contains a lot of emotions, many of them mixed. I have no doubt, knowing Bruce as I do and as most people do in this place as the pleasant and professional gentleman that he is, that he will be quite sad about spending his last day in this Parliament. So I would like to pay tribute to Bruce for the very able job that he has done in presenting what goes on in this Parliament as he has done for a great number of years now.

I have often woken up to Bruce Webster on ABC radio. It has always been a wonder to me how he describes what is going to take place that day with such enthusiasm, knowing the reality of the proceedings and how fundamentally dreary most of them will be. I commend him for quite often performing the impossible task of making something which in reality is very dreary sound extremely interesting. I am sure that all honourable senators and members join me in expressing our gratitude for the very able job that Bruce Webster has done in presenting a public face for this Parliament for a long time. We wish him all the best in what I hope will be a very happy and successful retirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was of a mind to say something about Bruce Webster tomorrow, but as the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) has raised it I simply take the opportunity to endorse everything that he has said. What strikes me about the contribution of Bruce Webster over the years is the way in which he has enhanced the stature of this institution.
—We don't give him a lot of help.

—I was about to say, as is said from time to time, that we need help in this area. I think we should appreciate that. In helping present us to the Australian people in the way that we would like to be presented, he has done us a great favour as well. So we certainly record our appreciation for his very long contribution and excellent professionalism. He is someone who will be very much missed.

—I would like to add my own few words to the tribute to Bruce Webster. One of the things that has always amazed me is that, in contemplating the day's proceedings in Parliament, Bruce Webster could do so cheerfully. I add my wishes to those of Senator Collins and Senator Hill to Bruce Webster on an interesting and well earned retirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No money has been provided in the past four financial years to Mona Mona Mission, either for the construction of a bridge or the construction of a sawmill. However, the Mona Mona community commenced on the Community Development Employment Projects scheme on 1 April 1992 and, as part of its activities under this scheme, it intends to demolish an old existing bridge and replace it with a low-level causeway.

The community will be using equipment and materials purchased through Community Development Employment Projects grant funds to undertake the construction of a causeway. $2,000 of these funds is also planned to go towards maintenance of an old existing sawmill.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 12 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will the Minister table in the Parliament the draft schedules of concessions and commitments offered on agricultural and non-agricultural items by Australia in Geneva in March 1992 referred to in the reply to question on notice no. 1780 (Senate Hansard, 28 April 1992, p.1741).
(2) Will the Minister table in the Parliament the draft agreement on Sanitary and Phytosanitary measures referred to in the reply to question on notice no. 1780.

(3) Will the Government undertake to fully consult with the Australian Agricultural Council and Australian Rural Industries, including the beef, pork and poultry industries, before any decision is taken by Australia to accede to the proposed new GATT code on Sanitary and Phytosanitary measures referred to in question on notice no. 1780.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The draft schedules are negotiating documents and as such it is not appropriate that they be tabled in Parliament.
However I should be happy to make officers of my Department available to answer any queries that he might have on their detail.

(2) Similarly it would not be appropriate to table the draft text on sanitary and phytosanitary measures in Parliament. However I have arranged for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to provide a copy to the honourable senator.

(3) The Australian Agricultural Council has been kept informed about the developments in the Uruguay Round through the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy who chairs the Council. Australian rural industries have been kept informed through the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service as well as through officers of my Department. I should point out to the honourable senator that Australia and all the other participants will not be able to pick and choose which aspect of the Uruguay Round they will accede to.

The Round is a global undertaking and all countries will be expected to join all the new agreements negotiated in the Round. At the appropriate time the Government will have to assess the balance of benefits and costs to Australia from the Round as a whole before ratifying the outcome. This may involve further adjustments to our bound commitments on agricultural items, on non-agricultural items and on services.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support upon notice, on 19 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the provision of Radar from the East Sale RAAF sensor at Civil Air Traffic Control (ATC), Melbourne:
(1) Has the AUSCATS-3 radar software system been fully commissioned at Civil ATC, Melbourne and does the system now include material supplied from the sensor located at the East Sale RAAF base.

(2) If material from East Sale has not been fully incorporated into the AUSCATS-3 system what are the reasons for it not being included in the System and can any indication be given regarding when it can be expected to come on line.
(3) If material from East Sale is already on line, what effect has it had on the operations of Civil ATC, Melbourne.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) AUSCATS VERSION 3 has been operational at Melbourne since 25 May 1992. This allows for the input and display of data from RAAF Secondary Surveillance Radar at East Sale.

(2) A number of technical deficiencies have been identified with the radar data from East Sale. These relate to both the characteristics of the RAAF Radar, the monitoring systems used with the RAAF Radar and loss of data through an interfacing unit provided by the CAA.
(3) It is hoped that the technical deficiencies will be corrected in about four weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 27 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the extensive use of circulation cleaner and powder acid by the dairy industry and by cheese producers in Australia:
(1) Have these products received a certificate of clearance from the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemical Council; if so, when.
(2) What are the risks involved to persons using these products.
(3) What restrictions and conditions are placed on the use of these products.
(4) What are the main methods of disposal currently practised by the industry and what methods are recommended by the Minister.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Approval of compounds for use for cleaning purposes in dairy factories is a responsibility of individual State authorities rather than a current function of the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemical Council. I understand that the only States which administer control in this regard at the moment are Victoria and Queensland. Approval is based on compliance with the following Australian Standards:

ANSWER.PARA: AS 1389, 1973 Acid detergents for use in the dairy industry,
AS 1398, 1982 Iodophores for use in the dairy industry,
AS 1400, 1981 Heavy duty alkaline detergents (for in place cleaning in dairy factories), and
AS 1803, 1982 General purpose detergents for use in the dairy industry.

PARA.TAB: While provision for national coverage of dairy cleansers is included in the Commonwealth's Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act, this function will not be assumed from State authorities until suitable regulations have been drafted.
(2) I am advised that the risks to operators through incorrect usage are likely to include, in general terms:
(i) chemical burns if compounds come into contact with skin or eyes, or if dry powders are inhaled,
(ii) burns and chemical burns from heat and vapours generated if concentrated solutions of acid and alkali are mixed incorrectly.

(3) Responsibility for providing directions for usage rests with manufacturers. The Australian Code of Practice for Dairy Factories, administered jointly by the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service and State dairy authorities requires that "Detergents and other hazardous material shall be stored in a manner that will prevent contamination of dairy produce."

(4) Disposal requirements are a matter for State and local authorities. I understand that general practice is to use waste disposal farms for disposal of factory sanitary drainage and that this is subject to monitoring by the environmental protection and health authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 28 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the almost daily reports of maiming and death caused the Cambodian people by plastic anti-personnel mines and concern raised during Coral Sea Week regarding the need to remove live ammunition from the scene of World War II Pacific battle zones:
(1) Is Australia providing funds in overseas aid commitments to address this urgent problem, particularly in Cambodia;

(2) If so, what avenues are open to the Australian Defence Industry to tender for mine and munition clearance operations and do Australian firms, such as Austsar have the expertise available to carry out this work;
(3) if not, does it plan to allocate funds for this purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable Senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Australia is not providing funds in overseas aid commitments for ammunition clearance from the scene of World War II Pacific battle zones. The honourable Senator should address questions on such activities which may have been carried out under Australia's Defence Cooperation Program to the Minister for Defence.

The comprehensive settlement of the Cambodian conflict provides for mine clearance and training operations to be coordinated and supervised by trained personnel of the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia (UNTAC). Australia is not directly involved in any of UNTAC's mine clearance activities. We are, however, supporting the operation through our assessed contribution (1.51 per cent) to the UNTAC budget.

In addition to this contribution to UNTAC, a total of $2.2 million has been provided to the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) for the repatriation of displaced Cambodians living in camps on the Thai border. Mine-clearance is a crucial concern for the UNHCR, since scarcity of mine-free land is one of the major constraints on the repatriation operation. UNHCR has conducted mine identification surveys in Cambodia and mine awareness training in the displaced persons camps on the Thai border. However, UNHCR is not playing a principal operational role in mine clearance.

(2) Parts of the mine clearance operation in Cambodia are the subject of UN tenders. It is open to any Australian company to tender for UN contracts, whether they be in the area of mine clearance or in more traditional development work. Information about procurement opportunities with the UN is systematically collected and disseminated by AUSTRADE. Companies interested in working with the UN should contract AUSTRADE for advice on how best to proceed. I am not in a position to say whether Australian firms have the necessary expertise to effectively carry out mine clearance work in Cambodia or the Pacific.

(3) The Australian Government does not propose to specifically allocate funds from overseas aid commitments for the purposes of mine or live ammunition clearance from either Cambodia or the Pacific World War II battle zones.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Ministers listed below (Question Nos *1996—*1997) upon notice, on 28 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: Has the enquiry being conducted by the New Zealand Government's Special Committee on Nuclear Propulsion been discussed at meetings attended by the Minister, or ministerial or departmental officials; if so: (a) what were the dates, venues and purpose of those meetings, and the names and designations of those who were present; (b) what views were expressed by the Australian officials about the enquiry; and (c) what information was passed to New Zealand participants on matters being considered by the committee.

QUESTION.PARA: *1996 Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (a), (b) and (c) At the specific request of the Special Committee on Nuclear Propulsion established by the New Zealand Government the Australian Government has made available officials as independent witnesses and experts. In providing assistance to the Committee the Government has been concerned that it should respond in a constructive and helpful manner to the Committee's requests, and that Australian officials convey relevant information about Australian practices in this area.

Meetings have been held at various levels to discuss the Australian Government's assistance to the Committee. I do not propose to go into the details of any meetings as they were routine and in keeping with the Government's desire to provide the Committee with the benefit of Australia's experience. That experience is well documented in the 1989 Report by the multi-party Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade "Visits to Australia by nuclear powered or armed vessels", which has been made available to the Committee. The Government has also made available to the Committee information which is in the public domain (including the Government Response to the Senate Report and the Operations Manual, "Visits by nuclear powered warships to Australian ports") on nuclear propulsion.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer upon notice, on 1 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What procedures are in place to police the prohibition on foreign investment in Australian urban real estate.
(2) How many convictions have occurred and how much revenue has been raised in the last 12 months in policing this prohibition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Not all foreign investment in Australian urban real estate is prohibited. Generally speaking, the policy is only restrictive in respect of established housing, where acquisitions by foreigners are not permitted, except in certain categories which are exempt or normally approved, including:
Australian citizens living abroad,
foreign nationals entitled to permanent residence in Australia,
foreign companies seeking to house executives in Australia, and
foreign nationals temporarily in Australia for more than a year, subject to
the house being used as the principal residence and sold when the occupant departs Australia.
Full details of the policy are set out in the Government's booklet: Australia's Foreign Investment Policy—A Guide for Investors, which is available at Australian Government Bookshops.

In regard to policing, where alleged breaches of the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act are brought to the Government's attention, they are followed up, and would be referred if necessary to the Federal Police or Australian Government Solicitor for appropriate action. However, it is the experience of the Government that compliance with foreign investment policy is generally high.
(2) None and nil.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 2 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What cultural programs are offered by the Department for implementation in overseas countries?
(2) How are cultural programs promoted overseas?
(3) What is the total departmental expenditure on cultural programs overseas, both capital and recurrent costs?
(4) What methods of coordination are applied to maximise the availability of cultural programs on an equitable basis relevant to the size of each individual diplomatic post?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department offers its cultural programs for implementation in overseas countries through the Cultural Relations Branch of the Public Affairs Division of the Department. These programs are drawn up in consultation with Australian Diplomatic Missions overseas and where relevant in consultation with the Boards of the various bilateral foundations which are co-located within the Branch. These foundations are the Australia-Japan Foundation, the Australia-China Council, the Australia-Indonesia Institute, the Australia-New Zealand Foundation and the Australia-France Foundation.

The Government is in the final stages of formally establishing the boards for the Australia-India Council and the Australia-Korea Foundation. The Department also undertakes widespread consultation with a range of bodies such as The Australia Council, Musica Viva, the Australian Film Commission, art galleries and museums, the Australian Sports Commission and academic institutions and Commonwealth and State Departments.

The cultural programs which are offered are designed to project Australia overseas as a stable, democratic, multicultural, technologically advanced society displaying excellence and innovation across the broad spectrum of artistic and intellectual activity and to further Australian foreign and trade policy interests. These programs comprise a wide spectrum of activities including performing arts, the visual arts, sport, the promotion of Australian studies, academic exchanges, and youth exchanges.

(2) The cultural programs are promoted through the Government's diplomatic and consular posts overseas. Where major activities are undertaken these will be promoted by host organisations such as art galleries, theatres and academic institutions, sometimes in association with a consultant, curator or entrepreneur who has been commissioned by the Department for a particular project or promotion.
(3) Total expenditure on cultural relations programs in 1991/92 was $7.409 million, comprising $3.95 million in running costs and $3.459 million in trust account expenditure.

(4) The cultural programs are drawn up within the Cultural Relations Branch in consultation with overseas posts. The budget allocation is made on a country by country basis determined by the Head of the Public Affairs Division. In the case of the bilateral foundations, the content of the cultural programs is determined by the boards of the foundations.

The secretariats of the boards work closely with the sections of the Cultural Relations Branch and the secretariat of the Australia Abroad Council. In these ways every effort is made to maximise the availability of cultural programs to diplomatic posts. In general, programs are available on an equitable basis, based on the budget allocation to each country.
